DEBATE.TITLE: CHILD CARE (NATIONAL CHILDREN'S SERVICES PROGRAM) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Dunn) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced:
A Bill for an Act to amend the Child Care Act 1972 to establish targets and standards for the development of a national children's services program, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Dunn) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.
SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

I present to the Senate a Bill to amend the Child Care Act 1972. My amendment deals with the public provision of child care through a national child care program. High quality child-care is not a second-class alternative to parental care but a valuable supplement offering positive contributions to child development. Children in late twentieth century industrialised countries lack the broader based child-rearing units of the pre-industrial communities. They tend to be dependent on either one or two adults for their primary care.

The experience of group care, with appropriate developmental input from skilled carers, has been shown to be of benefit to children. The benefits are most obvious for those whose background resources are limited, but all children benefit from stable quality care. It is therefore important that children in their most vulnerable years, when they have the highest learning curve, have access to quality care. It is unreasonable to expect single parents to bear the responsibilities which cross-cultural and historical evidence show were previously borne by a wider group. All parents need access to quality care because it enhances their capacity to satisfy the varied needs of children. It also allows parents to choose the most appropriate mix of paid work, domestic caring and leisure.

The Prime Minister drew attention to child poverty in Australia with his promise to eliminate child poverty by 1990. The proposed increases in payments for children shows that this Government is prepared to attack the intractable problem of child poverty, but child poverty requires more than direct payments of money. Sole parents on a pension and their children are rapidly becoming Australia's `underclass' trapped in poverty with its attendant social and health problems.

Affordable and accessible child-care is prerequisite of work force participation by sole parents, yet nothing in the Treasurer's April statement removed barriers to the employment of sole parents caught in the poverty trap. If parents can't escape the poverty trap, how can their children? A commitment to a minimum level of child care will be recognised as a commitment to the elimination of child poverty.

The proportion of children being reared in single parent households is growing. There is an increasing dependence by sole parents on pensions and benefits as women withdraw from the labour market for child rearing. Where women were working before single parenthood, they tend to retain their jobs if they can move back to them soon after the birth of a child. Adequate child care can thus reduce the costs to the community of single parenthood. Many families, especially young families with mortgages, find it essential to have two incomes to maintain a standard of living above the poverty line. These families cannot afford to lose one income for the years until a child enters school. The birth rate among such couples will decline rapidly unless adequate child care is available.
Social Justice and Equity

Some members of the Government feel that there is no justification for the public funding of a broad child-care program and consider that the only role of government should be to subsidise fees for the very poor. But child-care should be provided from the public purse for reasons of social justice and equity. The commercial sector does provide some centre-based care, but there is no evidence that this is being provided in response to the real pattern of demand.

The situation in New South Wales shows that commercial centre developments are set out in areas where child care is already established. Where it might be expected that there would be a ready market for more costly care, such as in high income areas, there are few commercial centres. It is clear that commercial centres alone will not provide for the child care needs of the community.

The Government's program was restructured in 1983, when the planning model replaced the submission model. This has resulted in services being offered in areas of high need rather than in areas where articulate people were able to prepare persuasive submissions. The current guidelines ensure access for those who need child care for work-related reasons. Furthermore, the contribution of the second income earner to the family positively benefits the community by reducing both poverty and dependence on sole parent pensions in cases of marital breakdown.

The Government's commitment to equal opportunity and economic independence for women can be judged by the extent to which it is prepared to provide child-care services. On a broader scale, the provision of day care services should properly be seen as part of a compact between the community and parents to share the responsibility of child rearing.
Economic Benefits

The financial value of child-care services should be measured by their contribution to the capacity of families to remain economically independent. The access of the labour market to the skills of those women, and the few men, who take the primary responsibility for children's care should also be taken into account. Many advantages flow from the provision of child-care which enables the primary care giver to enter the work force. They include the following.

1. Families benefit; Many families have been able to avoid poverty, maintain housing mortgages, buy a house (in spite of the inflated housing market), move from Social Security payments into paid employment and improve living standards because of the provision of child-care which allows women to respond to the increased demand for female labour.

Of women with children in the age group which requires day care, 43% are in the labour force. The increase of 16% in the past two years, mainly in part-time workers, will obviously continue and require a growth in child care services to meet the demand.

2. Household disposable income is up; The return of women with small children to the work force has allowed the Government to make much of the fact that household disposable income is up, even though wages have fallen in real terms. Thus the provision of child-care for these women has effectively softened the economic impact of the Government's wages policy.

3. There is a cost benefit to the Government; A recent study by ANU economists shows that the present children's services program could net more than $100m to the Commonwealth budget when the costs are offset against the gains in tax, Medicare levy and savings in Social Security payments. The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has stated that this figure is a distortion of data provided in the paper. His dismissal of claims that major net fiscal benefits will accrue to the Commonwealth budget does not detract from the fact that subsidised child-care has enabled many women to enter or re-enter the paid work force.
Their work force participation clearly does bring a cost benefit to the Commonwealth.

4. The labour market benefits; Shortages in traditional female employment areas, such as nursing, are being reduced by skilled women returning to or remaining in the work force because of the provision of child-care.

5. Taxpayers benefit; the falling birth rate and the ageing of the Australian population make it important to have maximum labour force participation by women of child-bearing age in order to reduce the fiscal burden on the individual taxpayer. By 2025 the over 65s will constitute 16 per cent of the population-they presently make up 10.5 per cent-and the under 15s will constitute only 19 per cent of the population. That represents a 50 per cent growth in the over 65 age group and a drop of 22 per cent in the under 15s. This will result in an increased demand for services and retirement income from the public sector.

In view of these demographic changes, the absence of an adequate child-care system will have two negative consequences. The first is that the burden on the working population of supporting the over 65s will be higher if there is limited work force participation by younger women. The second is that the Australian birth rate will continue to fall below replacement level unless young women are encouraged to have children by the provision of child-care which allows them to retain their place in the work force. There is considerable evidence that women are already delaying child bearing or having fewer or no children because of economic pressures.
Existing Government Policy

The Government must be commended on its approach to work-related children's care services and, in particular, its achievement in doubling the number of day care places during its period in office. The current provision is meeting at least 50 per cent of present need for those below school age. The latest ABS figures on child care show that between 1984 and 1987 there was a 60 per cent increase in the use of centre-based child care services. This included a 34 per cent increase in those using care primarily for work-related reasons. But those efforts have been conducted in an environment which does not seen to adequately acknowledge the importance of child-care. Child-care should be a priority in the development of social and economic policies.
The most common types of child-care are:
1. Long day care, or extended hours care, is centre-based care for pre-school children for eight or more hours a day;
2. Full day care is centre-based care for pre-school children for between six and seven and a half hours a day (this is frequently described as pre-school or kindergarten);

3. Out of school hours places are those centre-based places provided for the care of children of primary school age, which will vary according to the school entry age determined by each state and/or territory;
4. Occasional care is centre-based short-term care for pre-school children for between one and twenty-four hours a day, but with an `in principle' limit of 12 hours a month;

5. Family day care is agency supervised care for up to four children aged between under one year and twelve years, in an approved carer's home. This provides a mix of out of school hours care and day care, depending on the age of the children.
The Government's current children's services program has the following components:
(i) capital subsidies in conjunction (where appropriate) with other providers of capital, such as the States and local government, for construction of centres;

(ii) an operational grant which allows for a level of quality control and limits the maximum fee to a reasonable level, taking into account the generally lower wage levels of women workers. The average $15 per week offered to all children in funded day care centres is, in fact, less than the $20 subsidy offered through the dependent spouse rebate;
(iii) a planning system which ensures that new centres are sited where they are most needed. A set of access guidelines ensures that certain groups such as sole parents receive priority;
(iv) services for out of school care and vacation care which are also important to working parents;
(v) funding for occasional care services which recognises that women out of the work force also need access to some form of childcare.

These components comprise a national program which recognises the needs of both the children and the women who are usually primarily responsible for their care. The provision of publicly funded day care under this program has made day care services available in areas of need, for the more costly younger age group of children, and for hours which reflect the needs of parents for child care. While the proportion of those paying fees over $45 has risen by 60 per cent, they are still less than a fifth of those using day care services. In other words, the bulk of users are subsidised and low-income users. This suggests that the program is effectively targeted, as far as it goes.
Deficiencies in the Government's Program

In the first two years of this Government there was substantial growth in the program. This was most noticeable because it was in stark contrast to the rate of expansion during Senator Chaney's time as Minister for Social Security. From 1983-1985, of the new places funded there were 11,000 in centre-based day care, 12,000 in family day care, and almost 5,000 in out of school hours care. In 1985 the government announced triennium funding for 20,000 new places. At the end of the 1985-88 triennium the Department of Community Services and Health reported that about 35,500 places had been approved in the previous three years.

It appears that additional funding was provided for the 15,500 places over and above those announced by the Government at the beginning of the triennium. This is not the case. Some of the new places were allocations from the year prior to the triennium and 15,000 were out-of-school hours care, which costs about one-fifth of centre-based day care. In the three-year period 1985-88, only about 10,000 centre-based long day care places were provided. This was 1,000 less than the 11,000 centre-based long day care places approved in the previous two-year period. Some of the intended centre-based long day care places were traded for the lower subsidy and family day care places, which have no capital costs. As a result of these trade offs, only about 6,000 more places were provided for the three years to 1988 than were approved in the previous two years. Moreover, the totals for the triennium should be calculated over a four-year period, not three. The last triennium was supposed to be completed by June 1988, but the period was extended until December 1988 and there has been no new money in this year's budget for children's services.

The Government has announced another triennium, starting in the 1989-90 financial year, and promised a further 30,000 places. However, the proportion of centre-based long day care places has been further reduced, and there will only be 4,000 of these. The same number of places is planned for family day care; the balance will consist mainly of out of school hours care.

The centre-based day care figures show the decline in real expansion. The rate of new centre-based day care places approved has been reduced from an annual rate of 5,500 places in the first two years, 1983-1985, to 2,500 in the next four years, 1985-1989, and will be down to about 1,333 per annum in the next triennium. At this rate, there will be nil expansion within a few years.

The Government's own National Agenda for Women document acknowledges the importance of child-care for women and appears to be committed to adequate quality care, but this has not resulted in a program that will answer the growing demand for quality child care in our rapidly changing society. Thirteen years after the passing of the original Act by a coalition Government in 1972, the present Government changed the Act by dropping the level of operational subsidy and detaching the subsidy from the employment of qualified staff.

Several Government Ministers regard child-care provision as an optional expenditure and spirited representations were needed to persuade them to approve even the meagre increases of the last triennium. A forward plan should be developed in the framework of an Act which commits resources to the expansion of the program over a defined period.
The Bill

This Bill to amend the Children's Services Act seeks to remove the children's services program from the political margins. It proposes a child-care program that meet 80 per cent of the present need for child-care services by the year 2001. This program would provide services for children under school age, including appropriate mixes of centre based and family day care, as well as services for older children.

The draft Bill therefore proposes that a total of 220,000 long day care places be the target for the year 2001. This would be achieved by the provision of public funds for a further 80,000 long days care places. This assumes that there are 80,000 places in the public sector already established, and that the existing 23,000 commercial places would double over the next decade. It establishes a long term target of providing day care places at the rate of about 7,000-8,000 per annum, only slightly above the 5,500 actually approved in the first two years of this Government's tenure.

To achieve this the Bill would require, at most, a doubling of the recurrent costs of the present program-that is, in 1989 dollars, about $500m in 2001. If most of the places were to be centre based, that is, about 200 centres per year or about 8,000 places, capital costs might add another $500m or about $50m each year. This assumes land will be made available as it is presently. This is a very modest sum in comparison to the total budget and would represent about 6 per cent of the departmental budget or less than 1 per cent of Government outlays.
In addition it is important that there should be no changes to the present Commonwealth program that involve the incorporation of any of the following:

(a) Vouchers to replace any of the existing funding, including the operational subsidy. The introduction of vouchers would undermine the present program's major role in ensuring access to care in low-income areas and for low-income people.
(b) Any form of tax rebate which would advantage higher income earners at the expense of direct funding for the program.

The provision of children's services should be regarded as highly as access to health care and education. It is essential to the prevention and alleviation of poverty. An adequate child-care program will restore to women the reasonable expectation that they can choose to raise children without suffering economic hardship. It will also make available to the community the work skills of child-bearing women. Budget outlays will be recovered in increased revenues. I commend this Bill to the Senate as a measure which is both pragmatic and equitable.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (SUPERANNUATION) BILL 1989INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988INCOME TAX (FUND CONTRIBUTIONS) BILL 1988INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 1 June.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the amendment to be moved on behalf of the Government to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill. I point out that two copies of the amendment, which are slightly different, have already been circulated. The one which will be moved by the Government is the one with a sixth page.
—Could you read it out?
—The sixth page is an addition to the amendment previously circulated.
—You are amending the one you tabled yesterday or circulated yesterday?
—I am adding to it. The sixth page which Senator Watson has asked me to read says:

SPEECH.PARA: `(5) This section does not apply to an ADF in relation to a year of income unless the Commission is satisfied that the whole of the benefit that would accrue to the ADF from the application of this section in relation to the year of income has been or will be, passed on to eligible depositors.'.''.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989
Clause 9.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that amendments No. (5) and No. (6) moved by Senator Haines be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise simply to indicate that the Australian Democrats will not be supporting their own amendments. I will now hand over to Senator Bishop to do whatever she likes in the way of rubbishing me for that.
—Do you wish to seek leave to withdraw your amendment, Senator Haines?

—If that is the easiest way around this. I sought leave originally to reput them last week when the Opposition's amendment to exempt the earnings tax did not include pool superannuation trusts. There has been a considerable move in other directions since then. If it is the wish of the Committee that those amendments be withdrawn, I am certainly prepared to seek leave to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments-by leave-withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines gave me an open invitation to make comment upon the position we have reached. It is a temptation that I cannot resist.
—Senator Bishop, you will have to resist in so far as you must relate your remarks to clause 9.

—Indeed, Mr Chairman. My remarks will be very pertinent to clause 9. We found ourselves in this situation when we last met on 1 June when the Opposition was of a mind-it is still of a mind-to ensure that any form of superannuation saving was exempt from the investment tax of 15 per cent. We were concerned that this is an anti-savings tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point is that the whole thing has become far too complicated. When we finally look into the manner of the drafting and the way the Bills have been handled by the Government, whereby the Bill we will deal with next, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1989, is not only supplemental to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 but amends clauses within it, we have a situation where we are dealing with a proposed Act where what we will pass into law will remain law for something like two minutes. When Bill Hayden comes to give assent to the Bills, I hope he signs them in the right order.

The Government initially put the proposition that our amendments to achieve the excising of the 15 per cent investment tax were technically flawed. I flag at this stage that we will be moving a further amendment to clause 18 of the No. 2 Bill to include pooled superannuation trusts (PSTs), and I point out that that part of the amendment that we will move to cover life offices and registered organisations is in fact dealt with not in Bill No. 2 but in the superannuation Bill. I foreshadow that I will be moving amendments to the superannuation Bill as well. I also foreshadow that I will be moving an intent clause. I think it is important to have that on the record so that anybody who can read simple English can understand what the Opposition wishes to achieve. The terms of the intent clause simply say:

It is the intention of the Parliament in passing this Act and the Income Tax Laws Amendment Act (No. 2) 1989 with the inclusion of the amendments moved by the Opposition in committee of the whole that the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 be interpreted so that:
(a) the investment income of complying superannuation funds and complying ADFs, other than income which is special income as defined in Section 273, be exempt from tax; and
(b) the standard component of the taxable income of PSTs be exempt from tax; and
(c) the part of the investment income of life assurance companies and registered organisations that is referable to:
(i) superannuation policies held by complying superannuation funds or complying ADF's; or
(ii) roll-over annuities;
be exempt from tax.''.

That was always our clear intention, which the Government clearly knew and which the Australian Democrats understood. The Democrats chose to support our amendments, which we passed on 1 June, which excised the tax from superannuation funds and approved deposit funds (ADFs). The amendment I will move today to clause 18 will excise the tax from PSTs and the foreshadowed amendments to the superannuation Bill will include life offices and registered organisations. The Democrats have chosen to single out 100,000 people from the 3.5 million or 3.6 million superannuants in this country and say, `You are the only ones who are going to benefit from the excising of this tax'. The amendments which stand to clause 9 and which give that benefit already to superannuation funds and ADFs, and our proposed further amendments, would have had a very simple effect and would have resulted in a simple administration for various insurance companies and managers of various superannuation funds. Now we have an entire mishmash. We have an administrative nightmare and we have seen a cynical exercise by the Democrats to choose 100,000 people whose investments are in approved deposit funds and whose investment will be at least 90 per cent in fixed interest investment, and people who are in roll-over funds as administered by life offices will be disadvantaged.

There seem to be two reasons for the Democrats taking this extraordinary attitude. They seem to say, `Well, there are only 5,000-odd people in the complying roll-over funds and really they don't matter a whole heap'. The fact of the matter is that roll-over funds or deferred annuities differ from approved deposit funds only in that at the end of the period, that is at age 65, they give an option to the superannuant to take out an annuity, to take out a pension-like payment, instead of a lump sum. The ADFs offer the lump sum. I would have thought it was very much in line with Government policy-it is certainly in line with our policy and I would have hoped it was in line with Democrat policy-to encourage people at the end of their period of being in one of these funds, that is when they turn 65, to take the amount that is due to them in the form of an annuity or pension so that there is more self-sufficiency.

But no, the Democrats have said it is all too hard. The Government says, `Oh, I think it will require all sorts of amendments perhaps to the Life Insurance Act and other pieces of legislation. So it is all too hard'. What we have in the end is legislation which is in the category of near enough is good enough. It is a good old Australian adage and it is well and truly followed by this Government. Near enough is good enough: that is the end result of government by press release. A press release was given on 25 May 1988, then the No. 2 Bill and other pieces of legislation were introduced on 30 November 1988, the last sitting day in the House of Representatives last year. Why was that introduced? It was because the Democrats on 8 November 1988 had put in a requirement, which is now an order of the Senate, which says, `Unless the Government gets legislation into the Parliament within six months then the commencement date of it will be the date it is introduced into the Parliament'. The Democrats have one or two riders. They say, `Well, you can circulate a draft Bill and, if that is out in six months, okay, you can have your retrospective date. But if the draft is not out in six months it will be the date of the publishing of the draft. But of course the Senate can change its mind if it likes'. We not only supported it; we attempted to do it ourselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the point?
—The point is that it is the cynicism of the Government. The Government said, `All right, we'll get the No. 2 Bill'.
—Nobody is arguing about that.
—Fine; it is the cynicism of the Government. The Government said, `We will comply with that resolution'.
—It was a good idea.
—Sometimes the Democrats do things for the good-not often but sometimes.
—It worries me, however, when you think that.

—It worries me that I have to conclude that the Democrats have done something well. But, as usual, it was our initiative, one which the Democrats chose not to support when we tried to introduce it. As Senator Messner commented-Senator Haines may care to read the Hansard-we chose to support the Democrats because we thought it was in the interests of good government. The Government in its very cynical way got the No. 2 Bill and some supporting legislation into the House of Representatives on the last day of sitting in 1988. But guess what? It did not deal with all the matters that needed to be dealt with. It dealt only with ADFs, complying superannuation funds and PSTs. It did not deal with life offices and it did not deal with registered organisations, which of course include trade unions, friendly societies and employer organisations. The cynical exercise that the Government embarked upon meant that, instead of wanting to amend-the first Bill that it introduced as it properly ought-the No. 2 Bill, which was known as the No. 6 Bill in November of last year-and instead of seeking to amend provisions in that Bill that it subsequently decided was defective, it chose to use the vehicle of the superannuation Bill to repeal that Bill and to introduce new measures in its place.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give honourable senators an example. Section 275 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Act (No. 2) requires that, in order for the liability for the contributions tax to be passed over to a PST or other body, the actual cash money of the contribution must be paid over to the PST or the other body. Clause 49 of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill repeals that section. In its place it puts another section which says that to transfer the liability for the contributions tax one no longer has to pay over the cash money and that one may use that contribution for something else. The only thing that is required is that there be a sufficient investment in either the PST or another form of trust in order to meet that taxation liability. That sort of exercise is repeated in this Bill and is the nature and complexity of its drafting.

The bottom line is that the Democrats have said that the only reason they are going to bed or doing a deal with the Government on this occasion is that they thought that the coalition would cave in. That is nonsense. Never at any stage has the coalition said that it would in any way recoil from persevering and pressing in the hardest and most effective endeavour to get the whole of the 15 per cent investment tax excised. We have said at every moment that we will not touch any of the rest of the package. We have told the Democrats that what we will propose will only cost somewhere between $20m and $120m. I have asked the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in this chamber on a previous occasion whether he would give us the break-up of the costing of those four component taxes. He declined to do so. In his usual way he fell back on to vitriol and abuse, which is what we have all come to expect from him in this place. Never was an answer given. At no time did the Opposition draw back from the position it firmly stated. David Connolly put his attitude on the record as early as July 1988, soon after the economic statement of 25 May.

The subterfuge and campaign of obfuscation conducted by the Government in this debate ought to make it ashamed. But of course it will not. Never at risk was the basic $1.3 billion which would flow to the Government from the rest of the package. We only ever sought to excise the entire 15 per cent investment tax and we had the support of the Democrats in doing that. But for reasons that they will apparently explain during the rest of the debate they have chosen the Government as their wedded partner. They have chosen to go back on their support for the 3.5 million superannuants and instead single out 100,000 people who will receive a benefit from the amendment that will subsequently be put. With the support of the Democrats, who have done a deal with the Government, it will probably result as the way the law will be carried.

The Minister has also chosen to leave out in the cold another 5,000 people who apparently do not matter because there are only a few of them and drafting of the legislation is a bit hard. We have a package which is near enough, good enough. That is clearly the attitude of the Government and the Democrats but not of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be worth while setting some of the record straight following Senator Bishop's speech. We all know that the Government announced this proposal on 25 May 1988. As far as the Senate and a lot of other people were concerned this legislation by press release was the final straw, particularly when well into the second half of last year nobody had seen any concrete signs of what this proposal was all about. However, there had been enough information leaked about the contents of the legislation for the Australian Democrats to approach the Government with its concerns as early as July of last year. Our concerns were primarily that the 15 per cent earnings tax which was able to be reduced by any fund which involved itself in the share market was not going to be of any benefit to approved deposit funds (ADFs) and other fixed interest funds. The Government brushed aside those concerns, presumably because it ultimately believed that it would have the support of the Opposition. We continued that pressure on the Government hoping it would give us some sort of amendment that would assist people who had opted for safety by rolling over their lump sum following early retirement into things such as ADFs and got nowhere. Earlier this year we again approached the Government. Finally when this legislation was introduced we had no other option but to produce the amendments ourselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Like the Opposition we do not have access to the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel (OPC). Sometimes that is an inhibiting factor; sometimes it is not. Usually we find that the clerks of the Senate can produce amendments that are in every way as good as those drafted by the OPC. In this case the amendments that were produced for us quarantined a number of funds which offered the security of fixed interest benefits to investors. That amendment was not supported either by the Government or the Opposition when it was moved what seems like an aeon ago but was probably only two weeks ago. As a consequence, we did what we had told the Government from the beginning we would do=mthat is, support the Opposition's amendment to remove the 15 per cent earnings tax altogether. We have been telling the Government from day one that that was not our preferred option. There are benefits to the earnings tax. Opposition members carry on about its being a tax on savings, but we do not hear any concerns from them, when they are given the opportunity to amend the tax laws, to remove some of that tax on the savings that people put into bank and building society accounts. The Opposition talks about equal playing fields, but we do not have an equal playing field in any area of the tax Act, including areas such as who can get a tax deduction for buying a home and who cannot. To hear the Opposition talk about level playing fields and equality in tax matters is just a trifle odd, considering its normal behaviour.

In any event, there is no doubt that the earnings tax will produce some benefits. In the 1987 election campaign I urged the Government to introduce some incentives that would act to encourage the big life and superannuation funds in Australia to invest their money onshore instead of offshore, to stop depriving Australian business and the Australian economy of billions of dollars of investment potential. Two years down the track it produced the earnings tax, which will encourage the big life and superannuation funds to invest in Australia because if they invest in Australian companies which pay tax, they will be able to get the benefit of dividend imputation. In doing so they will reduce that 15 per cent earnings tax to zero. The other benefit is what it could well do to Consolidated Revenue by encouraging some of the biggest Australian companies, which currently do not pay tax, to start looking at their tax avoidance measures. There is no reason why major investors, such as the AMP Society or National Mutual Life Association of Australasia Ltd or anybody who buys large parcels of shares, would want to invest in an Australian company that is paying no tax if they want to get the benefit of imputation to reduce their earnings tax from 15 per cent to zero or thereabouts. So there are considerable benefits to accrue to the economy, to Australian companies and to the Australian people as a consequence of the earnings tax. That is why the Democrats regarded as a last resort their support for the amendment moved by Senator Bishop on behalf of the Opposition to remove that particular tax element from the six-Bill package that we have before us. It was not our preferred option. Our preferred option was to protect that group of people who are going to be the only people in this country faced with the penalty of a 15 per cent earnings tax-that is, the people who had invested their money, rolled over their lump sums on early retirement into fixed interest funds which by their very nature are not able to get the benefit of imputation because they do not have any exposure to the share market.

I think it is worthwhile at this point to dispel some of the beliefs that abound in the community about what sorts of schemes superannuation funds have on offer. There seems to be a fair amount of confusion about what is and is not a fixed interest fund and to what extent any fund that is a fixed interest fund is so. If we go out into the community and ask people about capital guaranteed funds or deferred annuities (DAs), the majority of them will tell us that those are fixed interest funds. But they are not necessarily so. Quite a substantial number of capital guaranteed funds have a significant exposure to the share market. They are certainly protected in the event of another October 1987-type crash from too much in the way of shock waves, but only because the funds themselves have set aside a reserve to absorb that problem. I do not think that even the big life and superannuation funds have the right to print money, and if there is a big enough problem, of the sort we saw in October 1987, we could well find that those so-called capital guaranteed funds are not terribly guaranteed at all as far as the capital component is concerned.

DAs are not all fixed interest, and therein lies the major problem with excising those people from the effects of this legislation. Senator Bishop said, `Senator Haines gets up here and says that there are only 5,000 people and they are not worth worrying about'. That is not true. I think they are very much worth worrying about, but the difficulty is, as the funds themselves admit, that there is no way they can be included in this legislation because they are not a legally identifiable separate entity from those DAs which have an exposure to the share or property markets. That is a problem within the funds.

We have spoken to the funds and said to their legal people, `If you can come up with an amendment that will get those fixed interests DAs separated from your share or property exposed DAs, give it to us and we will run with it'. But they cannot. No matter what this chamber would like to do, it cannot legislate for something which is not a legal entity.That is why, in the long run, we have had to come down in support of virtually only ADFs with a 90 per cent fixed interest component, which is what was in our original amendment. DAs were not covered in the original amendment put forward by the Democrats because they could not be, and they still cannot be. That is a matter of regret to me, as it is to Senator Bishop, but it does not alter the fact that the problem lies with the structure within the funds and not with anything this chamber wants to do. It is a matter of capacity.

The figure of 5,000 is one which I believe is reliable. The large funds inform us that there are only about 5,000 people in Australia who have actually invested in interest earning DAs. Whatever the rest of the people out there think about their DAs, they are not interested in earning DAs solely, they have a significant exposure to the share market and in that regard they will get some protection-because of course they will benefit, as other funds will, from any capacity to use imputation to reduce that 15 per cent tax.

When we introduced our original amendment, which excised from the effects of the legislation those funds with a fixed interest component of 90 per cent or more, we were disappointed that we did not get the support of the Opposition. The funds then came to us and said, `We have some problems with your amendment. By isolating the funds, by quarantining them', which is what our amendment did, `you could, inadvertently, cause some behavioural changes within investors'. The big life funds were concerned that if our amendment had gone through, with the best intentions in the world it would have caused people to leave the other funds to go into ADFs. That is a concern I took on board. Certainly it was not my intention to cause a flood of people changing their superannuation behaviour patterns. My concern was simply to prevent a retrospective imposition being put upon those people who, prior to 25 May 1988, had gone into ADFs knowing they were the most secure funds that they could invest in because they were fixed interest and were not subject to speculation.

For that reason, we said to the funds and to the Government, `Come up with an amendment that will excise the members. If you can do that-fine'. It was far too complicated for us. As I said, we do not have access to the Office of Parliamentary Counsel. Indeed, that is what this Government has now done. It has produced an amendment that will allow people aged 55 and over who were already in ADFs on 25 May 1988 and who had retired for any reason at all not to be affected by the 15 per cent earnings tax. It also extends that benefit to people aged 50 and over whose retirement was involuntary. Furthermore, recognising that after 25 May 1988 some people may have changed their behaviour in the industry in such a way as to move out of ADFs and into something else, this amendment also allows people who withdrew as members of ADFs to go into another fund to move back into an ADF. It is to the advantage of the industry because it will not cause a leap out of other funds by people who want to go into ADFs. It has maintained whatever stability can be maintained in what is essentially a fairly unstable industry to the extent that people move around because they look for the best deal that they can get.

I do not think that we will ever get a level playing field or equality in the tax area-certainly not in the superannuation area. After all, only half the people who can take advantage of superannuation do. There are many people, the majority of whom are women, who never really get the advantage of a superannuation system because they are never in a position to be able to go into one. So it is not much use talking about level playing fields. We have to make sure that people are not retrospectively disadvantaged in any way when they have opted for safety. Obviously, the funds have the choice of going into such things as redeemable preference shares, which will, as I understand it, maintain their fixed interest definition but give them some benefits from imputation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The manner in which this package of taxation legislation is being presented to the Senate today gives no credit to the Government because the timing of the amendments, the so-called duplication of issues, further adds to a confusion of a very complex set of amendments and legislation. I will therefore restrict my main comments to changes to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1989 rather than to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 currently before the Senate. We have just heard an apology from the Australian Democrats for the fact that some people will get benefits; others will be denied. It is no fault of the particular person that he or she will be denied a benefit under what Senator Haines has been trying to achieve. Many people have come through what are known as the old section 23f funds. Their money in a life insurance environment has often found its way into a pooled superannuation trust.

SPEECH.PARA: Why should those people be discriminated against compared with people who, basically, have gone into bank-type approved deposit funds (ADFs)? I think it is poor when we legislate in the tax area for a group within a group. We are not talking about a whole class of people such as fishermen; we are virtually saying, `We are selecting groups within a defined category'. If we are to legislate in this manner to give a benefit to a sector within a sector and, at the same time, take away rights from the general body of people, we need to go into this a little more thoroughly and we need to make more extensive amendments to the body of the Bill than has been done.

At present, all we have really seen is a superficial change to let the Australian Democrats off the hook in relation to their original intention. What we are seeing now is a far cry from what was originally espoused by the Democrats. The Government has so narrowed the legislation that the cost to it will be a lot less. This mechanism will enable the Government to get its legislation through with the support of the Australian Democrats. So we have an unholy alliance, a cave-in, on what is tantamount to a most unsatisfactory situation. People who have joined funds in all good faith and who have moved in a particular direction on sound advice at the time will find that they will be discriminated against. There will be a need for different unit prices for continuing fund members.

This legislation is an apology for leaving some people out and for bringing some people in, simply because there are `definitional problems'. I do not think the body of people out there will be satisfied with this ad hoc, mishmash piece of legislation which will cause a great deal of difficulty for fund operators. A number of these people have invested $1m, $2m or perhaps even more millions of dollars in sophisticated computer hardware to comply with the requirements contained in the May economic statement. They are now finding that a lot of that hardware will be redundant and they will have to add to it in a major way. This will cause great confusion for the funds.

At present, no fund in Australia is prepared to tell those people who are retiring where to go because of the confusion in the industry arising from this complex set of laws. We are really adding further to this complexity for fund managers and, as I have mentioned, it is a complexity that the industry can well do without.

This part of the legislation is almost unworkable and is causing people to move out of superannuation funds as an investment option. I think this is unfortunate, particularly at a time when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is talking about introducing tax breaks for savings under the Income Tax Assessment Act. If the Government were concerned about this, it would at the very least agree to the Opposition's amendment to ensure that the investment income of superannuation funds across the board and not of a group within a group will be exempt from tax. That is the only fair way to go. I thought that parliament was about creating an environment of fairness and equity for everybody. This legislation discriminates quite unfairly against certain types of people. If we start doing this, it will be a sad day for the reputation of this chamber and people's respect for this institution. We are the people who are supposed to get it right.

Inevitably, there will be court challenges in respect of the amendments that will be introduced by the Government. Surely in debating the issue we can get it right when we are being told by silks, QCs, or whatever one likes to call them, that this is deficient legislation. In the urge to get something on the legislative books at any cost we are putting on the books something that is inadequate, something that discriminates, something that is deficient.

The Opposition's call for the exemption of investment income regarding the three principal types of funds-superannuation funds, ADFs and pooled superannuation trusts-will not be the great revenue loss that the Government presupposes. I call on Senator Walsh to give us the figures for each of the four components; the tax of 15 per cent paid in respect of the employer's contribution-I submit to Senator Walsh that that must be about $1 billion-the capital gains tax, the 16.25 per cent tax on eligible termination payments and the tax on investment income. The rough figures range from perhaps $20m to $95m. I call on the Government-it is the Government's duty-to produce a financial impact statement. Where is the revenue to be earned? We know that the overall figure it will get out of this proposal will be $1.4 billion. There is a responsibility on the Government to show us what the components of this legislation are so that we know the full financial impact of what we are going to impose on people and on the funds.

We have been told that overall there will be about a 17 per cent loss to the contributors because all the costs that will arise from this legislation will have to be passed on in one way or another. That will be reflected in a lower rate of return to the individual members, whether they be in superannuation funds, ADFs or pooled trusts. The big problem is that one cannot discriminate. The costs of a benefit to one particular category will have to be borne by every member of the fund because one cannot discriminate. Is it not unfair that somebody in a fund pays for a benefit that will move elsewhere? I believe that the first of the foreshadowed changes will be completely unworkable. I reserve my further comments to clause 18.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 9 is the crux of this legislation, which is yet another example of this Government's rapacious demand for revenue. It implements a measure the Government announced with regard to superannuation more than a year ago in its May 1988 economic statement. This clause will both increase the tax take of the Government and bring forward revenue for the Government, at the expense of future retirees, through additional taxes on superannuation. The Government claims that this legislation, in particular this key clause, will improve the efficiency of the dividend imputation system and reduce tax avoidance opportunities. The Government further claims that it will increase the spread of superannuation without an unsustainable Budget cost. It is really a thinly disguised attack on the superannuation entitlements of millions of Australians who are already significantly overtaxed. In other words, Government revenue will remain unacceptably high as a result of this measure.

SPEECH.PARA: One of Australia's basic requirements is the need to perform better. That involves comparing the performance of Australia as a nation with our world competitors which are constantly fine tuning their performances. If we are to become a performance oriented society we need a major shift in attitude. It is individuals who achieve superior performance; governments, industries and unions do not. Instead of taxing an individual's savings-which for a country in our circumstances, are far too low and which, in many circumstances, are non-productive-Australians ought to be encouraged to save more of their incomes for investment in productive activities. Instead, we find, through clause 9 of this legislation, that the Government is reducing the incentive for people to be involved in a very important form of saving, namely, superannuation.

It is claimed by the Government that the 15 per cent tax to be imposed on the income from investments of superannuation funds will be offset against dividend imputation credits on domestic equity investments made by the funds. But that will be only partially the case. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), to the great detriment of their credibility, have both argued that no recipient of superannuation payments will receive lower payouts because of the new tax structure. The Treasurer in particular has stressed this. When this was announced last year I undertook detailed calculations and presented them to the Senate in the debate at that time, which completely shot that claim to pieces. The simple fact is that superannuation funds currently have about 15 per cent of their total investment in equities offering franked dividends. To have sufficient tax credit to completely offset this new 15 per cent tax on their earnings, they would have to lift the level of equities in fully franked dividends to about 60 per cent. That is because dividends in companies give a much lower yield than do other sources of income such as interest or rent. It would be most imprudent for most funds to have such a high percentage of their total investment in such equities. In the first instance, therefore, prudential management of contributors' funds would prevent the tax being fully offset by dividend imputation.

When I did these calculations, the money invested in superannuation funds totalled about $50 billion. About $10 billion of that was in equities, about $7 billion being in franked dividend equities. Given the need, as I said, to raise that percentage of equities in their total equity investment to about 60 per cent, under this clause superannuation funds would have to lift their total investment to nearly $30 billion, an increase of about $23 billion. Again, given that not all Australian equities provide fully franked dividends, in reality that would require an increase of between $25 billion and $30 billion in overall equity investment by the funds.

It must be remembered that this increase in investment has to be achieved in the total Australian commercial and industrial equities market of about $110 billion. It is that commercial and industrial equities market which provides regular dividends, but not even all of those are fully franked dividends. Furthermore, that $110 billion consists of many equities which would definitely not be prudent superannuation investment, leaving aside the imprudence of a 60 per cent investment in equities anyway. There are simply not enough shares available to allow funds to acquire an extra $25 billion to $30 billion in equities, nor would appropriate shares be capable of being issued to meet that demand.

The Government, particularly the Minister for Finance, is guilty of believing in the fallacy of composition. It may be possible for one or two funds to meet that requirement of fully franked dividend equities to completely offset the 15 per cent tax, but the fact that one or two funds are capable of achieving that does not mean that all funds are capable of achieving it, in particular because, as I said, there are insufficient equities to go around. If funds tried to achieve that 60 per cent investment in equities there would be an increase in share prices, because of an increased demand for equities, and that would be an unsustainable rise in terms of dividend returns. We would find that, as a result of the price of the shares going up, the yield on those equities would decrease, thereby decreasing the tax credits and, of course, pushing those funds further away from the goal of having sufficient tax credits to offset the tax. It is not possible, despite the Government's claims, for funds to invest in sufficient equities completely to offset the new 15 per cent tax by dividend imputation. That is the flaw in this clause in terms of the Government's claims.

There are also concerns in regard to this clause in regard to its legal principles. It may well be that this legislation will be thrown out by the courts, because it contravenes certain basic legal principles to which I shall draw attention. Beneficiaries under a superannuation deed may obtain accrued rights. Those accrued rights are legally enforceable and it would take a very clear expression of legislative intent to alter those rights. That clear expression is not present in this legislation. Some trust deeds may provide the power to make retrospective variations to trust deeds, in which case any such accrued rights are subject to that overriding right of the trustees, but that would not be evident in all cases. In the absence of such power in the trust deed accrued rights could not be validly altered by the trustee. A direction by legislation to a trustee to alter accrued rights would not by itself be sufficient to alter those rights. The retrospective alteration of accrued rights can usually be justified only by the trustee acting bona fide. It is certainly not clear that a trustee directed by legislation retrospectively to alter accrued rights would be acting bona fide. It would depend on a number of circumstances which are difficult to predict, given the uncertainty of the detail of the legislation. So, the legislation falls short not only of the Government's claims with regard to the capacity of superannuation funds to avoid the 15 per cent tax through dividend imputation, but also of basic compliance with legal principles.

The Treasurer tries to argue that this legislation will act as a catalyst to promote investment in Australian rather than overseas securities, but even allowing for that fact it will still not be possible for funds to achieve sufficient investment in Australian equities to offset the 15 per cent tax. The Government's claim that end beneficiaries will not be 1c worse off as a result of this legislation is clearly false. The hypocrisy of the Australian Democrats in supporting this Government amendment is writ large for all to see. We have seen Senator Haines running around the electorate of Kingston, which she will seek to represent after the next election-I think that is a false hope on her part; the most recent poll in Kingston shows her support running at about 13 per cent-castigating the Government, and quite properly so, for its high interest rate regime and its effect on home buyers in Kingston.

The argument about high interest rates is the effect they have on people's pockets. They affect the amount of money left in people's pockets after they have paid tax and interest rates which are in effect fixed charges which they cannot avoid. This, of course, governs the amount of money left in their pockets for other cost of living expenses. But this legislation will rip more money out of the pockets of individuals. If people are to retain the end benefit to which they are entitled from their superannuation when they retire, they will be required to increase their contribution to superannuation funds to maintain that same end benefit which they expected when they entered superannuation. That will have exactly the same effect as increasing interest rates are having-ripping more money out of people's pockets, money which they cannot at this time afford. For Senator Haines to support the Government's legislation at a time when she is running around criticising the Government because of the amount of money it is ripping out of people's pockets because of increasing interest rates is sheer hypocrisy and certainly will be noted by the Kingston electors.

This clause should be opposed. The decision of the Opposition to excise the 15 per cent tax on income earned by superannuation funds is the correct way to go. I urge the Committee to support the Opposition's amendments to ensure that those who have entered superannuation funds in good faith to establish a level of benefit required for an adequate income in their retirement without being dependent on government are not penalised.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a frightening aspect.

Public servants make a decision to take a lesser amount of money in the work force to get security. They wish for security, take a lesser sum of money and at the end of their 40 or 45 years--

—That is an unbecoming comment and, quite frankly, any time you are stuck for an answer you go for the bucket. That is your last means of defence. You are very good at it. But it does not really help Commonwealth and State public servants. SPEECH.PARA: There has for a long time-possibly forever, I am not sure-been a reasonable benefit limits policy applied to private sector funds. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the proposal that has been put forward by the Opposition in regard to pooled superannuation trusts (PSTs).
