TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Harradine and Senator Watson for their interventions and stress the point I made in my opening remarks-that the Government deliberately chose to present two Bills to cover the field of superannuation. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, which we are presently debating, was introduced last November as the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1988 in an attempt to comply with the order of the Senate requiring legislation to be introduced within six months. The reason that one part of the superannuation industry is covered in a separate Bill is that the Government deliberately chose to do it that way. Accordingly, I have moved an amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 in relation to pooled superannuation trusts because they are first mentioned in that Bill. But, because I am well acquainted now with the modus operandi of the Minister for red herrings, otherwise known as the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, I will move that clause 64a be inserted in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1989 so that even the most humble member of this Parliament-and, indeed, interested observers-will be able to understand the intent of the Opposition and, should the amendment be passed, the intent of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has chosen to amend its amendment to this legislation. This morning Senator Walsh claimed that the amendment to the amendment was but an addition, yet this so-called addition effectively alters the intent of the original amendment circulated yesterday. Surprise, surprise!-there is not a single copy in this chamber of the original explanatory memorandum which accompanied the original amendment. But guess what? I just happen to have a copy, left over from the limited supply that was available yesterday, which clearly shows-and we will be dealing with this show in the next Bill-that the intent of the Government's original amendment was not to put a compulsory requirement on trustees to distribute the benefits to eligible depositors but to leave that to the discretion of the fund managers.

Guess what the so-called addition, which in my view is clearly an amendment, does this morning? It puts such a compulsion on the trustee managers. One can quibble if one likes about terminology in this chamber. One can say that I wish to be pernickety and I should not be pernickety. But the bottom line is this: the Minister has chosen to introduce legislation into this place on the basis that near enough is good enough. So far as the Opposition is concerned, that simply will not do. It will not do that only 100,000 folk out of 3.5 million superannuants are being singled out for single advantage. The Government is saying to the 5,000 people in deferred annuities, `Too bad about you, it is all too hard and anyway there are only 5,000 of you'. What sort of legislation are we entertaining in this place? What sort of principle do we adhere to?

It is important if we are to have equity, if we are to have a superannuation scheme which encourages savings and which encourages people to be more self-reliant, that we have one set of rules for everybody. That is what our amendments do and that is not what the Government's amendments do and that is certainly not what the Democrats are achieving by doing a deal with the Government on this issue. The Democrats stand condemned. Indeed, the 3.5 million superannuants who will not get a benefit by the amendments and will not be given a fair go because the Democrats and the Government have got together will remember and will have a long memory when it comes to the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was wondering whether we should move to report progress because the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who is in charge of the Bill, is not here to answer the questions and to respond to the issues which have been raised. Senator Tate, do you intend to respond? If you do it might be necessary for you--
—I am not going to take directions from you.
—Order! Senator Watson, please address your remarks through the Chair.

—We have a fairly unsatisfactory situation. I understood that Senator Walsh was in charge of this set of very complex Bills. They are difficult. They will need fairly detailed responses from an informed person. While I have the utmost respect for Senator Tate, the details that are involved in these Bills are issues that require some study and background. Senator Walsh has that background. I ask whether the Government intends to have Senator Walsh here for the carriage of these Bills, or whether we are to have a plethora of Ministers who will not be able to respond to the vital issues that are being raised in relation to a taxation system which is affecting millions of people around Australia. I do not think it is good enough. May we have the Minister's response?

—This is actually a very simple matter to deal with. Human beings are embodied spirits. The fact is that Senator Walsh has been in here for some time. He asked me whether I would relieve him while he takes a comfort break, as the Americans would say. Had I been required to respond to Senator Bishop I would have. But I think judging from the reaction in the gallery, it was recognised as rhetoric rather than something that required a detailed and arithmetical type response so I did not rise to my feet. I can assure Senator Watson that Senator Walsh will return to the chamber shortly and will be able to engage in the refutation of any matter put which is cloaked in the language of substance. I am sure that he will be able to undertake that.

—I would like to support my colleague Senator Watson's comments about the importance of having the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) here. I understand Senator Tate's point about the reasons for Senator Walsh's absence. But I take some exception to the statement by Senator Tate that Senator Bishop's very important and detailed summation was a matter of rhetoric. I ask Senator Tate whether that, therefore, means that the Government does not believe that the singling out of 100,000 superannuants at the cost, if you like, to 3.6 million others amounts to discrimination. Is that what Senator Tate is suggesting? That was the very point that Senator Bishop was making-a point which Senator Tate seems to regard as rhetoric. I would like a specific answer to that question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Walsh for returning to the chamber and I also thank him for his response to the question on reasonable benefits which was raised by Senator Boswell and me. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) felt that it did not have a great deal of relevance to the package of Bills before us. I wish to remind him that last night we were told that the many and varied ways of taxing superannuation-for example, eligible termination payments, which we will have a look at later on-amounted to 32 in number.
—I can do better.

—Senator Haines said, `I can do better'. There are now 64 methods of taxing eligible termination payments. There are a lot of indirect effects that feed into this particular legislation. One concerns reasonable benefits. To give a linkage to this I wish to come back to the problems that the lack of direction that has come from the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC) has caused superannuation funds. This lack of direction has led to the problem that superannuation funds must ask the contributors. If they do not ask the right questions they will be taxed at a penal rate or at a rate different from that which might otherwise apply. Therefore there is a responsibility on the ISC to come out very quickly with its standards, and not only on reasonable benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now return to this issue of reasonable benefits which is causing so much difficulty and, in some cases, some hardship. May I have an assurance from the Minister that he will contact the ISC to direct it to hurry up and to provide, at the earliest opportunity, a set of standards or guidelines to apply not only to reasonable benefits but also to the wider issues of standards that will be required under this legislation and that should have been ready now? I also make the further request that the Minister not only make this request of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission but also make the request of the Commissioner of Taxation because he also has to issue standards and guidelines under this legislation. He has had over six months in which to present them. He has failed to present them.

This situation is adding to the confusion and the difficulty. Let me, therefore, request that the Minister contact both these officers of government. They are under his direction and control. I know he will say that they are commissioners and, therefore, they should be at arm's length. But if that is the point it is about time we started bringing some of these people back if they are being dilatory and not getting on with the job that they are set up to do. I am not referring necessarily to the Commissioner of Taxation but to the ISC. We warned the Minister when he set up the Insurance and Superannuation Commission that there were going to be problems. He is dragging the chain. Who is paying the cost? It is the millions of people out there who are superannuants or who come under that wider category of friendly society members-the whole gamut.

I would like to explain to the Minister the seriousness of the problem. This scale of benefits was formerly contained in various taxation rulings and was revised by the ISC in circular No. 7 issued the day after the April economic statement, which I referred to earlier. A number of problems were identified with the original statement. A revised statement was subsequently issued. That statement itself contained a number of difficulties and anomalies. The ISC has advised that it is undertaking a further revision of the whole area of the scale of benefits. That further revision has been under way since July 1988. There has been no official release of the results. That is not good enough. That is why I am asking the Minister to direct these people to act and to act quickly.

In the meantime, the trustees have been asked to administer the reasonable benefits standards in accordance with a reasonable benefits scales in which the ISC has admitted it has definite problems. The proposed scale provides that only specified portions of benefits paid from untaxed and unfunded arrangements are taken into account. It also provides a different treatment for golden handshakes, depending on the relationship between the employee and the employer and the section under which the deduction of the payment was claimed. These rules increase greatly the number of questions that fund administrators ask of the current or prospective members, particularly when it is borne in mind that many members have difficulty providing the correct answer. For example, neither the Australian Taxation Office nor the taxpayer, the employer, will be able to ask the member the section of the Act under which the golden handshake paid to the associated employee has been claimed or allowed. That will give the Minister and his advisers some idea of the difficulty that they place people in at present, not only current members but also prospective members.

Fund managers are having trouble advising their clients or prospective clients what to do. The people in the community should contact their local Labor member of Parliament, if they have one, or ring up and find out who he is to put pressure on him. Only by the action of people in contacting their local members will these issues be raised and corrected. It appears that what is said in this place is not adequately responded to. With this lack of response I call on members of the public who have been affected to contact their local members of parliament and raise these issues. If they want action on housing interest rates they should contact them on that as well and then we might get some action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -I would like to give the Committee an example of how dilatory the Government is in answering direct questions about superannuation.
—And other questions too.

—I acknowledge that. I must say that it varies from Minister to Minister and from department to department. Some departments and Ministers are very courteous and prompt in their replies. Such is not the case in respect of queries relating to superannuation. I have a case in point from an individual constituent who, on 5 February 1988, wrote to me about the problems of superannuation and the rules that have been changed of which he was not aware. The circumstances of his case are disconcerting indeed. This constituent wrote to me on 5 February. I wrote to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 8 February 1988. Ultimately, I received a reply from the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris) on 11 August 1988, some six months later. That letter misinterpreted the matter that was raised by the constituent. It said that the constituent had stated that the Government had amended the law to prevent lump sum superannuation retirement payments from being rolled over into deferred annuities. That is not what the constituent said at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to go into this too much but I raise it so that a reply may come forward. I sent that response to the constituent who replied in detail to me, indicating that what the Minister had stated in his 11 August letter was not correct. He asked for certain detailed information about his superannuation entitlements which he, as a constituent, was entitled to receive. He has spent many years in public service for the people of Tasmania. On 31 October I wrote to the Minister Assisting the Treasurer asking him to respond in detail to the quite specific questions that were raised by the constituent in respect of superannuation. There has been no substantial response to that letter to the Minister Assisting the Treasurer which I wrote on 31 October 1988. It is now June, mid-1989. There has been a series of acknowledgments to my repeated requests for an answer. But that is just not good enough. I feel like it but I am not going to delay the Committee on this matter. I think it is important. I ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) whether the Department could answer the letters that I have written on behalf of that constituent who asked questions about superannuation which that constituent is entitled to do.

I raise this matter because Senator Watson said that members of the public should write to their members of parliament. I certainly hope that they do that. In so doing we want some guarantees from the Government that it will treat these requests for information promptly and provide that information. This is not a secret society. Some of these questions are very difficult. I find that it is now virtually impossible to get an amendment which will place into this legislation an objective which would probably be desired by most members of this chamber. I repeat that that is in relation to enabling superannuants to offset losses incurred where funds are running at a loss and which are open to the vagaries of the share market and against that particular fund which may be making a profit and from which that superannuant is receiving some income which will be taxed. I think everybody in this chamber would see the justice of that, particularly concerning workers. The case I mentioned is that of a worker in a major industry in Tasmania. He was a representative of the union. He was closely associated with getting people to advise on superannuation. He received certain advice and the proposed legislation was so complex that he had to take the advice he was given. He did so and now he finds that three or four of the investments are losing while one is not. He will have to pay taxation on the full sum that he is receiving from the one that is not making a loss while not being able to offset the losses from the ones that are making a loss. I appeal to the Government, to the Minister and to my colleagues in this chamber to ensure that prompt answers are given by the Government to reasonable questions which are addressed to it through elected representatives in the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I note that honourable senators are addressing themselves generally to clause 9, but I remind the Committee that the question before us is the amendment moved by Senator Bishop.

—Senator Watson asked me to direct the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. It is a fact that I certainly cannot direct the ISC because I am not the Treasurer. I am not sure whether the Treasurer can direct it. I will pass the matter on to him.

—I was hoping to receive an indication from the Minister in respect of requests that are made to the Government by superannuants on issues of superannuation. Can we get a guarantee that a prompt reply will be provided to superannuants who make such requests either directly to the Government or, alternatively, through their senator or member?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give a guarantee, for the same sorts of reasons I gave previously, but I will take the matter up with the Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Bishop's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to proposed new section 276 on page 14 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), headed `Contribution notices given after return lodgment date', which states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: notice under subsection 82aat (1a) in relation to a contribution made to a fund . . .

The Minister will note that `the clawback amount is allowable as a deduction from the assessable income of the fund of the notice year'. How can that be complied with when the notices have not been given because the regulations have not been drawn? Are people going to be disadvantaged as a result of the late passage of this Bill because there will not be adequate time in which those notices can be complied with according to proposed new section 276?

TALK.START.PARA: —The point of Senator Watson's question, if I understood it correctly, is that there is not much of this financial year left-which is, of course, a fact-and therefore there will not be time for a fund to receive many notices from contributors. Is that it?

—Yes, but the provision provides: `the clawback amount is allowable as a deduction from the assessable income of the fund of the notice year'. I am concerned that people may be denied an allowable deduction from the assessable income under proposed new clause 276, simply because time has run out and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (ISC) has not done his job. How can the notice under subsection 82aat (1a) and similar provisions be given? I do not want to have to ask this question in relation to all similar notices, but I put the Government on notice, using this as a test case, to save my asking the question again: Are people and funds going to be denied the sorts of deductions that are allowable under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 simply because the notices have not been given because the ISC and the Commissioner of Taxation have been remiss in not putting forward their regulations and in not putting out the notices to enable people to get the deductions to which they are legitimately entitled, provided that they put in their notices in this year? By the time this Bill gets royal assent there will be precious little time left. What administrative arrangements are there? Does it require an amendment to the Act? If it does, I will call on the Government to prepare another amendment to enable the deductions that people are rightfully entitled to under this Bill to be claimed, because the effluxion of time might deny them that opportunity.
—What Senator Watson outlines is, I believe, possible in the short term, but there is provision for an amended assessment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —So the Minister is saying that because of the deficiencies of the Government in bringing forward this legislation at such a late stage, because of the deficiencies of the Commissioner of Taxation in failing to provide the guidelines, the notices et cetera in another area, and because of the inadequacies of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, which the Government set up for the sole purpose of helping people to obtain their entitlements, provided that they do the right thing. These people are wanting to proceed, and the advice that we are being given is that the onus is on them to request an amended assessment.
—Are you talking about individuals or funds?

—We are talking about both. I said in my preface that I am using this as a test case. If the Minister wishes, I will ask the same question on every clause of the Bills which are now before us, to determine an answer. I use it as a test case that will apply to all notices and regulations required by the Tax Commissioner and the ISC to enable people and funds to fulfil their commitments to meet the requirements of the legislation and, above all, to ensure that people and funds can get their rightful entitlement, as outlined.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may say that this is a short term problem; that the major problem relates to this year. But that is because he has made the legislation retrospective to 1 July. Sure, it will not be a problem in perhaps two years time if it is going to take two years to get out the regulations. But I assure the Minister that it is an immediate problem, a pertinent issue, at the present time, because we are running out of time. We must have a better mechanism or we will have to ask these bodies to send a notice of entitlement to every person concerned, under proposed new section 276. Unless they are told of this, they will overlook it and will be denied a deduction to which they will be entitled. How are we going to overcome it?-just by a request for an amended assessment, putting the onus back on the individual or the fund to have that amended assessment. What is the mechanism?

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that it has no relevance to individuals. It is a complex issue and I am waiting for a written note from the officers present. Senator Watson appears to believe that this is relevant to individuals, and my advice is that that is not so, and I will give him the reasons in a minute.

—Ultimately it spills over to individuals, does it not? Who are the beneficiaries of these funds? If the Minister had listened carefully, he would have heard me say `funds and individuals', and I hope I said it in that order, because the ultimate recipients are individuals. They are the people for whom I am concerned. I am concerned about the complexities that are faced by these funds, such as the additional software that they will have to put into their computer programs to be able to feed this out. I think we have to address the immediate problem. When is the Minister going to give us this advice? I think it has to be part and parcel of this package of legislation. I think we need it today, before this legislation is passed by this chamber, because it is pertinent to the passage of this legislation. Can the tax officers and the ISC give us information on how people are going to proceed, given the complexity of the issues that have been raised by proposed new section 276-using this as an ambit claim in relation to all notices?
—I will give you an answer in a couple of minutes.
—In fairness to Senator Watson, we ought to have an answer to his question. The Minister has asked us to wait two minutes. I do not know whether that is a guess.
—We could report progress, Senator.
—I was going to suggest that we report progress.
—I believe that Senator Watson's question does not refer to clause 9. He cited page 14, which covers clause 13.
—Clause 9 covers the taxing of all the different sorts of funds, whether they be superannuation funds, approved deposit funds or pooled superannuation trusts.
—Clause 9, which is the clause we are dealing with, is covered from page 7 onwards.

—I have the answer in writing. A notice under section 82aat disentitles an individual to a tax deduction and excludes an amount from assessable income of the fund. If the notice is given in the current year, the amount will not be included in the income of the fund. If the notice is given in a later year, the fund will get the deduction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The words are `in the year of income'.
—What line are you quoting?
—Clause 276 on page 14 states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the clawback amount is allowable as a deduction from the assessable income of the fund of the notice year.

I am saying that people are being denied a deduction under the clawback provision simply because the notice goes in next year rather than this year. I am concerned about the operation of the clawback provisions in relation to the current year. As I see it, there is no way that that notice can come in within the current year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the fund gets the deduction in the year in which it receives the notice.

—That is right. But is there not a problem in the current year as the notices cannot be received because of the time problem? We are only a few days away from 30 June and the notice has not been prescribed by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. Until the regulations prescribing this are put down, how can the notice be received in the current year?

—We seem to be back where we started. It would appear that it is possible that what Senator Watson has said could happen to a fund in the short term, but the fund can supply additional information and get an amended assessment-fairly promptly I would have thought.

—We have this problem of complying and non-complying funds. In the case of a complying fund paying a death benefit to a dependant of a deceased, is it not a fact that the dependant will have incurred a detriment compared with the previous provisions-that is, those provisions relating to the pre-1 July 1983 superannuation positions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that there is an anti-detriment provision for people seeking death benefits in clause 279d of the next Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to seek leave to move a motion that we recommit the Opposition amendments to clause 9 that were passed by the Senate nearly a fortnight ago. I was going to move to do this when we reported but I overlooked the fact that we are in committee jointly for all the Bills.
—Can you give us an indication of what you intend to do before you move it?

—I want to recommit the Opposition amendments to clause 9 passed by the Senate nearly a fortnight ago. The reason for that is that, as we all know, those amendments will be rejected in the House of Representatives. The Bill will then have to come back to the Senate. It is just for procedural convenience. It is now clear that the Senate will not insist on those amendments. For procedural convenience I intend to move that we recommit those questions now.
—Is leave granted?
—Leave is not granted.
—In that case, I will move the same motion when the Committee reports.

SPEECH.PARA: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (SUPERANNUATION) BILL 1989
Clauses 1 to 13-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill talks about the taxed and the untaxed elements of the post-June 1983 component. I refer to the promise of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that not one person will be worse off. When that promise was first made, did it relate only to the carry-forward benefit of people who were already in the scheme? I understand there is a provision that enables a person who is worse off to claim it back through the taxation mechanism. What is the mechanism? Should that mechanism to enable a person who is worse off as a result of that commitment by the Treasurer not be in this Bill? Where is that facility in the legislation before us to enable a person who is worse off somehow to claim back, we understand, through the Income Tax Assessment Act? As I see it, there is no provision or mechanism to enable a person who is worse off to be able to claim that. How does a person achieve that situation? It is quite unfair. The onus should be on the Government but the Government puts the onus on the person who is worse off as a result of these changes-it has to be as a result of his or her direct action. What is the procedure, the mechanism? To date the Government has not presented a mechanism. I understand that more Bills are to come down. The Government has given the undertaking. The provision is there, but how will it be achieved?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two things. First, I think Senator Watson is talking about the contribution being taxed. Clause 27ca of the Bill provides an anti-detriment provision. The explanation is on page 32 of the explanatory memorandum. Secondly, Senator Watson referred to the Treasurer's promise that no individual would be worse off. I think those were Senator Watson's words. I am not aware of such a promise. I believe that there were newspaper reports to that effect.
—What?
—I will quote page 14 of the May statement of 1988. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has therefore decided to bring superannuation funds within the full ambit of the imputation system, giving them access to dividend tax credits.
To achieve this a tax of 15 per cent will apply to fund earnings. But this 15 per cent tax can be neutralised or offset by the receipt of dividend tax credits.
For most superannuation funds, this will mean in practice no tax at all on investment earnings.
For others, the rate will be minimal, and can readily be adjusted to zero by including more Australian company shares in their investment portfolios.
This will ensure no detriment to any lump sum or pension end-benefit.

Of course that line is conditional upon the line that precedes it. There have been press reports that are somewhat different from that but I am not aware of the Treasurer having made a promise, as it has been described by some newspapers and by other people. The position is put with complete accuracy by the quotation I have just read out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for clarifying that issue because that commitment is certainly in the minds of everybody around Australia. I am surprised that the Treasurer has not responded and denied those newspaper reports. I venture to say that the Treasurer, and possibly his advisers, must be the only people in Australia who today are unaware of the commitment that not one person would be 1c worse off. I am getting the reports, and the superannuation industry is certainly aware of it. The advisers seem to have been asking this question and the nods have obviously been coming from the Government. I asked whether the wool had been pulled over our eyes because it appeared to me that this statement was false. I was going to present all those cases that indicated where people were going to be worse off but I am told that there is a provision which will enable people to claim back this money through the taxation system. I have scanned the legislation and I cannot find this provision so I defer to the Minister. I think he is 100 per cent right--
—Are you talking about the contributions tax?

—We are talking about the Treasurer's commitment that nobody would be one cent worse off. I said I thought that that must have related to a very narrow area in the provisions that we are looking at. Let us take, for instance, the `brought forward' component. The Minister has now raised a completely new issue.
—The `brought forward' component?

—Was that the only element the Treasurer was referring to when he said that nobody would be worse off? The Minister for Finance has said that that whole statement does not apply. I am saying that it does not have any relevance.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go back to the special deduction provision to prevent detrimental eligible termination payments as this is what we are looking at. Are the Minister's advisers with me?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator cannot ask questions of the advisers.

—I think everybody would be aware of the Treasurer's much publicised boast that nobody would be one red cent-that was the word and that fits with his colourful language when he is describing things-worse off under the new arrangements for taxing superannuation funds. Unbeknown at the time, he was referring only to the bring forward tax on contributions. If there were no tax on the income of superannuation funds the Treasurer would have been right most of the time and we would not have needed special provisions. Obviously he has brought in these special provisions in order to honour that commitment. I see that the Minister's advisers are nodding in agreement. These provisions are terribly complicated. We have a horrendous number of special provisions to ensure that the Treasurer honours his undertaking.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is now saying that the Treasurer never made that commitment. Why do we have all these complicated provisions if he did not say that? I am terribly confused at present. Most of the time he would have been right: we would not have needed special provisions; but because of the exceptions, special provisions were needed and they have actually be built into the legislation. I think we need further clarification from the Minister and I am prepared to wait for five minutes while he consults with his advisers.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the contributions tax, or the bring forward tax as Senator Watson calls it, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) gave a commitment that no individual would be worse off. That commitment is taken up by the anti-detriment clause to which I referred earlier. However, the wider claim that has been made about the entire package is that no individual would be worse off. As I have said, I am not aware of the Treasurer having made such a promise. I do not need to quote again from the May statement as it is clear in that statement that the 15 per cent tax is a tax on fund earnings. The Treasurer's statement applies to the 15 per cent tax on fund earnings. Even though it has been asserted here ad nauseam, I am not aware of the Treasurer having made any promises that, because of the tax provision on fund earnings, no individual would be worse off. But he did point out in the May statement that no individual would be worse off, providing the funds adjusted their investment portfolio-a point which I have made several times in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The latest statement of the Minister for Finance has now clarified the position. It confirms what I said earlier that the Treasurer's promise that nobody would be one red cent worse off applies only in a narrow and restricted sense. Does the Minister recall my saying that? That undertaking covers only that area which I was addressing and it applies only in a narrow and restricted sense. I was referring to the bring forward tax on contributions. I hope that the Minister now acknowledges that that is what I said. I never said that this tax would apply right across the board. The Minister should not try to bring me into line with that because my comments were very specific.

SPEECH.PARA: I was asking the Minister to confirm that that promise and undertaking did not apply across the board as the newspapers said. It applied only in a narrow and restricted sense. I think the Treasurer was relying on a general feeling in the community-which was quite wrong-that everybody would be worse off. Why did he not have the courage and the guts to come forward and say, `Yes, in the majority of cases, people will be worse off. But in this narrow and restricted sense they will not be worse off and we have made special provisions. By cripes, it is complicated but we have achieved that. It took a lot of legislative amendments to bring it about'. Is that correct?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is correct that the anti-detriment provisions is there to ensure that no individual will be worse off as a result of the contributions tax. To the best of my knowledge, nobody has found any fault with that.

—Was not the Treasurer referring only to the bring forward tax on contributions of nearly $1 billion which is now lying in superannuation funds? Was it not only in that area and in no other area? I cannot see the difficulty and I do not know why the Minister cannot respond to that question.

—The Treasurer gave an explicit commitment-a promise, if you like-on the contributions tax. I have said that I am not aware-I cannot say for certain that he did not because I do not have tape recordings of everything that he says-of the Treasurer ever saying that no individual would be worse off as a result of the 15 per cent tax. There has been some confusion here. Perhaps Senator Watson referred only to the contributions tax, which is being dealt with, or the effects of that tax on individuals. Many people in the Opposition have asserted that the Treasurer gave exactly the same promise: no individual could or would be worse off under the 15 per cent tax. I have said that I am not aware of the Treasurer making such a statement. I read out the relevant part of the text of the May statement to the honourable senator and I do not think there is anything more to be said about it.

—I am not referring to the contributions tax when I am alleging what the Treasurer promised. I am referring to a specific component of the contributions tax; not the contributions tax, per se, across the board. I am asking the Minister for Finance to be honest with the people of Australia and to be specific in relation to the Treasurer's promise-which he has not denied-which a lot of people have inferred is a lot wider and relates to superannuation issues generally. I take issue with the Minister when he says that that does not apply just to the contributions tax. It applies only to a specific part of that contributions tax. Will the Minister confirm or deny that?

—What is the honourable senator asking me to confirm or deny? As far as the contributions tax in general is concerned people will be better off. In one case it is 15 per cent of 85 per cent; in other words, the pre-tax lump sum is 85 per cent of what it would have been had the 15 per cent contributions tax not been levied at the point of entry. Once all the amendments are passed we will have only a 15 per cent tax and that tax is levied on 85 per cent of the lump sum instead of 100 per cent if the change had not been made.

—Perhaps the Minister for Finance should be given an opportunity to consult with his advisers to correct and narrow his comments. If he persists with that line we might have to give a whole lot of examples which will indicate that that statement is not right. Given the time problem, we would prefer not to go down that track.

—While we are waiting for Senator Walsh to confer with his advisers, I might put two other things on the record. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), if my recollection serves me correctly, got into the act, too. He described this wonderful piece of invention as the magic pudding. Perhaps it ought to be called the poison pudding. What he is asserting, as Senator Watson has so adequately pointed out, is wrong. Irrespective of the fact that the Treasurer estimated that the measure would allow the Government to bring forward nearly $1 billion of its own tax money now lying in superannuation funds without diminishing any personal end benefit by 1c-as we all know in politics perceptions become the essence of what is promised-the perception was, and it has never been successfully denied by the Government, that no superannuant, those ordinary Australians out there who are supposed to be planning for their future, would be worse off; the Treasurer was somehow giving them an assurance that they would not be worse off. It was misleading and a subterfuge to allow that perception to remain. As I said, it is not a magic pudding; it is a poison pudding. We are supposed to think that the Government's assurances are supposed to make it all right. The fact that the anti-detriment clause confers on the Commissioner of Taxation yet another discretion somehow is supposed to make people feel safe, comforted and assured that their investment will not be lessened.

—Senator Watson has asked me to clarify the matter, and I can. What I said is completely correct. The contributions tax, for superannuants in general, will be a benefit-a minor benefit, admittedly-for the reasons that I explained. I explained the arithmetic behind it. The anti-detriment provision applies to those who would, in the absence of the anti-detriment provisions, have been worse off had their been no change, that is, had the tax been levied on the end benefit instead of partially on the end benefit and partially on the contribution, as is provided for under this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -Mr Chairman, I seek clarification. I refer to a letter dated 11 August 1988 to me on the letterhead of the Treasurer and signed by Peter Morris, the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, in respect of the superannuation taxation question. The Minister stated to me as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Changes to the tax treatment of superannuation were announced in the May Economic Statement but the reforms announced will generally not result in any reduction in after tax benefits for superannuation fund members.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson asked about the mechanism for the anti-detriment provision. It is set out on page 33 of the explanatory memorandum. In brief, it is the responsibility of the individual to apply to the Commissioner of Taxation in his or her tax return for the compensation the section will provide.
—What did you say?
—The individual needs to apply for it; that is the mechanism. The compensation can be by way of a tax rebate or a credit.

—As the Minister has attempted to portray the anti-detriment clause as something which is simple and easy to exercise, I think it is useful to have on the record industry's attitude to how it may operate. The understanding of industry is that the anti-detriment clause is unworkable; it would require the reviewing of the entire tax profile of individual superannuants over 30 to 40 years. With approximately 150,000 retirees with superannuation leaving the work force each year, the application of this clause would cause chaos in the tax system.

—I think we will find that many people will not be able to answer these questions. Five or 10 years ago, superannuation funds involved fairly simple sorts of documents. With changes in the ownership of companies, the transfer of funds, et cetera, many of the original questions will be difficult. Individuals put a lot of faith in the trustees. I think we will find that the funds will be taxed at a higher rate than possibly is intended under this legislation simply because we will require a sophistication not required in previous years. The funds and the individual members of those funds will be worse off simply because they will not be in a position to answer the detailed questions required. These sorts of questions were not required to be answered perhaps five, 10 or 15 years ago-or even earlier-when these people entered the funds. They will be worse off if they are taxed at a higher rate. Does the Minister recognise that there is a problem?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister seems unlikely to respond to Senator Watson's point, I ask him to respond to Senator Harradine's point. He has drawn the narrow interpretation of the undertaking of the Treasurer, the strict legalistic interpretation. Yet, as I said, the question really is one of perceptions. It was obviously in the Treasurer's interest to allow people's fears to be assuaged, to be comforted that their hard earned investment was not at risk, that it was not going to be eroded. The letter that was sent to Senator Harradine backs up that point. It talks about tax treatment. It says that generally nobody will be worse off. Is Senator Walsh saying that he is part of the Government's perfidy, or is he saying that he holds himself above that sort of thing and it is really only the Treasurer who is perfidious?

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 14 to 23-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 20, clause 14, after proposed section 100c, insert the following new section:

``110d. Of each amount derived by a life assurance company that would, apart from this section, section 110b and section 110c, be included in assessable income of the company of the year of income, the amount of the CS/RA class of assessable income which consists of the assessable income to which paragraphs 116ce (4) (a) and (b) refer is exempt from tax.
(2) Page 22, paragraph 18 (b), proposed paragraph 112a (1a) (a), line 28, leave out the proposed paragraph.
(3) Page 26, clause 20, proposed subsection 116ce (4), line 30, before the ``The CS/RA class'', insert ``Subject to section 110d,''.
(4) Page 28, paragraph 21 (d), proposed definition of `CS/RA assessable income', lines 36 to 40, leave out the proposed definition, insert the following definition:

`` `CS/RA assessable income', in relation to a registered organisation in relation to a year of income, means amounts which are to be included in assessable income of the organisation under section 275 and specified roll over amounts paid to the registered organisation in the year of income;''.
(5) Page 35, clause 23, proposed paragraph 116gd (3) (a), lines 33 and 34, leave out the proposed paragraph.

These amendments deal with that part of the superannuation industry which is not covered in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 with which we have already dealt. They deal specifically with life officers and registered organisations. This morning we have already been through the reasons why the Government has chosen to deal with legislation in this manner, dealing with part of the industry in one Bill and another part of the industry in another. I have moved these amendments in order that all classes of superannuation funds will have the benefit of the excise of the 15 per cent investment tax. As we have already experienced the red herrings that are cast across the trail of our amendments, I foreshadow that later I will move an amendment to clause 64, which is a statement of intent, so that nobody can be in any doubt that the intention of the Opposition is to ensure that all superannuants benefit from the excising of the 15 per cent investment tax-not just some and not just those who are preferred by the deal between the Government and the Australian Democrats.

On a quick recap, the situation is this: the Democrats voted with us on 1 June to excise the tax on superannuation funds and approved deposit funds. This morning I moved an amendment which would excise the tax on pooled superannuation trusts. I have now moved a series of amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill which would excise the tax from life offices dealing with superannuation policies held by complying superannuation funds, complying approved deposit funds (ADFs) or roll-over annuities. That would ensure that all of the 3.5 million superannuants would be beneficiaries of the amendments. Senator Walsh has already indicated that he will be seeking to remove the amendments that were passed by the Senate on 1 June, and put back the original wording in the Bills as they were first printed-that is, to take away the benefit that the Senate has already bestowed. That will mean, if the rest of his plan is complied with, that only 100,000 people in superannuation funds will benefit from the tax being excised. It is just too difficult to include the 5,000 people who are in roll-over annuities or deferred annuities, so they will have to be left out in the cold. It does not matter that they entered their superannuation fund in good faith; it does not matter that the only difference between an ADF and a roll-over fund is basically that, at the end of the day, the roll-over fund offers the superannuant the option of taking a pension-type payment instead of a lump sum. I would have thought that option would certainly have been in accordance with Government policy and in accordance with the Democrats' wishes. It is certainly in accordance with the coalition's wishes to attempt to achieve more self-reliance for people in a population which is steadily ageing. We should be delighted that the people of Australia are healthy and live longer. Yet most of them are to be discriminated against by the deal done between the Government and the Democrats.

As I said, we are moving these amendments to this Bill, dealing with this particular part of the industry, because that is the manner in which the Government has chosen to introduce the legislation. As I also said earlier, the nature of the drafting of the Bills is such that the original Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) is, in effect, amended by the Bill that we are now debating. I gave the example of how clause 49 repeals section 275 of the principal Act and substitutes a new provision. It deals with the very meaty issue that we were dealing with a little while ago of the contributions tax. How interesting it is that the original intent of the Bill, under the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) provision, was that the actual amount of the contribution had to be paid over to the body that was accepting the liability before that liability could be transferred. But, in the amending legislation-the Superannuation Bill-that clause is repealed and no longer does the actual contribution of the cash have to be transferred to the other body for the liability to be transferred.

There are two aspects about which the Opposition is most concerned. Firstly, there is an absolute need, which is echoed in every publication by people who write about the economy, to increase the amount of savings that are accruing in this country. That means we have to attract into superannuation funds groups of people which have never been attracted to superannuation before. Such people have to be given a level playing field. People who are to be attracted to superannuation funds must be told, `Look, don't take your hard earned, after tax money and spend it on something that will give you instant enjoyment or gratification; put that money into a superannuation fund and take the benefit at the end of the day'. Would a prospective superannuation client who saw the history of this Government's treatment of superannuation, its greedy tax grab, by using superannuation as a milch cow to add to its coffers, and the 20 changes to superannuation that this Government has introduced since it came to office, think it was a reasonably safe and predictable investment? Would they not be better advised to buy an antique clock or two, which might appreciate in value and be more stable than a superannuation investment?

One of the other arguments which Senator Walsh has used in the course of the debate is that the 15 per cent investment tax is, somehow, an instrument of government investment policy. He says it is very important that we have this tax so that people who choose to invest in the equity market will invest in those Australian companies which pay the full tax which is due; dividends paid will be franked; and imputed dividends will be paid over the superannuation funds. Senator Walsh says it is very important to do that because it will increase the amount of investment in those equities. What he has not bothered to say is that the imputation system is not quarantined to the investment tax; it can also be applied to the contributions tax. Therefore, if we excise the 15 per cent investment tax, the investment attractiveness of equities will remain.

One matter that is most important, in the Opposition's eyes, is that, if superannuation is to be attractive, it must be simple. One of the speakers in this debate today said that, once upon a time, when one entered into a superannuation agreement it was very simple. It is now extremely complicated. As I have said, if we are to have more Australians providing for themselves at the end of the day, instead of simply relying on government-funded schemes, we have to attract more and more people into superannuation schemes. The figures speak for themselves. In the private sector, only 39 per cent of people are in superannuation schemes. In the public sector, the number improves dramatically to 67 per cent.

That still leaves an awful lot of Australians who are not covered and who should be made to feel that superannuation is a real option for them. As I said before in this debate, that means that people on the lower margin of tax rates, who presently find superannuation to be unattractive in its totality, have to be attracted towards it. It is particularly important for women to be attracted into superannuation schemes. For the most part, they are the people on the lower marginal rates because that is the nature of our present wages system. That fact, together with the fact that women live, on average, nine years longer than men, means that superannuation is a key question for women.

I return to the question as to why we want to get rid of all the tax, not just a part of it. We do not want to say to 5,000 people that they do not matter a row of beans and to the remainder of the 3.5 million Australians that we do not think that we have to consider them too greatly either. The reasons why we are adamantly pursuing this course, and why we will call upon the Democrats not to change their minds from 1 June when they voted with us-

TALK.START.PARA: —We haven't. We changed our vote.

—We can quibble about whether changing their minds and changing their votes are the same thing. The fact of the matter is that the Democrats did vote with us previously to get rid of the 15 per cent investment tax and they have chosen to do a deal with the Government. They say they have not changed their minds; they say that was their intention all along: but in the Democrats' original amendments which we moved in the Senate on 1 June they did, indeed, seek to include pooled superannuation trusts. The Democrats are no longer concerned about that.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to note what Senator Haines was quoted as saying, as recently as this morning, in the Sydney Morning Herald:
The leader of the Democrats, Senator Haines, said that around 100,000 retired investors would be exempt from the tax because they were in ADFs.
However, about 5,000 investors in deferred annuities and pooled super funds-which have the same investment portfolio as ADFs-could not be exempted because of legal complexities.

This was regrettable. How would honourable senators feel if they were one of the 5,000? Would they feel that it was `regrettable'? I think I could find a much stronger adjective to use. She said that there was no way that these people could be excised from the tax. Well, there is, and that option is now before this Committee. That option is to leave the amendments as they are and to support our additional amendments that are now before the Committee, and at some other stage to include pooled superannuation trusts as well. The option is here for the Democrats to exercise. But, we read in the press that it is regrettable that 5,000 people are left out, that only 100,000 people are to be preferred and that the remainder of the 3.5 million are to be ignored.

Senator Haines was concerned with another aspect, too, which I will deal with when the Minister for Finance moves his amendments. I refer to the question of retrospectivity with regard to trust deeds, on which a number of legal people at a very late stage have been able to express an opinion on this very complex matter. It is worth putting on record why this has happened. I asked that the Government's amendments be made available to us. That was done. We were alleged to have had them 24 hours in advance, but we did not get them a full 24 hours in advance. The debate on the Bill was put off. As late as 5.45 yesterday evening, I spoke to somebody from the Treasurer's office and was assured that I would have the further amendment or addition-call it what you will-within half an hour. I received from the Government the additional amendment at 9.10 this morning. I have gathered-and other Opposition members have shared in this responsibility-various legal advices as to the effectiveness of the Government's amendments so that we may debate them when the Committee deals with clause 56. I thought it was important to place this on record because it is part and parcel of the reason why the Opposition persists in its view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —These five amendments pick up one of the errors in the Opposition's original amendment that was passed a fortnight ago-an error which the Opposition steadfastly insisted did not exist. The original error that the Opposition made with this legislation was to leave its carriage to two people whose ambition vastly exceeds their ability. When it was pointed out to Mr Connolly that this was the case, he responded, according to a report in the Age, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition spokesman, Mr Connolly, counterclaimed that the Government had either bluffed the Senate or had perpetrated `a barefaced ambush'. Mr Connolly said he still believed that the Opposition amendment covered all superannuation funds. It had been drafted by parliamentary officials, checked by the industry-
it would be interesting to know who from the industry checked them-
and it would have been seen days beforehand by the Government. If Senator Walsh was right, he owed Parliament an explanation as to why he had not pointed out the error earlier.

The sequence of excuses from Mr Connolly went `Walsh is wrong, Walsh had an ambush, it is Walsh's fault'. I wish to make a couple of other points on this part of the Bill, which is as good a place as any to make these comments. Opposition senators preached sanctimonious sermons at us for about three hours this morning and for several hours before that. For decades Liberal or coalition governments presided over the festering sore of superannuation. They watched superannuation degenerate into the crudest of tax rorts, which allowed crooks like the Kelly brothers and other cherry pickers to evade millions and millions of dollars in taxation under the pretext that they were providing for superannuation. All that was presided over with culpable negligence by Liberal Party governments. They had no policy-they still have no policy other than reactive opportunism.

As soon as the present Government began to clean up the superannuation mess-the festering, suppurating sore over which they had presided for decades-what did we have from the Opposition? We have reactive opportunism and sabotage. Initially there was a promise to repeal the lump sum tax, which is an essential component of a policy to prevent superannuation degenerating into a payment of deferred wages-which is what it had degenerated into, amongst other things. That promise no longer seems to be operative. Now the Opposition opposes the 15 per cent tax on fund earnings. The coalition wants to continue to preside over a superannuation policy which has the following investment effects: an incentive for funds to invest in foreign equities instead of Australian equities; an incentive for business to go in for debt financing instead of equity financing; an incentive to indulge in speculative investment instead of productive investment. That is the sort of policy that the Opposition wants to see continued. This is completely consistent with its record of many decades in government-a record of culpable neglect of superannuation policy and its degeneration into a tax rort. In short, the Opposition's past and present policy on this issue can be summed up as one of no guts, no brains and no principles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments moved by my colleague, Senator Bishop which are about fairness, equity and treating people in the same way. Is it not blatantly unfair that a person who deals with a bank could be treated differently from a person who goes to a life office to seek an approved deposit fund (ADF)? These amendments are about treating in the same way people who basically have made the same decision. One person could choose to go to a bank, which sells an ADF, and the other could choose to go to superannuation organisation and buy the equivalent of an ADF in a pooled superannuation arrangement. This proposal discriminates against friendly societies and all the registered organisations, and puts some people at a disadvantage compared with others. One person could be given an advantage in a plan and somebody else could be worse off. Our amendments seek to bring about fairness.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, to talk about promises that were made 20 years ago when the legislative environment was very different and to try to pin that on to the Liberal Party in today's environment. Does the Minister not recognise that the legislative provisions and the environment have changed? It might be a good debating point to say that 20 years ago the proposal was such and such, and that it was different again five years ago, but one cannot apply those undertakings to the environment that we are in today. This proposal seeks to exempt from tax superannuation plans, ADFs or pooled superannuation trusts. This is going to cause a flight of people out of certain plans into others. The Government is providing an opportunity for some people to be better off. What are people going to do? They are going to move their investments because of this legislation into different sorts of plans. Our amendment is to ensure that there is equity, that they are all going to be treated the same and that their investments are going to be the same.

I remind the Government that until a few months ago advisers were telling people to invest in particular types of plans because they provided better benefits. I refer to the issue of deferred annuities. It was acknowledged across the board by those who knew that deferred annuities were the best way for people to invest their money. There is no doubt that there are advantages. As a result of what is happening now these people are worse off. Fancy legislating to make people worse off when it was acknowledged, under the law that previously existed, that that was the way to go! Instead, the Government is deliberately discriminating against these people as a result of what has been offered and promised here today. What the Government is virtually saying is, `We want to give ADFs a marketing edge'. How does that fit with the integrity of the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party? The Government says, `We want to single out people and we want to single out those funds run by the banks and others, particularly ADFs, and we will give them a definite advantage'. I have got news for the Government. When the new changes are debated there will be problems. The Government is going to wipe out whole lots of ADFs. Within these ADFs there are segments which provide for capital growth equity link. There is no provision in the Bills to provide for this segmentation. So the Government is going to defeat what it is really after because there is no provision to treat its capital secured funds differently from others within this particular bracket as a result of its 90 per cent provision clauses and others.

The Australian Democrats have been conned. All the people that they are referring to will not have anywhere near the coverage that they are talking about. If the Australian Democrats look closely at what is before them, they are going to be in trouble. I am surprised that they took the stand that they did a few months ago when they voted with the Government against our earlier amendment. By that vote, they lost their flexibility to support ours. The Australian Democrats cannot say that they have been swayed by the argument of the debate and the logic of that argument in the Senate, because they have already made up their minds to deny the benefits that they feel should be going to a restricted category. That category will not be as wide as they think it is because of the restrictive nature of the amendments. The Government, through its subsequent amendments, has conned the Democrats. The operations of the ADFs will be a lot narrower than the Democrats thought they would be.

What is going to be done about restoring the benefits that were promised to all the people in ADFs who thought they were going to get a benefit but, because they were part of a bigger ADF plan which had different components within it, will be excluded? How will they be excised? Perhaps during the lunch break the advisers could tell the Minister how that excising of the different types of equity links compared with the capital secured ones within the ADFs will work. There is a problem there and the scope of the legislation will be a lot narrower. If the Democrats are not going to support these amendments, this legislation will give a marketing edge to a particular group to the detriment of others who previously had an advantage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., under sessional order I shall report progress.
