SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Administrator for the Northern Territory, Commodore Johnston, retires on 30 June. Commodore Johnston has had eight and a half years in office as Administrator of the Northern Territory. In paying tribute to the service and the work that both Commodore Johnston and his wife, Joan Johnston, have contributed to the Northern Territory I would particularly describe His Honour as a man of honour, hard work and humour.

SPEECH.PARA: Commodore Johnston was no newcomer to the Northern Territory when he was appointed Administrator on 1 January 1981. He had previously served as part of his very distinguished naval career as the officer commanding northern Australia based in Darwin in that period that embraced Cyclone Tracy. In the period since 1981 the Administrator has seen under him-that is one way of putting it-four Chief Ministers: Chief Minister Everingham, Chief Minister Tuxworth, Chief Minister Hatton and Chief Minister Perron.

Commodore Johnston has brought to his tasks as the Administrator of the Northern Territory, as I have said, a particular background of honour; that, of course, draws very heavily on his own career in the Navy. He started as a midshipman at age 13 and served Australia well and also served in the United Kingdom. When I describe Commodore Johnston as a man of hard work I believe the fact that he has seen so many Ministers come and go in the political operation of the Northern Territory Government would probably give him much to contemplate and, of course, the operation of his Administrator's Executive Council must at all times have been a very interesting operation.

Commodore Johnston is well known for the very extensive travelling that he undertook throughout the Northern Territory and in doing so he endeared himself to the people of the Northern Territory. I do not believe there is anybody in the Northern Territory who has travelled as widely, as extensively, or as meaningfully as Commodore Johnston in the last eight and a half years. I continually look at my diary and try to cover the principal seven or eight urban towns and the 45 or so principal Aboriginal communities and I am always competing with that diary in an effort to get around and cover as much ground as I can. I can honestly say that due to the hard work of Commodore Johnston he has probably covered most of those communities frequently during his term of office.

As I said, the Administrator is also a man of great humour. I think this has been the particularly endearing attribute that has drawn him so close to the people of the Northern Territory. I would like to take one moment to quote from a speech that His Honour gave last year in the 1988 Menzies Oration to the Menzies School of Health. The Administrator was describing his early arrival in the Northern Territory:

The first truly hectic day was Australia Day 1981 which seemed to be a never ending series of speeches and visits, each with an attendant change of clothing. One such visit was to the Fannie Bay racecourse for the Australia Day Cup, where, dressed in uniform I went for a stroll through the betting ring with Alec Fong Lim. My homecoming was complete when I was confronted by a well-oiled punter, clad in shorts and thongs and clutching his green can life support system. My inebriated friend focused with some difficulty on the white clad vision which confronted him and then asked, `Who the hell are you?' Drawing the last tattered remnant of my Canberra pomposity around me, I intoned, `I am your new Administrator'. Some seconds of silence ensued whilst this earth shattering news was dissected and digested and then the decision was delivered, `Big deal'. Off he went to terrorise some bookmaker. My preconceived view of the territorians' conception of my civic position had been well and truly vindicated.

That is just one example of the approach that Commodore Johnston has brought to this very important office, that of Administrator of the Northern Territory. Mrs Joan Johnston has also supported her husband continually throughout his various vice-regal jobs and attendant responsibilities. The Administrator is the patron of some 89 organisations in the Northern Territory, all of which, I believe, hold him very close. In all of those organisations he took a very intimate interest. Similarly, Mrs Johnston has also played a very important role in her own right with many women's and other community organisations throughout the Northern Territory.

They have forged very close relationships with the various aspects and people of the Northern Territory, particularly those people drawn from the Aboriginal communities that they visited so frequently. I am pleased today to pay a tribute to the eight and a half years that Commodore Johnston has been the Administrator of the Northern Territory and I wish both him and his wife well in their retirement for which they will be making their home in Darwin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to speak on a report that was laid on the table yesterday; that is Drugs in Sport.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on this report at this stage, mainly in protest at the way things were run yesterday. There was a certain amount of on-and-offness about this report being tabled and when it was eventually tabled we were allocated, no doubt by arrangement between Whips, one from either side, little time to speak because of the pressure of Government legislation. However, I do recognise the need to get Government legislation through at this time of the year, as the session is coming to an end. We certainly do not want to keep the Senate back here next week.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that where there are six people on an inquiry who have been meeting in this place and all over Australia for the past six months, anyone on that inquiry should be given the opportunity to speak on the report at its tabling. Otherwise I can see that, in future, it could affect the ability of this Parliament to fill the numbers on committees. That is one of the reasons I do want to speak on the report and I intend to speak briefly.

I commend the Chairman and the Secretariat for the way they have conducted the inquiry. I believe it reflects nothing but good on the Chairman and the Secretariat-not only the way it was conducted but also the way that the report was drawn up finally. On the drugs side, the use of drugs in sport has been a problem since the Olympics of 1964; that is when problems started to spread around the world. It started mainly from the Eastern bloc countries and spread to the Western nations as well, mainly for the reason that they have to be able to compete. The unfortunate part about it is that a lot of people do not realise that the athlete must have ability in a particular sport first. Secondly, that ability must be developed to possibly the end capacity of the human body so that it can be used on the track. Unfortunately, for a lot of athletes and competing nations around the world, it has not been left at that, just to get the absolute maximum amount of ability in the human body. Athletes have resorted to the use of enhancement drugs to get that little bit extra to be past their fellow men and women. Eventually, winning a competition is made rather one-sided if drugs are used and they certainly cannot replace ability.

Turning to Australia and the Australian Institute of Sport, more particularly, I believe that the use of drugs at the AIS and in Australia for that matter in athletics is far more widespread than we had ever imagined when the inquiry first started. I believe that they were introduced, not by the heads of the AIS or the head of any department of that institution or athletic association around Australia, but by rather adventuresome coaches who were appointed, mostly in the field of the power sports. I refer to weight-lifting, rowing and those sorts of things. As I have said before, it was done to keep up with the rest of the world.

Unfortunately, when drugs were introduced in the AIS it seems to me that the head of the AIS and its top management certainly were not aware of it at the beginning. Had they been aware at the beginning, I think things would have been vastly different. What worries me is that a certain coach there-and I do not mind mentioning that it was Lyn Jones-was probably the instigator of the use of these drugs and, what is more, could have been the instigator of importing drugs and using Australian athletes to get them past the Customs checks.

Page xxxviii of the report contains the recommendation that regulations concerning the importation of drugs be looked at and, particularly, Australian athletes taking them past Customs. I also would like to mention that on page 271 of the report there is a schedule that was used at the AIS when obviously steroids were being issued to be taken by athletes. The point I did make during the inquiry is that although Lyn Jones in front of us all the time kept pointing out how professional he is in his game-that he is professional at this and professional at that-he distributed a chart which was supposedly going to be a research program on certain vitamin pills and seemed to be drawn up by a kid in grade 4. I do not want to downgrade anyone in grade 4, but he was very amateurish for a fellow who maintains he is professional everywhere.

I would like to move on to other parts of the report and to the administration of the AIS in the lower levels rather than the higher levels. When it came to the administration of finances and purchases of vitamins, or whatever they purported them to be, I took it to be that steroids were being used. They were that amateurish that one of the coaches, justifying his purchase from a chemist shop in Sydney, came back to the AIS with a receipt to reclaim his money. Obviously writing that receipt himself, he put the wrong address on it. Instead of writing `Colin Bova, chemist, Burwood, Sydney', he put, `Colin Bova, chemist, Victoria.' I searched through the register of the Pharmacy Council of Victoria and no Colin Bova was ever registered in that State. Some of the methods used were very amateurish and I consider that the AIS, in using public money, should look well into its financial administration.

Then we came to the case I would like to mention briefly, Mr Acting Deputy President, where obviously the AIS was caught out using steroids and tried to make it sound as if they were used for therapeutic reasons; in other words, they were given to the athletes for medical reasons. I quote from page 199 of the report:
USE OF ANABOLIC STEROIDS FOR MEDICAL PURPOSES
The first of these cases occurred in 1986 and involved an athlete who subsequently went on to represent Australia . . . The second case was in 1987.

On the AIS policy of medical use of steroids, Professor Bloomfield, Chairman of the AIS Board, was asked what was the Board's policy in relation to an employee of the Institute who provided any banned drugs. He replied, `They should be dismissed'. Then he went on to say after further questioning on the therapeutic use of drugs, particularly with a second opinion: `Yes, we agree they can be used. We can see no major problem, provided it had been fully demonstrated to us that it may be necessary to assist in the repair of an injury'. Professor Bloomfield further agreed that this distinction between therapeutic and performance-enhancing use of banned drugs did not exist in writing but noted that on two occasions it had been implicitly approved by a decision made by the Executive. He also agreed that the anabolic steroids are totally banned in so far as high level international competition is concerned, and agreed that they should not be used under any circumstances but they are at the AIS. Carrying on further, when they obviously did use them, they did try to make a distinction between steroids and drugs used clinically.

The Committee noted with interest a document `Drugs and the Australian Institute of Sport-Guidelines for Staff' on an AIS file. This paper was apparently for consideration of the AIS board on 7 October 1987 and stated:

The Board recognises that some prescribed drugs may be used or may be contained in substances used in legitimate medical use by an athlete. Therefore athletes will be tested for anabolic steroids, only unless the director of the Institute otherwise directs.

The clear implication of this statement, Mr Acting Deputy President, is that in the Board's opinion, anabolic steroids have no legitimate medical use. It should be noted that the two cases involved in the administration of anabolic steroids took place in October 1986 and March 1987 even though this proposed rule has been around since 1986. As time marches on, I will turn briefly to quote Dr Ken Fitch of Perth, Western Australia, on the value of treatment of steroids:

Professor Bloomfield told the Committee that the therapeutic use of anabolic steroids could be justified if it could be fully demonstrated that they are necessary to assist in the repair of some major injury. In this context it is of interest to examine the success of the treatment.

As discussed previously, Dr Ken Fitch, Chairman of the Australian Olympic Medical Commission, has commented, for example, that `the use of anabolic steroids to treat injury cannot be deemed to be conventional medical practice. Quite simply', he said, `they have no role to play at all. It may be that some doctors are prescribing them but there is no scientific evidence of any kind to support their use'.

Concluding now, Mr Acting Deputy President, it has obviously been pointed out and backed by other medical experts that steroids have no place whatsoever in therapeutic use. Dr Fricker and Dr Macguire, having been caught out, tried to use the therapeutic value as a lame excuse. Obviously evidence that we had before the Committee by Dr Fitch and others-there was a Professor Donike, I believe-certainly proved that they were wrong. I believe that much more inquiry has to be done on the AIS to bring it back into the guidelines or the use that the AIS was formulated for in the first place; that is, to bring Australian athletes to the fore of world competition by fair and square means. Its emphasis should be on fairness in sport and not on taking part in drug use in sport around the world. For a time it may be successful for certain athletes, but then they pay for it later in injuries and with their own health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter of public interest this afternoon to express some concerns over an incident which has happened overseas but is causing great concern among a group of my constituents back in Western Australia. Indeed, it is causing great concern among groups of people right throughout Australia and I would dare suggest that those concerns will be echoed from other places in the rest of the free world. The matter is the arrest and detention in Anchorage, Alaska, of Mr Sergio Buschmann.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Buschmann reached prominence in Australia here in the last few weeks. That prominence was particularly pointed in Perth where Mr Buschmann was detained by immigration officials. He appeared in court in an appeal against a deportation order and did eventually lose that appeal and was deported by the Australian Government. Mr Buschmann was en route-a safe route the Government officials were told-back to his present home in Stockholm when the aircraft in which he was travelling landed in Anchorage and he was detained by United States immigration officials. I do not profess to be an expert on foreign policy or the immigration laws of the United States, but I am led to understand, and so far it has not been denied to me, that the act by the United States Government through its officials is an illegal act under international law. Mr Buschmann had never had any intention of remaining in Anchorage or in the territory of the United States; he was in transit; it was merely a refuelling stop, and he should have been allowed back on the aircraft to complete his journey.

In making those comments, I have limited knowledge of the events that have happened, and that is a qualification I put on a condemnation of the United States Government and the United States immigration officials in Anchorage. If events are as they are reported in a number of media in Australia today, the United States really cannot stand up on platforms and claim that it supports civil liberties or freedom of movement of people. Whilst I have the opportunity of saying a few words in relation to what could be an illegal arrest and detention, I may also put on the record the fact that I did have a fairly significant involvement with Mr Buschmann and his supporters in Perth while he was in Perth. Honourable senators will not see any record of my involvement on the front pages of the print media of Australia or, indeed, on the television sets because there are different ways to work through a problem.

I have read media reports today which lay the blame for Mr Buschmann's present predicament at the feet of the Federal Government. I think because of my intimate knowledge of the events surrounding Mr Buschmann's arrest and his appearance before immigration officials in Perth, later his arrest, and finally his deportation from Perth, that the blame really does not lie with the Federal Government. I will not now point the finger at anybody, or lay the blame on any individuals involved, but I do make the point that Mr Buschmann was badly advised on the eventual course of events over in Perth. There were a number of commitments-

TALK.START.PARA: —Someone has to take responsibility.

—I think there is probably a time and place to level that responsibility and I do not believe that this is the time. I think that an individual's life possibly might be endangered and I do not believe in inflaming a situation that might ultimately lead to that eventuality. Turning to the point that I was making about ill advice to Mr Buschmann and his supporters at the time, I am aware, because of my intervention on their behalf over in Perth, that the Government was doing what it possibly could within the law to satisfy the demands that were being placed upon it regarding Mr Buschmann's leaving Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I regret to say that, despite the efforts of my office and myself, the officers of a number of my colleagues in the Federal Parliament and State colleagues and civil rights individuals, the advice that we were given and the agreements that were reached were not fully complied with by Mr Buschmann and/or his supporters. Because of that I think a lot of talking needs to be done before final blame is to be levelled at any particular individual or individuals in this sad event, not only for Mr Buschmann, but also for this nation and our record on civil rights.

I think a number of people have actually sought headlines, rather than trying to reach an amicable resolution of the situation that we found ourselves in. I find even today, on a report that has come through the Australian Associated Press, that the Civil Liberties Council is attacking the Government over the extradition moves that may eventuate in the United States to return Mr Buschmann to Chile where undoubtedly he will be interned, possibly even killed, or murdered, as would be a proper explanation of it. Unfortunately the Civil Liberties Council, which I hold in high regard, from the Press release that I have in front of me at the moment, has not got its facts right. It claims that the Australian Government repeatedly insisted that it would not extradite Buschmann to the tyrannical regime in Chile, yet the Government brushed aside the concern of the Uniting Church and other sponsoring groups and put Buschmann on a Qantas flight that landed in Anchorage on American soil.

Unfortunately the author-the article is attributed to Dr Factor, who is an officer of the Civil Liberties Council-obviously has not checked the facts through. She has not checked her facts because no Qantas flight landed in Anchorage. Certainly Mr Buschmann left Australia on a Qantas flight; he arrived at Narita airport in Tokyo and then changed aircraft and airline. No Qantas flight flew into Anchorage or into the United States carrying Mr Buschmann. One part of the Press statement is right, that the Government did repeatedly insist that it would not extradite Buschmann back to Chile. Indeed the Government did not; the Government actually bent over backwards to ensure that Mr Buschmann was given a safe passage out of the country. Unfortunately Mr Buschmann or his supporters did not take up the offers and the flights that were offered to him at that point during the debacle.

It is sad and when we do look to an analysis of what has happened in this sad affair hopefully the blame, if any, can be clearly directed to where it properly should rest; but I do not think this is the time to do it. Before I sit down, Mr Acting Deputy President, I would remark that a number of members of Parliament, colleagues of mine in this place, and groups outside in the community, have expressed their concerns to the Australian Government on the detention of Mr Buschmann and his being taken off the aircraft.

Our concerns have been listened to by the Government and the Government has lodged a protest to the United States Government. We will be doing, I am assured by Government officials, whatever is in our power as a government to ensure that the United States Government does not return or extradite Mr Buschmann to his most certain death in Chile. I think it proves again that our Government has acted responsibly in this matter and it is unfortunate that some individuals, including the Australian Council for Civil Liberties, have not sought and got the facts clear before jumping on the band-wagon.

I suspect that a headline is probably more important to some people at some times than is the protection of an individual's life. I will make this final qualification before I do sit down-and I am aware that politicians usually take three or four times to wind up. I make this statement to one and all in the campaign. Even though I have done what I could in my office as a parliamentarian for the State of Western Australia to assist Mr Buschmann to get safe passage out of Australia, I do not hold with each and every thing that Mr Buschmann stands for. I certainly do hold with the return of Chile to a democratically elected government.

I do have some dispute with Mr Buschmann over the means of achieving that return to a democratically elected government. Speaking with an accent like mine, I am aware of the sorrow and the suffering that people living under repressive regimes have to endure and I certainly hope that the people of Chile will, in the very near future, return to a democratically elected nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise in the Senate today what I regard as a very important matter that affects the life and well-being of a former Afghan Army general, one Mohammad Nida, who was previously a senior officer with the Supreme National Defence Council of Afghanistan until he effectively defected on 23 March last. Since that time he has been residing in India on a visa which will expire on 23 June next. Efforts have been made on a regular basis since that time to enable the general to be reunited with several members of his family in this country. As Chairman of the Afghan/Australia Council, I have written to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Ray, to ascertain the Government's attitude to the general's application to enter Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I am most unhappy and dissatisfied with the response to date and I do not at this stage blame the Minister for that, but it may well be that there is some confusion of objectives between the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. The end result is this: the general attended the Australian High Commission in New Delhi on several occasions and was subjected to fairly intensive questioning. From the information available to me, after having discussed the matter with people who should know, there would seem to be no doubt about his bona fides. Yet the Australian High Commission has summarily rejected the application and, at this stage, the Minister, Senator Ray, is relying on that advice and has not acceded to the request.

I regard that as a very serious matter because I do think it is incumbent upon the High Commission to explain its reasons, if it has good and valid reasons to object. It should make them known to the Minister responsible for making the decision. For it to have simply declined to do so to date is not good enough, and I think it is very important indeed that that should happen without delay. But what is, of course, of critical importance is that, because the visa expires next Friday, General Nida is in imminent danger of being forcibly repatriated to Afghanistan, where he faces certain execution. I have that on advice from people in this country who know the extent of the close relationship between India and Afghanistan, and have no doubt at all that, although lesser mortals have not been deported back to Afghanistan, in this instance there is every likelihood that a very senior army officer will be repatriated and once that happens, of course, he will not survive in Afghanistan for very long.

Indeed, information communicated to me this morning indicates that, as a result of a press conference given by General Nida in New Delhi yesterday, he has since found that a vehicle from the Soviet Embassy in Delhi has been driving up and down outside his apartment and he is very concerned that he may even be kidnapped whilst in Delhi. I have information that the Soviet Embassy in New Delhi has made it clear to the British Broadcasting Corporation representative that it believes that General Nida made misleading statements in his press conference. I know of no reason for that and neither indeed does the general. The concern is that, if the Soviet officials are determined to deal with him and have him either sent back to Afghanistan or simply dealt with on the spot, General Nida's life is in very real danger.

The matter of utmost concern to me is a document which has been made available to me in the last 24 hours. It is over the name of one Rajiv Kapur, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees senior program officer for the UNHCR Charge de Mission in Delhi. I seek leave to table the document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Resettlement of Afghans in Australia

(1) The Australian High Commission has informed us that they have stopped all applications for resettlement in Australia from Afghans until they know what will happen in Afghanistan and if people can go back.
(2) All persons, including those who applied for Australia before, will therefore not be called for interview.
(3) Any inquiry should be to the Australian High Commission and not to UNHCR.
(4) Those who have already completed their medical examinations are not affected.
(5) This is only for Afghans.

On the face of that document, and assuming that it is genuine, that is a very clear case of discrimination against one particular ethnic group. I know of no reason why that should be so. The office of the Minister for Immigration is similarly not aware of any such decision by the Australian High Commission in Delhi and I publicly call on the Government to explain what seems to be a very unsatisfactory and discriminatory state of affairs. I know it has been the view for some years of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade that, because Afghan refugees constitute about five million out of a total world refugee population in excess of 15 million, and the majority of them are from rural areas, they should all be treated as persons simply wanting to return to their homeland when the current war has ceased. That is simply not good enough.

The experience that I have from dealing with about 500 in Melbourne and another 1,000 or so around Australia is that they are model citizens; that they assimilate very well into this country; that they are very energetic and enterprising citizens and there are very many of them who are basically urban middle-class. They are not in the rural, peasant category; they are not wanting simply to return to a devastated Kabul; they are wanting to make a new life for themselves. I think it is an outrageously generalised approach that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade takes to this matter, simply to put all of the five million into the same category when, clearly, that is not so and, clearly, any case by case assessment would indicate that very many of them have credentials that would benefit this country greatly.

So I call upon the Australian Government to explain this memo, to say whether it is accurate that the Australian High Commissioner has made such a decision. If it is accurate, and it has made that decision, then on whose authority was it made? Why was it not communicated to the office of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, who is ultimately of course responsible for processing such applications? In the ultimate I urge the Government not only to reconsider but also to rescind this memorandum and not resume the current, in my view, overly restrictive approach that is being taken to the processing of such applications, indeed to expand it and to treat such persons on a much more generous and humanitarian basis. One can only say that, if the approach taken to date to General Nida's predicament is indicative of the attitude of the Australian Government, it leaves a great deal to be desired.

The Australian Government will have blood on its hands if General Nida is deported by the Indian authorities when his visa expires on Friday next, because there can be no doubt at all that he will have a very short life expectancy if returned to his homeland. I therefore urge the Government to rethink the situation of General Nida in particular, and the resettlement of Afghans in Australia in general.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Right across this nation there is an overwhelming plea for affordable and available child-care. As this Government's economic policies further squeeze Australian families the need for child-care is growing at an alarming rate as many mothers are being forced to go into the work force. In April this year more than 500 people marched through the city streets of Melbourne demanding affordable child-care and a boost in the number of available places. In New South Wales and Queensland waiting lists are such that many people are resorting to registering for a child-care place upon the birth of their child.

SPEECH.PARA: In Tasmania the child-care funding crisis has reached such proportions that last Tuesday a public meeting was held in Launceston to discuss the impending and crippling fee increases. These increases will put child-care well beyond the reach of the average family and it will make a mockery of this Government's so-called commitment to child-care.

The meeting in Launceston pointed out that the Federal Government is neglecting its commitment to provide in real terms a program to ensure that parents and children have access to quality child-care services, regardless of cultural background, disability of geographical isolation and in proportion to income. The reality is that under this Government child-care is becoming a luxury. In today's society and with today's economic climate, thanks to this Government's mismanagement, child-care is a necessity. The situation, I think, is best summed up by the spokesperson for the Victorian Child Care Action Group who was quoted in the Age on 10 April this year as saying:
The Federal Government has paid lip service to the child care issue during a period when families are being squeezed by tight economic policies.

For those families who cannot survive today's mortgage rates and the cost of living without two incomes, for those single parents who choose to work to support their children rather than to depend on welfare and for those unemployed parents who need time to look for jobs, to attend interviews or to attend job retraining schemes, reasonably priced child-care is a basic necessity of life. So it is also for young mothers in the education system, as a group of young mothers at the Tasmanian State Institute of Technology pointed out only last week. I quote from the Launceston Examiner of 7 June:

`I saw a parent here in tears because of the choice she had to make-whether to leave her children at home or bring them to lectures', said one nursing studies lecturer. `In this day and age people shouldn't have to make the choice between education and children.'

Featured in that Examiner article is a story of a young mother doing a course and who has two small children, 2 1/2 years and six months old. She said that the cost of child-care was a reason for going part time; she had given up full time studies and if the child-care facilities were adequate she would not need to be constantly ducking home to breastfeed the baby. But she will battle on. The feeling is that it is a vicious circle. Parents retrain so that they can go back to work to better provide for their children but while they are studying they and their children are missing out. Without affordable child-care these people would simply give up and turn to welfare hand-outs in order to care and to provide for their children. In recognition of this, most child-care centres in my home State of Tasmania have held their fees down for so long, or for as long as they could reasonably do so, but they simply cannot do so any longer. The crunch has come.

The Commonwealth subsidy ceiling of $90 per week per child has not increased in three years. It no longer covers the expenses involved in running a child-care centre. The Launceston Creche Committee has pointed out that child-care staff salary increases, 3 per cent superannuation, $10 national wage increase, 4 per cent second tier and 3 per cent national wage rise were not allowed to be included in the Committee's annual budget. As a result, the Committee estimates that a break-even fee which includes a conservative 7 per cent allowance for the consumer price index must be $136 per child per week.

Clearly, rising operating costs have left the centres with no choice but to increase their fees by at least 20 per cent from 1 July this year or close down altogether. The choice those centres face is either to cater for those parents in need and to become bankrupt doing so, or to cater for those who can afford $136 per week per child and provide an elitist service only. Surely, if the latter choice is necessary it defeats the very purpose for which child care centres exist. These centres have been forced to become businesses rather than community services, serving the elite few who can afford to pay for them, rather than the many who desperately need them. It is sheer hypocrisy, in my view, on the part of the Government, on the one hand, to say that it wants more women in the work force and yet, on the other hand, to fail to provide economic child-care facilities.

After these increases that are coming on 1 July, a family with two infant children and earning more than $32,000 a year will have to pay $260 a week for 40 hours of child-care, whilst for some lower income families a 20 per cent increase will put their daily child-care bill in excess of their daily income. In such a situation obviously some mothers have just got no choice but to leave the work force. In last year's Budget Mr Keating promised that the Hawke Government would expand by 30,000 the number of child-care places over the next four years. This is an announcement which the families have heard now several times and are becoming increasingly cynical about. It is simply an announcement that keeps getting repeated, not action.

I am constantly reminding the Senate that this Government has no child-care policy for its Defence Force children; that is, people for whom it has a special responsibility, not only as their employer but as an employer that requires them to go thousands of miles from their extended family and live in isolated and difficult areas. They are young couples, newly married, with little babies and they have no family support of their own. They desperately need child-care but constant postings to suit the service needs mean that they are never in one place long enough to rise to the top of a waiting list.

Some child-care centres in the defence forces have been started with self-help, but recently two of those have had to close due to financial problems-one for the Air Force at Point Cook, Victoria, and another one that is used by the Army and the Navy at Holsworthy in New South Wales. This Federal Government that skites about the 30,000 child-care places that it is going to provide us with refuses to lift a finger to help them and will not produce a child-care policy for the defence forces, having promised to do so for the last three years. The Government's track record in the area of child-care is heavy with rhetoric and with promises but its performance is rotten.

Only yesterday in the Hobart Mercury it was reported that a Ms Dianne Ridley had recently completed a study for the Federal Government on work related child-care and its effects on productivity. She pointed out that work related child-care was not just a women's issue, but could be an important factor in improving productivity. She also pointed out that, due to the falling birth rates, Australia's labour force was going to shrink and would make it more important for employers to minimise staff turnover and attract people back into paid work. So it is an economic necessity for Australia to provide more affordable child-care places.

It is time for this Government to wise up to the reality and to get its priorities right. We have all seen, sadly, in increasing numbers lately, the great Australian dream of owning a home vanish under this Government. Now it seems that affordable child-care for parents who are working to provide a home and to support their families is also going to follow the same path.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 March, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988 is an omnibus Bill for legislation administered within the primary industries and energy portfolio. The Bill has been brought on at this time at the request of the Government to meet its legislative program. It makes a number of amendments to existing legislation, including repeal of the Sugar Agreement Act 1985, repeal of the livestock slaughter legislation, changes to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977 and changes to the Wool Marketing Act 1987. The amendments are not being opposed.

SPEECH.PARA: The repeal of the Sugar Agreement Act of 1985 with effect from 1 July will rescind the current import prohibition on sugar, as announced in the May 1988 economic statement. The current domestic administered pricing arrangements will be terminated on 30 June 1989, the expiry date of the Commonwealth-Queensland Sugar Agreement. The revised agreement ends the 70-year-old embargo on sugar imports and will see the current import embargo replaced with tariffs.

From 1 July this year there will be a tariff of $115 a tonne, which is equivalent to $US4.2c a pound. This will run for two years. On 1 July 1991 the tariff will reduce to $95 a tonne and then to $70 a tonne a year later. The Government's original proposal was for a tariff of 35 per cent for raw sugar and 25 per cent for refined sugar from 1 July 1989, phasing down to 15 per cent from July 1992.

Industry was not consulted about the complications and implications of the Government's original proposal and the Opposition successfully moved for a Senate committee to address the problem of structural adjustment with minimum damage and with adequate protection for sugar growers. The Senate committee took a bipartisan approach and produced a solution which proposed a mixture of deregulation and protection with an Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) inquiry in 1991 to determine the arrangements to apply from the following year.

The Senate committee's recommendations to move up and down with world prices was not accepted by the Government on the grounds of complications with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations. But the Senate committee's recommendations did provide the basis for an all party agreement on a fixed tariff rate which is acceptable to the sugar industry. It should be noted that other sugar producing countries pay huge subsidies to their producers and the world price of sugar is therefore a corrupted price. Sugar ranks after wheat and cheese, along with citrus concentrate, as the most subsidised corrupt international trade item.

Studies have shown that sugar prices are the most volatile of prices for commodities traded internationally. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, has acknowledged this and has spoken of the need for what is called shadow pricing to determine the true world price and possibly to introduce special anti-dumping provisions similar to those in place for European cheese.

With the lifting of the embargo on the importing of sugar, the Government will need to monitor, firstly, the developing country 5 per cent preference on tariffs-these countries are the only significant raw sugar exporters and generally have a developed rather than a developing sugar industry-and, secondly, sugar imports from New Zealand which are tariff free and therefore provide an opportunity for sugar to be dumped into Australia via New Zealand. Concern has already been expressed by an ice cream powder manufacturer in Queensland, who mixes milk powders with sugar for export that his main rival, a New Zealand owned Australian company, is importing milk powders from New Zealand and may now also import the sugar.

Minister Kerin has promised to establish a sugar industry council and an IAC inquiry will be held in 1991 to establish the future needs of the industry from 1 July 1992. The Opposition does not oppose the phasing down of assistance, but I point out once again that the Government has yet to address the endemic problems on the waterfront and in coastal shipping that add to the burdens of our primary producers and pose a major threat to the Darwin and Perth markets for Australian sugar.

This Bill also repeals the Live-Stock Slaughter Export Inspection Charge Act 1979, the amendment Act for 1983, the collection Act for 1979 and the validation Act for 1984. The meat industry moved to a fee for service in respect of Commonwealth meat inspection services from 1 July 1988. The fee for service charging regime comes under the Export Control Act 1982 and has obviated the need for the livestock slaughter inspection charge legislation which related to a per carcass charge.

The change to a fee for service charging system has not been as smooth as industry and government expected and some meat processors have continued to deduct the $2.50 meat inspection charge from cattle producers account sales. This Bill now prevents that and makes it clear that the inspection charge is a fee for service and not a price per head. The Australian Meat and Live-Stock Corporation Act of 1987 changes to this Act implement agreements which have been negotiated between the Australian Meat and Live-Stock Corporation and shipping companies and remove an inconsistency in the Act which resulted from amendments made in 1987.

Finally, on the Wool Marketing Act, the need for these amendments arises from the fraudulent use of wool samples in the wool sale room. Last year a wool broker was found guilty of using wool samples purchased after the sale to represent a further lot. This has led to a re-examination of the security surrounding samples of wool. The purpose of these amendments is to maintain the confidence of wool buyers by ensuring the integrity of wool testing and sampling procedures. Nearly all wool sold at auction is tested for key characteristics which form the basis for a commercial assessment by buyers and payment is also made from the payment of fees in relation to registration and inspection costs. The coalition wishes the Bill a speedy passage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, for the most part this is a housekeeping Bill which will not be opposed by the Opposition, particularly in the light of the statement that has just been made by the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) and the amendments which the Government now proposes to the Bill.

In effect, the present Bill is a bandaid job on very old legislation; in fact, the Audit Act is one of the oldest Acts of the Parliament, having been enacted first in 1901. I think it is fair to say, as indeed the Public Accounts Committee has recently said, that there is a desperate need to reconsider the viability of the Act in its present form. The report of the Public Accounts Committee to which I have just referred and to which I think one or two of my colleagues will also refer in this debate is report No. 286 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, entitled The Auditor-General, Ally of the People and the Parliament. The procedures under which we are operating suggest that I should not take the time of the Senate to elaborate on those points. TALK.START.PARA: —I will keep my remarks short in the interests of allowing as many people as possible to speak. My concern arises initially out of my membership of the Public Accounts Committee and the concern that I express often about the need for accountability of government expenditure. Our attention on the Public Accounts Committee was first drawn to the implications of the Audit Act, and indeed in particular to clause 26, in the course of our inquiry into the use of consultants by government departments. During that inquiry, one of the exhibits that came our way was a proposal for reform of Commonwealth Government purchasing arising from government review under the financial management improvement program and in particular, in appendix 2 of that document, proposed amendments to the Audit Act, Finance Regulations and Finance Directions.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of those inquiries we also had cause to question various government department employees concerning how they presently comply with the financial regulations and the manner in which observance is given to regulations that are already in place. It is significant that in the course of one of these hearings we heard evidence from the Australian Taxation Office about hiring a consultant and not complying with the need under the Finance Regulations to go to tender and purporting to rely on the exemption of section 52aa (2) of the Finance Regulations, which gives a list of exempt types of people when there is no need to go to tender.

On that occasion the Tax Office sought to have a survey conducted of basically the attitude of taxpayers to the Tax Office when their returns were knocked back. Instead of going to tender to find the best survey firm to carry out that survey it chose to rely on appendix A of Finance Regulation 52aa (2) and call these people management consultants. When I asked the witness whether or not the people to whom the contract was given held themselves out as management consultants he replied no. So clearly they did not comply and they did not fall within the exemption of appendix A and the Australian Tax Office was clearly in breach of the laws of the land as they prevail. I then endeavoured to find out what the penalty for this breach was and I found it was a $10 fine. We did refer the matter to the Australian Audit Office, which wrote as follows:

During the Committee's public hearing on Tuesday 18 April 1989, the question arose as to what types of consultancies services fall within the definition of `Management Consultancy Services' which is listed in Appendix A to the Finance Regulation 52aa (2) as one of the kinds of supplies which is exempt from the requirement to obtain quotations or publicly invited tenders. Specifically, the Committee inquired whether the Australian Audit Office considered consultants engaged in conduct market research surveys would be exempt supplies.

2. It is evident that the services similar in nature to market research surveys such as public relations agents and advertising agents and media are listed as exempt supplies. Having regard to the definition of `Consultancy Services' outlined at Finance Direction 25/11 and the types of services listed in Appendix A of Finance Regulation 52aa (2), it is however considered that a strict application of the Regulations, market research surveys, being in the nature of a specialist service, would need to be specifically listed in Appendix A to be an exempt service.

It is a very long-winded way of saying that the present rules say that, to spend more than $20,000, one really has to go to public tender. This whole operation was to circumvent the need to do that so that the person engaging this surveying firm could make a subjective analysis. My concern and that of my colleagues on the Public Accounts Committee is that the amendment to the Audit Act does not make this situation worse. It is government money we are spending and it is taxpayers' money we are spending. The total amount of money which is spent in procurement of goods and services every year is $8 billion and I reckon that is worthy of some particular scrutiny.

So the compromise to which the Government has agreed to require the new guidelines which are pursuant to the document, Proposals for Reform of the Commonwealth Government Purchasing Arising from Government Review under the Financial Management Improvement Program, will indeed require that the new guidelines be tabled and subject to disallowance. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Audit Amendment Bill. This is a Bill that the Auditor-General would like through the Parliament as quickly as possible so, if I may make a request of the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), I have a few concerns about the amendments that have been put forward to clause 26. I seek an assurance that the guidelines that are to be issued by a Minister pursuant to regulations made under the proposed new section that shall be tabled in the Parliament and may be disallowed by either House will be subject to the Regulations and Ordinances Committee's scrutiny because, if that review were lost I would have difficulty in supporting the particular amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not a regulation as such but it is similar to a regulation, and I think we need an assurance before the passage of this Bill that that second amendment to clause 26 will come within the ambit of the Senate Committee on Regulations and Ordinances review. If that is the case, I will be quite happy.

The second request of the Minister is that the Government proceed expeditiously to implement the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in report No. 296, The Reform of the Australian Audit Office, because again we are seeing a bandaid treatment here. I seek the permission of the Minister to incorporate in Hansard some comments that I have in relation to the Audit Office and the Audit Amendment Bill and the need for two separate Acts. I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate those comments.
Leave granted.
The comments read as follows-
Audit Amendment Bill
The Senate is debating the Audit Amendment Bill which seeks to make various changes to auditing of Commonwealth bodies and to enhance the powers of the Commonwealth Auditor-General.

The amendments to the Audit Act are essentially to, first, define the role and condition of the Australian Audit Office, and to improve its efficiency; and, secondly, to consider the proper role of the Auditor-General and the accountability of government departments and agencies of the Parliament.

The Australian Audit Act is a very old statute dating back to 1901. In fact, the importance of the correct oversight of the public account is indicated by the fact that the Audit Act was the fourth piece of legislation passed by the new Federal Parliament.

Not only have accounting practices, principles, and statutes changed, but the role of the Commonwealth has significantly grown with a proliferation of statutory corporations, utilities, companies and other organisations coming under the public umbrella.
Most modern statutes covering these activities are in two separate Acts of Parliament-an Audit Act and a Financial Administration Act.
So it is surprising to discover in this Bill before the Senate that the Audit Amendments contain both administration and audit changes.
I therefore support the second reading amendment of the coalition, which states:

. . . in view of the archaic nature of the existing Audit Act, consideration be given to repealing it with two separate Acts, one relating to financial administration, the other to the activities of the Australian Audit Office.

Such an issue has become even more relevant because of the tabling during the last few weeks of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts report entitled-The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament-Reform of the Australian Audit Office.

Indeed, reform is well overdue because in recent years we have witnessed a proliferation of `Band Aid Amendments' to meet pressing necessity. In a world of rapid administrative change and the creation of new financial instruments on almost a daily basis, a new flexible Act to meet the needs of the next century is well overdue.

The coalition has realised this and that is why we are putting forward our second reading amendment. I hope that this might press the Government to act. It should, as a matter of priority, adopt the key recommendations in the Public Accounts Committee report on the Australian Audit Office.

I am pleased that the Government agreed to delay passage of this Bill until the Public Accounts Committee was tabled in each House and I hope that Cabinet will take serious note of our recommendations-especially in regard to a wholly revamped Audit Act and a new Financial Administration Act.

While I have been actively involved in the preparation of the Audit efficiency report, there are nevertheless still areas of concern which need to be addressed and these lie principally in the area of Financial Administration and activities relating to the Australian Audit Office.
I would like to refer to individual clauses in this Amendment Bill.
Clause 4

The amendment to section 21 of the Act which deals with the maintenance of bank accounts bearing the designation Commonwealth Public Account provides some flexibility with the addition of the words `agreements made under section 20' in that the Minister may agree with any bank for the conducting of business in respect of the Commonwealth Public Account.
The Drawing of Money from the Commonwealth Public Account
Clause 4 amends section 31 of the principal Act and provides that no money should be drawn from the Commonwealth Public Account except in the manner provided by this Act.

There has been some doubt in the mind of the Auditor-General arising from the overlap in the wording between sections 20 and 21 dealing with the conducting of banking business and the Commonwealth Public Account. The clause effectively clarifies the position of section 21 to make sure that bank accounts opened under that section are in accordance with agreements entered into under section 20.

Under proposed clause 7, the Minister for Finance may direct that all of the moneys appropriated for the performance of a particular function by a Commonwealth department may be transferred to another department to use in the same function area. With the proposed amendments the Minister is in a position to manage the funds as required.

I am pleased that such a change might lead to better accountability to Parliament of the expenditure of public money. However, my concern is with the interpretation of this clause and I seek a clarification from the Minister in charge of the specific effect clause 7 would have.
In clause 14, which repeals section 54 of the principal Act, some explanation is given of the difference between performance, efficiency and project performance audits.

It is, of course, essential for audits to be performed in order to scrutinise for inefficiencies in administration and thus improve management practices as in efficiency audits. It is also important to promote efficient use of resources on a large scale or small scale as in project performance audits. The question must still be posed: who is to perform these tasks due to the high numbers of people with proven auditing skills who are leaving the public service for the private sector?

Furthermore, are these tasks then to be tendered out to the private sector and, if so, are the auditing procedures compatible with the procedures already used, an improvement on the standard form of government auditing?
Who is to be ultimately responsible for the functioning of the department and for the carrying out of recommended improvements, Minister?

I know from personal discussions with senior personnel in the Australian Audit Office and accountants in private enterprise that the Audit Office is having a great deal of trouble keeping its staff and recruiting new graduates. Honourable senators will know that international accounting firms snap up the cream of new economics and commerce graduates because they can offer lucrative salary and benefits packages, which the Government Audit Office cannot.

This is a problem not only confined to the Commonwealth Auditor-General, but also is experienced by his state counterparts and by recruitment people in the Department of Finance, the Treasury and the Tax Office.
I suggest that the answer to attracting and keeping good staff is to review the conditions of work and the salaries and other benefits offered.
The Opposition believes it is vital that taxpayers' money is not only spent wisely and on worthwhile projects, but also that it is spent properly and efficiently.

Clause 6, in adding the words `shall not knowingly or recklessly cause or permit', softens the previous position which stated that `an officer shall not cause or permit the account to be paid except in accordance with section 34 1(b) and subsequent provision?'

Proposed clause 24 of the Bill deals with guidelines by Ministers and the proposal for an inclusion of a new section in the Act which will enable the regulations to authorise a Minister to issue guidelines on any matters for which that Minister is responsible (provided they are matters on which regulations may be given).
My colleague the honourable member for Dundas in the other place on 3 May asked: does this mean the Minister will issue the guidelines and, if so, where is the role of Parliament?

Anyone reading the Audit Act 1901 will know that accountability was at the forefront of the minds of our first legislative framers. If one turns to the recent report of the PAC, the same principle remains paramount. I am most concerned that the only time that Parliament will have a role is when the regulations are made to give the Minister power to make guidelines.
We ought not to be abrogating further the diminishing accountability of this Parliament and bolstering the already dominant executive.
I therefore ask the Minister in charge, is there to be no accountability between the Minister and Parliament?

The Joint Committee of Public Accounts recently reprimanded more than half the secretaries of Commonwealth Government Departments for breaching clear guidelines in the preparation of their annual reports.
Departmental secretaries are required to publish in their annual reports the actions they have taken in response to administrative issues raised by the Auditor-General or parliamentary committees.

In the light of clause 24, how are we as a Parliament supposed to respond to this survey which shows that half of the departmental secretaries have contempt for the guidelines laid down by the Prime Minister?

It would appear that managers are not accepting responsibility for their departments. Recent revelations about the employment of consultants give further weight to the diminished level of accountability that is being tacitly accepted.
The second amendment deals with the role of the Auditor-General, and whether he is to remain the key link in the chain from government enterprises and agencies to the Parliament.
Clause 21, audit of subsidiaries, is extrinsically involved in the projected future role of the Auditor-General.

It is argued that where the Government has an interest in an entity the Australian Audit Office should have a central role. An impression is given of an attempt to retain the mandate of the Auditor-General by the inclusion of 70bb. However, on closer examination the role of the Auditor-General is becoming increasingly redundant. This assumption may have been made by inserting the proposed new section 70bb. The role of the Auditor-General to report on financial statements and inspection of audits of the accounts and records of subsidiaries would in fact be tightened and reinforced.

Furthermore, it is to be mandatory for subsidiaries to be audited as well as the parent company. The proposed section is to apply to subsidiaries acquired after the commencement of the section but does not disturb any present arrangements for the Auditor-General to audit and report on `relevant' subsidiaries or authorities. This means that a subsidiary cannot unilaterally dismiss the Auditor-General.

How is the last statement to be understood, as when subsidiaries become corporations, incorporated under the Companies Act 1981, the need for the Auditor-General will not be crucial in relation to its operations, as the corporation will no longer be subject to any review by the Auditor-General?

A corporation, for instance the Snowy Mountain Engineering Corporation, since becoming a public company accountable to its shareholders, will put its auditing to tender and a private sector auditor will be used, and the audit will be conducted according to the relevant companies legislation. The company code sets out the necessary requirements for the appointment of auditors and the form and content of reports to shareholders.
Where does this then leave the role of the Auditor-General? Quite clearly the Auditor-General's role will be excluded, not enhanced.
It has been envisaged that the Auditor-General will nevertheless carry out both the Audit Act and company legislation requirements concurrently. How will this be so?

In normal circumstances, it is not expected that an auditor other than the Auditor-General would be appointed to report under the companies legislation. In a sense, in this provision the Auditor-General is seeking to restrict access to outside auditors in relation to subsidiaries that are established in the future.
Considering that, as I have already said, the number of auditors in the government services is dwindling, who then is to assist the Auditor-General to carry out the important task of audits?

In addition, since there appears to be an increase in the numbers of subsidiaries, statutory bodies and agencies run at arms length to Government departments it will be near to impossible for an audit to be carried out on many of these bodies due to the fact there is not enough personnel to complete the necessary tasks.
The issue is one of the instrumental elements of the Public Accounts Committee report that will require attention from the Minister and the Government.

This is a major difficulty that will have to be addressed-converting what are in effect standard private sector audit and accounting techniques in a way that would prove useful to meeting the requirements of Parliament and the issue of accountability of public money.
In the other place, the shadow Treasurer, Dr Hewson, quoted Professor Bob Walker writing in New Accountant. The quote is very apposite and worth repeating here in the Senate:

The interest of Parliament and the normal checks and balance that might be appropriate in the private sector may prove to be insufficient when one is auditing government expenditure or funds allocated through government. When taxpayers funds are involved, the form of accountability to Parliament could be quite different . . . it cautions the profession on the extent to which it has rushed into the idea of public sector auditing . . . little concerns seem to be given to insulating an auditor from pressure.
One wonders whether the Auditor-General is to have a role as a `watch-dog' over any private sector auditors involved.
The role of the Auditor-General is further examined in clause 22, indemnity insurance of Auditor-General.
This raises the question of whether the Auditor-General should be required to take an indemnity insurance so that he is put on an equal footing when competing with private sector auditors.

The amendment is based on legal advice that such indemnity is appropriate although it seems that at present there are no specific circumstances that necessitate this amendment. Actions taken for damages against Auditor-General counterparts overseas have occurred.
The independent status of the Auditor-General calls for a suitable indemnity provision in the legislation such as now proposed.

Regretfully, this provision is thought necessary because of what has happened in other countries where government auditors have been sued in civil action and so it is right and necessary that our own Auditor-General and his staff are indemnified against such a liability when carrying out their statutory tasks.

I would be very grateful if the Minister could answer the many questions that I have posed on particular clauses of this Audit Amendment Bill. The coalition does not oppose the Bill but I fervently hope it is the last such piece of legislation we ever see in this place.

If the recommendations of the PAC report to write wholly new audit and financial administration Acts is adopted by the Government, we will leave these band aid Bills which really only prop up a `horse and buggy' principal Act and bring Australian audit legislation into the modern era.
In closing my remarks I support the second reading amendment moved by the Opposition and look forward to the Minister's responses to my questions.
