As Senator Powell would know after debate in this place yesterday, both the adequacy of these payments and the way that they interlock into a whole range of considerations that we debated yesterday are being given consideration by this Government, not only in response to the Burdekin report but also in response to a working group report presented to the State and Federal welfare Ministers yesterday. At the end of the day we on this side of the chamber have a comprehensive wholesale policy assessment which has been going on for quite a period. Just to stress the point, I think I should repeat one of the points I made yesterday. In 1986 Senator Powell recommended that we should simply index family payments. There was no attempt at that stage to examine their structure or attempt to develop a broader and more comprehensive outlook in terms of family packages. If we had taken that advice-and I will close on this point-and simply indexed payments in 1986, child payments would have been $26.34 a week to- day. Under our Government they now stand at $43.10 for older children and $33 for younger children. As I said at the start of my answer, not only Senator Powell but some other honourable senators should not come into this place with questions born out of that sort of cynical hypocrisy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister's knowledge of arithmetic sufficient to acknowledge that, indeed, seven people in this place cannot carry anything without the support of one or other of the main major parties? Secondly, does he further acknowledge that quarterly indexation is and has been a matter of policy in all of these areas and that the only reason that a hypocritical stance is taken by the chamber as a whole with regard to welfare payments as compared with payments to political parties is a matter of arithmetic and not a matter of hypocrisy on the part of the Australian Democrats?
—Order! The first part of the question is not a supplementary.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have canvassed the serious parts of the second part of the question. In respect to the other more general parts of the question, I think we on this side of the Parliament and those on the other understand that seven cannot carry the Parliament, but we are bemused continually about election promises that the Australian Democrats always will.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It is relevant to concerns in the community about the extent of foreign ownership of land. Is it a fact that a wholly foreign owned company can acquire control of another foreign company which owns Australian real estate without any payment of Australian stamp duty? Is it also a fact that if an Australian company or individual were to take over an overseas holding company which controls property in Australia through its local subsidiaries, the transfer of ownership would attract stamp duty of up to 5.5 per cent? Does this mean-and I think it does-that, where Australian land is owned by a foreign company, it will be cheaper for another foreign company to acquire the land by acquiring the shares of that foreign company than it would be for an Australian individual or company to acquire the land in the same or any other way-in other words, that there is a cost disadvantage to an Australian purchaser in those circumstances? Does the Minister agree that this poses a considerable disadvantage to Australians wishing to repurchase Australian real estate at a time when there is considerable community concern about the growing level of overseas ownership in this area? Will the Minister examine this matter and see what can be done to provide at least a level playing field for those Australians who are trying to buy back the farm?
—There are several questions there. I am afraid I do not know the answers to any of them, but I will get answers.
—Indeed, they cover State jurisdictions.

—Yes, I was going to say that. If, however, the facts are as Senator Chaney clearly assumes in the question, I will certainly ask the Treasurer to examine the matter. If stamp duty is the major problem, obviously it is not all that easy for the Commonwealth Government to do anything about it, other than to recompense the States for revenue not otherwise collected, unless-and this is probably unlikely to happen quickly-the States collectively agree to take some action.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I refer to reports that the Chilean dissident Mr Sergio Buschmann, who was deported last Sunday from Australia, has been detained by United States authorities in Alaska. Can the Minister advise the Senate on the accuracy of these reports and can he inform us whether Mr Buschmann was offered a choice of flights out of Australia before his eventual departure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Buschmann was deported on Sunday, 11 June, after he had appealed unsuccessfully to the Federal Court of Australia. The reasons for Mr Buschmann's deportation were to do with false statements on his visa application and not activities in which he is alleged to have engaged in Chile. Prior to Mr Buschmann's deportation action being commenced, he and his supporters were counselled that the best course of action for him would be to depart voluntarily. He did not accept that counselling. As Mr Buschmann, in discussions about the manner of his deportation, had expressed concerns about his personal safety, he was offered a choice of flights back to Sweden. He decided to return to Sweden via Tokyo and Amsterdam. We have now received advice that that flight landed at Anchorage and that Mr Buschmann and his Australian resident travelling companion were detained by US authorities. At this point of time it is unclear on what basis they were detained. The Government has instructed our embassy in Washington to raise these matters with the United States Administration. The Government had made representations to the US at senior levels expressing the view that the Australian deportation of Buschmann, taken after legal proceedings in Australian courts, should not be interfered with and that he should be allowed to continue his journey to Sweden, where he has resident status.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the Minister seen reports today that Mr Buschmann was actually travelling on a Qantas Airways flight that landed in Anchorage? If so, can the Minister inform the Senate about the accuracy of those reports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been a number of inaccurate reports about Mr Buschmann's stay here and his departure. I can inform Senator McKiernan that if, indeed, Mr Buschmann landed in Anchorage on a Qantas flight, it was a rare Qantas flight indeed. As far as I know, he landed in Anchorage on the scheduled flight of Japan Air Lines. That is just another distortion that has appeared in this saga.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does he agree with one of the principal conclusions of the report of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) on non-tax charges that the Government's administrative reforms of various government business enterprises to date do not address what, in the Commission's view, is `the single most important factor underlying inefficiency in public enterprises' and that is `the absence of effective competition'? When will the Government discard its practice of making only minor changes to the regulatory environment of public enterprises, especially in telecommunications, rather than commit itself to wholesale and effective competition to increase efficiency and competitiveness as proposed by the IAC? Further, what does the Government propose to do in the light of the conclusion of the report that `the wide-ranging concerns expressed by industry to the inquiry suggest that it would be appropriate for government to consider instigating a separate inquiry, or program of inquiries, on aspects of regulation compliance costs'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer the last part of the question to the Treasurer. I have not seen the IAC report and, therefore, I am not very well placed to make comments about its recommendations. I noted Senator Messner's reference to the absence of effective competition in publicly owned business enterprises. Prima facie, that must be taken to be correct. There is, however, a problem with organisations, be they publicly owned or not, which have elements of natural monopoly in them. It is a difficult problem to deal with. I do not think there are any unequivocally correct or incorrect answers to it.

ANSWER.PARA: I noted also Senator Messner's special reference to telecommunications and to the problem of monopolies and, therefore, the absence of effective competition. If that is the view of the Opposition, I look forward to the Opposition when it completes its policies producing its policy for the fragmentation of Telecom Australia or alternatively for the ending of Telecom's monopoly and, therefore, of the geographic cross-subsidies which are dependent upon Telecom maintaining its monopoly.

TALK.START.PARA: —We gave you all the amendments last week-57 of them.

—I am aware that a list of enterprises, which the Opposition said it would sell off if it became the Government, was published some months ago. I am also particularly aware of the fact that Telecom is not on it because the National Party of Australia will not let the Opposition do so and because the National Party still calls the shots in the coalition as it always has.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It relates to an earlier question I asked the Minister on 31 May concerning the future-particularly bleak, I understand-of north Queensland crocodiles. Can the Minister confirm the alarming reports in today's press that the Queensland State Cabinet has again placed the threatened north Queensland crocodile on its most wanted list?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been difficult over the years to come up with reasons for supporting the Queensland Minister for the Environment, Conservation and Forestry, Mr Muntz. But I have to acknowledge that in the last few weeks, for one brief shining moment, a ray of light appeared. Mr Muntz showed some concern for Queensland crocodiles and had moved towards banning the slaughter of those crocodiles that has been going on over the last couple of years. I and, I am sure, many other senators, were delighted with that report. But it is sad that I now have to report to the Senate that what Senator Collins has read is true.

ANSWER.PARA: The real environmental disaster men-they are usually all men-of the National Party of Australia have won again. The absolute worst of them-it is not Senator Boswell by the way; a lot of people think that he is the absolute worst of them but he is not--

TALK.START.PARA: —No!

—I have to be fair, Senator Button. He is perhaps a close second. But it is a Mr Martin Tenni. Mr Martin Tenni has apparently won again. He has delivered the coup de grace, if you like, to whatever crocodiles may be left in north Queensland. Tourist operators, of course, are screaming because they cannot find any any more. It merely confirms what too many of us have suspected for too long, and that is, Bjelke-Petersen may have gone but absolutely nothing has changed in Queensland.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Is the Minister aware that in June two years ago, just before the 1987 Federal election, in what could be politely described as coincidental circumstances, the Imam of the Lakemba Mosque, Sheikh Al Hilaly, was granted temporary residence for two years? Had the Imam been an illegal immigrant to Australia? Has the Imam strongly criticised both Christian and Jewish groups in Australia in a manner widely considered inflammatory, discriminatory and disturbing to cohesion in the Australian community? Will the Minister be renewing the Imam's visa or will it be terminated this month when there is apparently no election imminent? In either event will he do so before the Senate rises so that the Parliament, as is its right, can examine his decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that there has been considerable controversy going back for some time over the Imam. That has been well reported. I recall that there was an extension granted to the Imam, although I cannot recall exactly when it was or whether it was just before the last election. In any event, given that I was told about the election when I was in a hotel in Dublin, it was hardly a planned election. I, therefore, dispute that anything was done at the time to get it over with before the election. We all believed that there was very much more time available than before an election.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as what is planned for the Imam and what the Minister intends to do, I shall make inquiries of the Minister and inform Senator Baume as soon as I can.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As the decision, I understand, has to be made this month and as I drew this prospect of my asking a question to the attention of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, is the Minister representing him telling the chamber that he has received no advice whatsoever on this matter despite the prior warning? Will he give an undertaking that if any action is to be taken it will be done before the Parliament rises?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only give Senator Baume an undertaking that I will make an immediate inquiry as to when the decision is likely to be taken. I cannot promise that the decision will be taken before the Senate rises. But given the progress the Senate is making at the moment it may well finish up being possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. When will the boundaries of the euphemistically named conservation zone in stage 3 of Kakadu National Park, which is a zone set aside for mining, be determined? What is the period of exploration and how many mining companies hold leases within the zone and will be likely to explore and/or mine during this period? What is the Minister's position on the protection of sacred sites in the area? And, finally, is the Minister aware of the erosion which has arisen from the exploration activities at the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) gold mining site at Coronation Hill, in particular, along the access road to the old workings and the effect this has had on the nearby streams and the surrounding environment? Will the Government require the company to carry out restoration work on the area?
—Another movement to the right, is it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear the interjection so I cannot respond to it. I cannot give Senator Dunn a date as to when the decision will be made. Like many others, I would have thought that the decision would have been made by now. But difficulties have arisen, in particular with Aboriginal sacred sites, which is something to which Senator Dunn has referred in her question. My understanding is that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, had discussions with the Northern Territory Government in an attempt to resolve those difficulties. I shall ask him, as a result of Senator Dunn's question, what progress he has been making. I am not aware of a date having been set for this decision to be made by Cabinet. So I cannot enlighten Senator Dunn exactly, except to say that I hope it is soon.

ANSWER.PARA: There are three companies which have pre-existing mineral leases or mineral lease applications. BHP Gold Mines Ltd has 29 mineral leases, BHP Minerals Ltd has 37 minerals lease applications and Destiny Prospecting Pty Ltd holds three mineral leases. The date for commencement of a period of five years, which was proposed as an exploration period, has not been set. But I assume that that will be part of the decision that the Government will make in the very near future.

I am aware of some erosion problems on the site at Coronation Hill and on the access road. In fact, I had discussions only a few weeks ago with representatives of BHP on this matter. I have organised to meet with them on site during July to take those discussions further. I point out that whatever sediment has escaped from Coronation Hill into the surrounding environment would be a pretty small percentage of the total sediment load that is expected in those streams during the wet season. It is a matter of concern if mining is to proceed. I have raised the matter and I intend to pursue it further. In terms of the environmental conditions that apply, obviously the Government would require rehabilitation of what work has occurred at Coronation Hill in the event of a decision not to allow mining to proceed, but if a decision is taken to allow it to proceed, clearly the Commonwealth will demand a full rehabilitation of the site at the end of its mining life.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Justice. I refer to his announcement on 9 June that Mr Pat Dodson, the current Deputy Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and the current Director of the Central Land Council, has been appointed to a third public office as a royal commissioner to examine the underlying causes of Aboriginal deaths in custody. As other royal commissioners are being paid between $100,000 and $300,000 per annum each, what remuneration will be paid to Mr Dodson and on what basis was the remuneration determined for each of his three government jobs? Will other staff and counsel assisting be appointed with the usual salaries in excess of $200,000 per annum each? How will Mr Dodson divide his time between these jobs and avoid conflicts of interest?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Pat Dodson has been appointed as an additional commissioner to inquire into Aboriginal deaths in custody. I believe that that distinguished Australian will bring much to the Royal Commission on Aboriginal Deaths in Custody particularly as it examines the underlying issues relating to deaths in custody that have occurred in Western Australia. Indeed, his appointment follows agreement between the Western Australian Government and the Federal Government to make that appointment. Before I answer the more technical parts of Senator Tambling's question, I say that I am delighted that Mr Dodson has been able to accept this appointment. It will be at the expense of his giving up some of those tasks and appointments which he presently holds. I will detail those in a moment.

ANSWER.PARA: As a full-time royal commissioner, Mr Dodson will be paid an annual salary of $100,924 as determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. Whilst I do not have the report in front of me, I recollect that Senate Estimates Committee E recommended that in the case of royal commissioners-and I think it had in mind royal commissioners in relation to the Aboriginal deaths in custody inquiry-remuneration ought to be determined by the Tribunal. That is what has been done in this particular case. Senator Tambling should know that as Deputy Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission Mr Dodson is not and has not ever been paid any remuneration. However, when attending commission meetings Mr Dodson's air fares and expenses are met. Mr Dodson has informed the ADC Board of his retirement on 30 June 1989. So he will be retiring at the end of this financial year. Mr Dodson had set an original retirement date, when we were talking with him earlier, of 31 July 1989 as Director of the Central Land Council. On 28 June at a full meeting of the Central Land Council Mr Dodson will formally advise of his appointment to the Royal Commission and will retire from that position on 8 July 1989. As Director of the Central Land Council Mr Dodson is paid a salary which is equivalent to the senior executive service level 1 of the Australian Public Service plus a district allowance.

From the date of his appointment as a royal commissioner-that is from 1 July 1989 until 31 July 1989-Mr Dodson will be a part-time royal commissioner and will commence full time from 1 August 1989. It is not unusual for part-time royal commissioners to be appointed. During that period he will get a daily sitting fee related only to performing duties as a royal commissioner on those days.

As to other staff, I do not think that has been finally determined. Pat Dodson, I think, was to retire in any case from his position on the Central Land Council to return to Broome where I think he is the senior member of his tribe. I forget the exact title one gives to a senior member of the Yaoro Aboriginal tribe. He will be returning to Broome, which will be his headquarters for the conduct of this inquiry in Western Australia. The staff assistance support he will have has not yet been determined.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. My question relates to the latter point that the Minister referred to, that of the staff or counsel assisting Commissioner Dodson. In light of the fact that Mr Dodson does not have formal legal qualifications himself, is it anticipated that he will need to appoint special legal counsel to assist him? What special qualifications does the Government consider Mr Dodson has which will equip him to adjudicate fairly on the evidence which he may be expected to receive sitting as a commissioner in relation to the so-called underlying causes of Aboriginal deaths in custody? Were Aboriginal people consulted prior to Mr Dodson's appointment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling reveals his bias in asking this question by talking of the so-called underlying causes. I do not think there can be any doubt in the minds and hearts of all honourable senators that there are indeed underlying causes for the deaths in custody which have occurred. It has been revealed in some of the reports that have already been put down by the existing commissioners and the retiring national Royal Commissioner. There are underlying causes relating to the deaths in custody of Aboriginal persons, as there would be for the deaths in custody of non-Aboriginal Australians. Honourable senators will be aware, for example, that the death rate of Aboriginals in custody has been shown by a royal commission examination of statistics to be about the same as those for non-Aboriginal deaths in custody. That is why in the statement made by the new national Commissioner Johnson and by me a month or so ago in relation to the refocusing of the Royal Commission much was made of the need to concentrate on the incarceration rate, the detention rate, of Aboriginals which is way beyond that experienced by the non-Aboriginal population of Australia. If one is an Aboriginal, one is 20 times more likely to find oneself detained in some form of custody than if one is a non-Aboriginal Australian. That is one of the underlying matters which have to be addressed. So there are true underlying matters that have to be looked at.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe Mr Dodson brings an experience, a capacity, and an understanding, which is, nevertheless, not of a biased character, to this inquiry. He will come, as I said, with an experience which is not available to other members of the Royal Commission. I believe, as does the Premier of Western Australia, who has not been uncritical of the conduct of this Commission, that he will bring to its deliberations a certain experience that I have no doubt will be extremely helpful in bringing to all Australians a worthwhile report at the conclusion of its studies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Resources seen a report in the Age this morning which gives the background to the oil dispute in Bass Strait? Will the Minister inform the Senate of the Government's view of this dispute and, in particular, its claims that it exposes Australia's vulnerability to declining production and supply?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to express a view on the dispute other than to say that the disputing parties should, as expeditiously as possible, settle their differences so that production can recommence normally in Bass Strait. I do not think it is appropriate for me to express a view about the rights and wrongs internal to the dispute other than to say that the processes of dispute settlement should be followed and that the dispute should be settled as rapidly as possible because it affects the strategic supply of petroleum to Australia. About six out of 10 motor vehicles are fuelled by oil that comes from Bass Strait.

ANSWER.PARA: The article which appeared in this morning's Age and which was referred to by Senator Beahan goes much further than talking about our reliance on the Bass Strait oil production and what the effects would be were Bass Strait to be shut down. It is an article which quotes extensively the Chief Executive of Esso Australia, Dr John Schubert. Once again we get a rerun of the old argument that the level of taxation imposed in the form of excise on the production of crude oil out of Bass Strait is somehow negatively affecting the exploration effort in Australia to find more oil and to meet our needs into the next century. It is an old and tired argument, an argument that is trotted out on every occasion. It is an exploitation of the industrial relations situation to use an industrial dispute to give that argument a further run. As I have said many times, the exploration effort in Australia is determined by three things. The first is: what are our prospects of finding oil? The second is: what is the price of oil on the world market? The third is: what are the costs of extraction including the costs of tax?

The best gauge of prospectivity is the number of wells that are drilled in the search for oil around Australia and the level of exploration, off-shore in particular. Notably on the North West Shelf and in the Timor Sea there is a very high level indeed. It is comparable with past years. Certainly, in terms of prospectivity, an effort is being made to find more oil. Whether it is there is another matter, but certainly the effort is going into finding more oil. In terms of prospectivity, the Government expects, by the end of this year, to have completed negotiations with the Indonesian Government about a zone of cooperation in the Timor Sea. That zone is held to be highly prospective. When we do that, we expect exploration and, hopefully, oil strikes in that area.

In terms of the international price of oil, the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries has been meeting over the last week. It has agreed to put more production onstream and thus one would expect that the price of oil would fall a little. Indeed, it has gone down one or two points. The price of a barrel of oil on the world market, if one takes all of the spot market indicators, seems to be firming between around $18 and $22. I think that is a sufficient incentive for further exploration effort. This Government has indicated also that we will be reviewing the excise arrangements on Bass Strait. That review is now under way. I expect that review to be completed and any legislative change that may arise from the completion of the review to be in place to operate from 1 July next year.

I conclude by tabling two documents. The first is the Australian Bureau of Statistics petroleum exploration expenditure for 1981-82 to 1988, the source of which is the actual and expected mineral exploration in Australia in December 1988. The second derives from the financial accounts of Esso Australia. The summary of these two tables is that the amount being spent is lower now than it was in 1981-82, but it is still a very healthy $495m per annum in terms of exploration. The profits going to Esso which have been returned as dividends to shareholders and not spent in exploration have increased dramatically. In fact, in 1988 the net profits after tax and profits in the hands of shareholders were $368m. It is clear on this point that a healthy profit is being made out of Bass Strait production. If Esso is true to the point that it needs incentives for more exploration, it can divert some of its profit to searching for more oil; there is no need for a reduction in the excise rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. I note that tenders have been called for the new coastwatch contract. Will the Minister give the Senate the precise details as to how those tenders will be assessed so that the Government does not get into the enormous mess it got into when either intentionally or unintentionally it broke every rule in the book on assessing the tenders?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE

TALK.START.PARA: —The question contains what is called a non sequitur. It suggests that, if the Government gave all the details of the tender arrangements to the Senate, it would not get in a mess. I am not sure that that is correct.
—We want to know what you have done to stop it.

—That was what he said. If Senator Chaney does not mind, I do not want his interpretation of what he said; that is what he said. I will see what information can be provided and, if the Minister is agreeable, I will provide it to the Senate.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. To make it more specific for the Minister: Will he detail changes that the Government has made in the assessment program so that it does not get into the mess it got into last time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen a report in the Australian Financial Review of Wednesday, 7 June, headlined `Defensive ESOPS: Bad news'? I ask whether that report indicated that in the United States:

QUESTION.PARA: Employee share ownership plans that help management ward off hostile takeovers immediately depress a company's stock price by an average of 5.1 per cent . . .
Does the Minister have any information indicating that this is true in Australia also?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen that report in the 7 June issue of the Financial Review. It is a study conducted by a Harvard academic and a Massachusetts consultant. It examined 21 recent defensive ESOPs-that is, employee share ownership plans. According to the Financial Review report, they arrived at the conclusion mentioned by Senator Crowley, that is, that they depress share prices by an average of just over 5 per cent. I am not aware of any similar broad ranging studies having been conducted in Australia. There are a number of facts which suggest that the position is similar.

ANSWER.PARA: For example, Mr Elliott has been engaged in recent manoeuvres to try to consolidate control of Harlin Pty Ltd over Elders-IXL Ltd. In the Australian of 8 June, Richard Gluyas-I am not sure how that name is pronounced; a wheat variety was once named that after the farmer who had selected it in South Australia-reported Mr Elliott's explanation of these manoeuvres:
Concern has also been expressed that Harlin has effectively taken over Elders without a formal takeover offer . . .
He went on:
But Mr Elliott rejects this interpretation saying people are `missing the point' of Harlin.
Harlin has two purposes . . . It serves as an executive incentive scheme and quite a good one at that, for certain Elders executives, and as a protection against the partial takeover of Elders.

I repeat: `as a protection against the partial takeover of Elders'. In other words, Mr Elliott was stating that Harlin is the vehicle for a defensive ESOP. The difference from a normal ESOP is that Mr Elliott and a few of his executives get to enjoy the benefits of participation at the expense of all the other shareholders, as I have pointed out before. Finally, it should be noted that, in the four weeks since Mr Elliott announced this latest manoeuvre, the price of Elders shares has fallen by 7 per cent, although not too much weight should necessarily be attached to that, because there has been a fall in share prices in general.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters aware of a 1987 decision of the Federal Court affecting superannuation entitlements of some 80,000 public servants who joined the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund between 1976 and 1979? In view of the decision of the Federal Court that the Commissioner for Superannuation was not obliged to determine the health of any entrant into the superannuation scheme between 1976 and 1979 at either the time of entry into the scheme or within a reasonable time and, further, that he, the Commissioner, can make an adverse finding as to the health of a superannuee at the time of his or her entry into the fund after that person has retired and in the light of the fact that the Commissioner is making such determinations, will the Minister advise whether the Government intends to take any action to remedy this situation and relieve the anxiety present employees have concerning retrospective health determinations by the Commissioner for Superannuation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the Federal Court decision to which Senator Bishop refers. Therefore, I am also unaware of everything that flows from that decision. But I will seek to obtain an answer as soon as possible.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to the High Court's ruling that the Commonwealth and not the States had jurisdiction over the territorial seas below the low water mark. On that occasion the Federal Court granted control of that portion of the sea out to the three-mile zone to the separate States. What form did the hand-over take? Was it legislated or merely by agreement? Did the hand-over refer to the seabed only and not to the water above the seabed? For either or both of these reasons is the Commonwealth not fully able to legislate to protect the marine environment anywhere below the low water mark, for example, to control sewage discharged to the sea from metropolitan Sydney? I am referring to the water, of course, and not to the seabed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have traversed some of this ground-or water-with Senator Coulter before. The hand-over of powers to which Senator Coulter refers was both by legislation and by agreement. At the June 1979 Premiers Conference the Commonwealth and the States developed a constitutional agreement regarding the three-mile zone which gave the States jurisdiction. There was an exchange of letters. I think I referred to that exchange of letters when Senator Coulter last asked a similar question. In addition, the Fraser Government introduced the Coastal Waters (State Title) Act 1980 and the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980 which gave power to the States over those territorial waters. It further amended the Seas and Submerged Lands Act to ensure that there was conformity with existing laws. This legislation vested in each State proprietary rights and title in respect of the seabed of the adjacent territorial sea. However, the Commonwealth legislation reserves the Commonwealth's right to use the seabed for some national purposes such as defence, navigational aids, et cetera.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to Senator Coulter's second question is that the hand-over referred to both the seabed and the waters above the sea. In answer to his third question I inform him that, while it would be possible to overturn those agreements and the legislation that I have just referred to, the Commonwealth has no plans to do either. This Government has not been in the habit of abrogating agreements, particularly when they are of such constitutional importance as this one. I would be concerned about our doing so. Senator Coulter referred to the issue of Sydney sewage. He has certainly referred to that issue here before. I reaffirm what I said the last time, which is that we cannot use the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act as it stands to control that problem. I do not believe that we will achieve much by continually going over the same ground.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has recently said that he is seeking more powers with respect to control of the environment. The answer he has just given recognises that the Federal Government has those powers. Is he now saying that in seeking further powers with respect to the environment he will not be seeking any further powers with respect to the protection of the territorial seas, either within or outside the three-mile zone?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said that we will not achieve much by going over the same ground but I will make one brief comment on Senator Coulter's supplementary question. I have said that I believe that further down the track-quite deliberately I used a five-to-10-year time frame-it will be necessary for the Commonwealth to seek more powers via a referendum to deal with the enormous issues which the greenhouse phenomenon will present. I do not know now-I do not think anyone does-just what powers it will be necessary for the Commonwealth to seek, but I would much prefer the Commonwealth to seek environmental power of that kind rather than attempt to pinch powers one by one, particularly when it involves the abrogation of an agreement with the States.

—Can the Minister for Consumer Affairs explain to the Senate the importance of the announcement by the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) of an inquiry into petrol prices? Are the reported comments of the Shell company a fair assessment of that inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President--
—Yes.

—I will not say yes, as Senator Stone suggests. I will say that the Government has welcomed the inquiry for a number of reasons. It should be noted that, even though for five years or so the PSA has had a role in both monitoring and setting maximum wholesale prices in this industry, a public inquiry has not been held by the PSA since 1984. Since then there have been a number of changes in the industry. The industry has been deregulated and we have had new pricing regimes, new pricing policies and so on. Recently petrol prices have been volatile, which the Government has been sensitive to.

ANSWER.PARA: In welcoming the inquiry we have been sensitive to the fact that world crude oil and petrol prices have been rising. We are also cognisant of the fact that this country has the fourth lowest retail petrol prices of Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. A number of issues are very much to the forefront of the PSA's decision in this area. Those issues are well known to the Government. I, for instance, have had strenuous representations made to me from the honourable member for Grey, Lloyd O'Neil, and the honourable member for the Northern Territory, Warren Snowdon. They are concerned about the lack of adequate competition in the industry, especially among retail outlets in their two electorates. As a consequence the PSA will give due consideration to that aspect of pricing. I have also had representations from the oil companies. Given the changes over the last five years, they have asked the PSA to consider a more transparent pricing formula. These two aspects of concern to the community will be adequately addressed by the PSA.

What we are talking about is the first Prices Surveillance Authority inquiry into this industry for five years. The Government sees it as an opportune and timely inquiry which will give both consumers and industry a chance to look at and have a say in the national petrol pricing regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of reports that Aussat Pty Ltd could face an additional $100m penalty in launching costs for its second generation satellites as a result of the decision by the United States Department of State to withdraw permission to use the Chinese Long March rocket? Are these reports correct? If so, what are the prospects of Aussat's continued commercial viability in view of its already very high gearing ratio? Has the Australian Government made any representations to the United States authorities to obtain an exemption from the ban on the transfer to China of defence related technology? What would the Government's attitude be if, as reported, in the event of continued repression in China, Aussat decided to withdraw from the deal of its own volition?

—I do not know anything about the alleged losses which would result from certain circumstances which Senator Alston referred to in his question. I will get a response from Mr Willis on that. I am, however, advised that there is no urgency for immediate action, as Aussat has until June next year to nominate an alternative launch vehicle of its own choice. Aussat intends to monitor the situation. My response to the last part of the question regarding what the Government's reaction would be, again to a hypothetical situation, is that I do not know. I will see whether Mr Willis has any comment to make on the matter.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The fact is that Aussat has the ability to nominate an alternative supplier, but under the agreement with the Hughes Corporation it bears the financial burden. The cost of identifying a supplier for a rocket other than the Long March rocket would be of the order of an additional $100m. I ask the Minister to take that into account in seeking further instruction.
—I have already dealt with that, Mr President. I have said that I will seek Mr Willis's comments or confirmation.

—Does the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories agree that the relentless advance of the dreaded cane toad, Bufo marinus, towards Kakadu National Parks represents a major threat to the wetland ecosystem and that an all-out research effort is required to prevent the ruination of this and other potential World Heritage areas across northern Australia? What progress is being made by the cane toad control project, which was promised funding over a 10-year period by the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers starting in 1986, what is the current status of the 10-year funding commitment, will it be increased over the remainder of the research period, and what other research initiatives are being supported financially by the Commonwealth Government to control the cane toad invasion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The continued expansion of the range of habitat of the cane toad has caused concern not just to the Commonwealth but to the States for some years. I am told that cane toads have been sighted even near places such as Toowoomba, so there are problems. As far back as 1978 the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service instituted some research into the physiology and ecology of the cane toad and obviously, unless some suitable control measures are found, and found quickly, it will be not just Kakadu that will be in considerable danger.
—Senator Boswell has a control mechanism for you.

—It may be the case, Senator Alston, that Senator Boswell knows something about the cane toad. I would love to take that further, but I will not do so. In 1984 CONCOM, the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers from around Australia, looked at a cane toad management project and the Council funded that study which commenced in 1986. I think that the report is due at the end of this year and that some $400,000 has been spent on that research over the last few years. Hopefully, we will get a result at the end of this year which will take us somewhere towards trying to halt the advance of the cane toad. In any event, I will make sure that I inform the Senate when we receive that report. I am sure that the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers will anxiously want to take up its result.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Wednesday, 14 June, Senator Panizza asked me a question about the diesel fuel rebate scheme. I answered a portion of that question, but I am now able to provide a further answer. The questionnaire referred to by Senator Panizza is an important instrument often used in the auditing process. It is a simple and relatively short document to complete, and its main purpose is to gather the necessary additional information about a claimant's operations to assist the Australian Customs Service in the examination of claims. The answer is fairly technical and somewhat long, and will be of interest to Senator Panizza but perhaps not to other senators. I seek leave for the remainder of the answer to be incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The information read as follows-

Each claim is registered and entered in the Customs computer system on receipt. Claims which meet certain preset profiles are selected for further auditing. Claims may also be selected as a result of previous risk rating or even randomly. Generally speaking, only a relatively small proportion of claims is selected.

To enable a selected claim to be processed further, a questionnaire is forwarded to the claimant. Without the questionnaire being answered, it is not possible to complete the auditing process and to pay the rebate. The sooner a claimant returns the questionnaire, the sooner his claim is processed.

The Senator asked whether the questionnaire can be sent between claims thus preventing any delay in payment. I should point out that, unless a claim is lodged and selected for auditing, there is no reason to go to a claimant for further information. I should further point out that a selected claimant is asked to complete the questionnaire only once unless his operation has changed substantially.
The Government's objective is to pay a rebate claim within three weeks of receipt. Of course, claims which have been selected for auditing would take longer but no longer than absolutely necessary.

The Australian Customs Service has the duty to ensure payment of the correct amount of rebates. Accordingly, a claim cannot be paid unless the Customs Service is satisfied that it is eligible for rebate.

Senator Panizza also asked whether I can give him an estimate of the amount of diesel fuel rebate that is never claimed. The short answer is `no'. Only off road users falling within prescribed categories such as mining operations, primary production, residential premises etc. are eligible. It is up to users to decide whether they are eligible under the legislation. Therefore, if diesel users do not claim for whatever reason, the Customs Service would not know of their existence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to give additional information in relation to a question asked of me by Senator Newman involving the participation of servicewomen in Exercise Kangaroo 89. Approximately 2,000 servicewomen will take part in Kangaroo 89. The majority of women will be Regular Army members of the Army Logistics Support Force and Army Reserve. Army Reserve members of units will be employed on vital asset protection tasks and will be rotated every two weeks. Details of the specific positions occupied by women in each of these and other units are not readily available. It is not possible to determine how many of the positions to be occupied by women during Kangaroo 89 would not be available to women if Kangaroo 89 were a real contingency. An answer would depend on the specific threat involved. In addition, the honourable senator might note that women in the Defence Force are not employed in combat or combat-related roles. The definition of `combat-related roles' is at present under review, with a view to expanding the career opportunities for servicewomen.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that integrated field force units of the Army Reserve with a complement of 15 to 20 per cent women will be taking part in the exercise. It is not true that naval ships with female crew have been advised that they cannot deploy to Kangaroo 89 with the females in the crew. It follows from these answers that there will be no distinction in the opportunities for women from the Navy and the Army Reserve to participate in Kangaroo 89.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer to Senator Chaney's question yesterday concerning land releases for housing development. The Commonwealth is undertaking a program of land releases for housing development. Minister West's 7 June 1989 statement details the whole program and specifically refers to the proviso that environmental conditions shall be met.

ANSWER.PARA: This program is being developed in close consultation between officers of the Australian property group and my Department. The important point is that the Minister for Administrative Services and his Department have the primary responsibility for identifying environmental significance and ensuring that environmental factors are taken into account. Formal arrangements exist between our respective departments to trigger when appropriate the processes of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act and the Australian Heritage Commission Act.

In his most recent correspondence with the Premier of Western Australia, the Hon. Peter Dowding, on progress with the proposed land releases, Mr West stipulated that specific land releases would be conditional upon environmental issues being resolved. These processes are securely based on cooperation between Commonwealth and State authorities. I am informed that, with respect to the Bushmead land in the Helena Valley east of Perth, environmental investigations are well under way.

Vegetation and wildlife surveys are under way to establish the nature of any jarrah and redgum stands and of wildlife habitats. An ethnographic survey of potential sites is also under way. Once those surveys are completed the Minister for Administrative Services will assess whether the proposed release of land is environmentally significant. If he does, then the Australian Property Group would refer the disposal of the property to my Department for formal assessment under the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act.

The Commonwealth is clearly concerned that the environmental implications of this overall program will be properly considered. There are no doubt areas of potential environmental sensitivity. The extent to which the statutory processes for environmental impact assessment need to be applied will be determined in the circumstances of each proposed land release. I believe there are ample safeguards for taking all environmental factors into account before decisions are made.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I undertook to give Senator Boswell a further answer on some questions he raised concerning Christmas Island phosphate mining. The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Holding, met with Mr John Booth and the liquidator of the Phosphate Mining Corporation of Christmas Island, Mr Robert Yeomans, on 31 May 1989 to allow Mr Booth to clarify his concerns over the evaluation of proposals to recommence mining on Christmas Island. The meeting lasted some 2 1/2 hours. Mr Booth's principal concerns centred on a comparison of his and Elders' proposals with respect to royalties, tonnages, phosphate prices, research and development on C-grade phosphate products and rehabilitation conditions. He was also concerned with the post-tender negotiations with Elders.

ANSWER.PARA: Given the degree of detail in Mr Booth's oral submission, Mr Holding asked him to summarise his position in writing, which he has now done by way of a 17-page letter, received by facsimile at about 4 p.m. on Tuesday, 13 June 1989. Mr Holding has written to Mr Yeomans attaching a copy of Mr Booth's letter. Mr Holding's office has further contacted Mr Yeomans requesting him to report back on this matter as soon as possible, giving specific responses to the points raised. Mr Holding's office has written and faxed a letter to Mr Booth informing him of the above action. Given the detail in Mr Booth's latest correspondence, it will take some time to do justice to the issues. It should be remembered, Senator Boswell, that the response from Mr Booth was almost a week late.

While the Government believes the matter is now one for Mr Yeomans in the first instance, Mr Holding has nevertheless asked the Department also to undertake an analysis of the various issues. Once all this information is available I shall further inform the Senate. I will also keep Senator Boswell informed as matters unfold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer.

The statement from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) varies a little from his previous statement when he said that he would either come in here and demand an apology from me or he would apologise himself. This is a complete backoff. The Minister is now playing for time. I pointed out very clearly in my statement of 26 May that an assessment was given to a company that could have paid up to $5m less in royalty payments to the Commonwealth. The Minister then came in here and said that that was rubbish. He said that the particular firm was a bigger company and, therefore, should have got the contract. He said that the rehabilitation was better, so it should have got the contract. He ran through a whole series of reasons why the particular company should have got the contract. He comes in here today and says that he is not quite sure and needs another week.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is outrageous.

—Senator Richardson can give it but he has to take it also. He cannot be like the collie dog. He can give it, but he cannot take it. On 26 May, which is almost a month ago, I made very serious charges that the Commonwealth had given an assessment to mine Christmas Island to a company that could have paid up to $5m less in royalties. Today, Senator Richardson comes in here and has the audacity to say, `Well, we are not really quite sure whether we did make a mistake'. He came in here on 26 May like a raging lion and he is now like a puppy dog. He was going to demand an apology and have me grovelling. The boot is now on the other foot, because the Minister has not met his deadline. There is still a very serious cloud hanging over his Department.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Minister has misled, although not willingly, the Parliament on three or four occasions. I do not believe that it is the Minister's fault. He is being snowed by his Department. It has got him by the nose and is leading him around. He has played for time. The Minister knows that we are in the dying stages of this Parliament and that the Senate will rise tomorrow. The Minister has tried to bat out and play for time. I point out to him that there are a number of islanders waiting for some job opportunities to be created over on Christmas Island so that they can have some decent standard of living other than living on the dole. The Minister is not getting down to the issues here.

Three people were contracted to get the assessment for this mine. That was three or four months ago. I point out again that the Federal Court said about the assessment that it was political and was not conducted in the proper terms. That was an assessment made by a Federal Court judge. That is a very serious criticism of the Minister's Department. Yet he has not been able to find out what has happened in the last three months. Senator Richardson should take a little more care in administering his Department. I know that Christmas Island does not mean a great deal to him and that he is right into the environmental issues, but Australian citizens are over there wanting some sort of management of the Department that is administering their lives. The Minister is not giving it to them and should be condemned. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, we wrote to you seeking to bring on a matter of public importance relating to the crisis in China and the Government's response to that crisis. We did so aware of the mountain of business that is before the Senate. However, we were appalled by the fact that it seemed that the Government was going to go from this session of the Parliament without having put down a statement on China or give its response to the position in China and without having given the Senate the opportunity to debate that statement. As matters have developed today, apparently it was decided in the House of Representatives-and we are pleased that this occurred-that a resolution would be moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and that there would be an opportunity for the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) to respond.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Leader of the Opposition has responded to that motion and put down the position of the Opposition, and in view of the vast quantity of work that still remains to be done in this chamber, on consideration we have, somewhat a little reluctantly I might say, decided that it would be in the best interests of business in this place if we withdrew our letter. But I would not want it to be thought in any way that by withdrawing it we do not regard the debate on China or the seriousness of Australia's response as serious. As I sit down, I only say that I wish that Australia had responded in a way such as Canada has responded and put some real input behind the sentiments that it has been expressing. I withdraw the letter I have written to you, Mr President, and do not pursue the China debate today.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I suppose those who were listed to speak in this debate would have already done, as I have done, a good deal of preparation for the debate. It may be necessary to give notice of a motion tomorrow in relation to one particular aspect of this question, but that will be on a particularly narrow aspect of the whole question which I would otherwise have been happy to debate this afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will recall that on 15 and 16 December 1988 I presented to the Senate correspondence from the Minister for Resources and opinions of the Government's legal advisers indicating a view that the disallowance by the Senate on 1 May 1986 of certain export control orders was not effective and that the orders were therefore still in force. On 20 December 1988 I presented advices from the Clerk-Assistant (Procedure) and Professor Douglas Whalan indicating a contrary view. On 28 February 1989 I presented the reasons for judgment, dated 23 December 1988, of Mr Justice Woodward of the Federal Court in making an injunction restraining the responsible Minister from acting under the orders.

INTERJECT.PARA: I now present to the Senate the reasons for judgment, dated 13 June 1989, of Mr Justice Jenkinson in respect of a finding by the Court that the orders were validly disallowed by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to speak very briefly on the matter. First of all I thank you, Mr President, for the action which you took in December, through the Clerks, to obtain advice on this matter which touches in a very serious way on the powers of the Senate and of control by the legislature of subordinate legislation. Honourable senators will remember that it was the Senate which disallowed three orders which were made relating to export control and the non-provision of services by the Commonwealth which were necessary to ensure that goods could be exported. This was a matter of high political importance because you will recall, Mr President, that in the Mudginberri dispute, which was a landmark in industrial relations in this country some years ago, there was considerable criticism of the Commonwealth for the failure to provide essential inspection services, which added to industrial difficulties faced by that company.

In the dispute at Portland we had a repeat of that exercise, albeit in a slightly different form. It raises very important principles of industrial relations as to whether the Commonwealth, through its bodies, should use its compulsory requirements to augment industrial disputes which may be very destructive of individual enterprises and of the Australian economy. The technical point taken by the Government was that the disallowance by the Senate of certain regulations was not valid. It is a matter of regret to the Opposition that we had what I can only describe as a spineless legal opinion from the Attorney-General's Department which suggested that the disallowance by the Senate was not valid.

This is not a court of law and this is neither the time nor the place to deal with the technicalities of the matter. But I want to put on the public record the fact that I describe the legal opinion as spineless because I believe that the Attorney-General's Department should have tried to find an interpretation which protected the right of the legislature to control subordinate legislation. The point is made in the tabled judgment that we have a situation where we are dealing with unicameral legislation-legislation which has come not through this Parliament but from the Executive Government. The control of that type of legislation is vested in this Parliament through the Acts Interpretation Act by giving the Parliament a power of disallowance. The opinion of the Attorney-General's Department reads down that power of disallowance to restrict us to having a power to disallow effectively whole batches of regulations. The Senate had picked out three particular orders that it regarded as offensive and had disallowed them. The opinion of the Attorney-General's Department said that the Senate had to disallow all or nothing. That is a very significant reading down of the Senate's power and of the power of this Parliament to control subordinate legislation.

For those who think this is a somewhat obscure matter, let me say that this is a very old struggle. It was in the 1920s that Lord Hewart wrote a book called The New Despotism. It is an English text of 70 years ago which makes the point that the capacity of the Executive Government to make laws by regulation without the control of Parliament gave a power which was despotic to the Executive Government; that is, a power which could be used to threaten the liberties of the people. One of the best contributions of this Senate to good government in Australia is the work of both the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances-I am pleased that the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of that body are present for this debate-and of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills which runs the rule over all legislation, not just subordinate legislation, and reports to the Senate whether it unduly trespasses on individual rights and liberties. There is bipartisan support and respect for the work of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. Senator Collins frequently seeks leave to make statements and to present reports. It is the unfailing tradition of the Senate to give him leave. Both Senator Collins and Senator Bishop, who currently is Deputy Chairman of that Committee, in common with all other senators, would say that it is a very valuable contribution to good government. It is not a political contribution; it is a contribution to try to ensure that we have good legislation in this country.

I would have thought that any lawyer with an understanding of the role of Parliament in ensuring that we maintain a free society would have bent over backwards to find an interpretation of a law which gave this Senate and the House of Representatives maximum flexibility in disallowing regulations which do not go through this Parliament. When I read the opinion of the Attorney-General's Department when it was delivered last December, I was surprised because I thought it was a very poor piece of work. I was even more surprised that it came out with entirely the wrong conclusion. Any lawyer would have realised that what one should have been seeking was an interpretation of the law which gave the Parliament the maximum power to disallow. The Attorney-General's Department needs to examine this opinion very carefully and to consider the principles that are at stake, and to examine how it came to give such a poor opinion.

We rely very heavily upon the Public Service in this place. We require good independent advice if we are to do our job well. Through the opportunity we have in debate in this place, I say to the Attorney-General's Department that I think its reputation has slipped. Through this and a number of other opinions that we have been given we have reached a situation where many senators pay little regard to an opinion from that Department. I say that with great regret because I have worked with officers of that Department and I have had great respect for many of them. I think of Mr Andy Menzies, who has continued to serve the Government in various capacities since he left the Department. There are many others for whom I have the greatest respect. I do not believe the Department is maintaining the standard that we expect of it. This opinion is a particularly poor example of its work.

Having said that of the Department's opinion, it would be quite unfair not to refer to the opinion which was also delivered to us on 16 December and dated 15 December from Gavan Griffith, QC, the Solicitor- General of the Commonwealth. The Solicitor-General of the Commonwealth holds a peculiarly important position. He is the counsel to the Commonwealth; he is the source of continuous independent advice, beyond the Department. It is a position of great significance. The Solicitor-General should look very carefully at the opinion that he so cheerfully endorsed with his opinion of 15 December-the opinion of the Attorney-General's Department. In this opinion he confirms his:

oral advice of 13 December 1988 that, having perused the Opinion of the Attorney-General's Department dated 5 August 1987 concerning the effect of resolution for the disallowance of Orders 100C, 100D and 111A of the Prescribed Goods (General) Orders passed by the Senate 1 May 1986, I concur with the conclusions expressed in that Opinion that the resolutions were ineffective and that the Orders remain in effect.

It is extraordinary that this highly qualified and skilled law officer should not have seen what a poor opinion this was and how wrong it was. First of all in a preliminary way, but now in the orders in the judgment of Mr Justice Jenkinson that has been tabled today, the Federal Court of Australia, which dealt with this, indicates that the view that we expressed in December is the view that the court has sustained.

TALK.START.PARA: —After six months.

—Senator Cooney should know that one of the lesser virtues of the law is its speed in dealing with issues. All of us who have been lawyers have grounds for embarrassment in that regard. I do not think Senator Cooney would place any significance on a six-month period, although I agree with him that it is an issue. In fairness to the court, one has to remember that the court was dealing with a series of issues and could not have been expected just to toss up an opinion in a way that a lawyer is able to.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I wanted to speak on this matter is that it is common ground in this chamber that the capacity of the Senate to disallow is a significant power which all parties have used in a proper way. I cannot pretend that there have never been mistakes. But there has been strong bipartisan support for that power. In December we saw the Government take advantage of a situation that was patently wrong. It is perhaps important to remember that in the debates at that time there were two separate issues. Firstly, there was the issue of whether Minister Cook should have acted in the way he did-a quite separate political issue-as a party to depriving the meatworks of essential Commonwealth services. He was clearly wrong in doing that. Secondly, the Commonwealth Government was prepared to rely on an opinion which was obviously wrong but which, if it had been right, it should have been anxious to see corrected. Clearly, it was a writing down of this important role of the Senate and of the Parliament.

I welcome the fact that the President has brought this material into the Senate. It is of importance to us. All honourable senators will appreciate the fact that he, through the Clerks, acted to try to seek clarification-and obtained a speedy correction-of that obviously fallacious opinion by going to Professor Whalan of the Australian National University, who in an opinion which was given to us before Christmas last year made it clear that he also thought the Attorney-General's Department was wrong. Quite frankly, I just hope that the Attorney- General's Department will smarten up its act and lift the standard of care which goes into the preparation of these matters. These are vitally important to the nation. If the Attorney-General's Department cannot do a good job in this area, we will have a lesser standard of government administration at every level.
Debate (on motion by Senator Crichton-Browne) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the eighty-fifth report of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The report deals with the operations of the Committee in 1987-88 and includes statistical data and analytical discussion of the technical scrutiny undertaken by the Committee. As with previous reports, it represents a manual or set of guidelines for Ministers and their advisers on how the Committee approaches the application of its principles. I urge Ministers, and in particular their advisers, to read the report carefully as it may guide them away from some of the pitfalls in preparing delegated legislation.

Briefly, I would like to add something that I pointed out to the Committee at its meeting this morning and that is highlighted by this report: the work of the Committee is increasing, not surprisingly. The number of instruments that are being prepared in terms of delegated legislation is continually increasing. But, despite that, the interesting thing-I am sure some honourable senators have noticed it-is that there has been a very measurable decrease in the number of protective notices that have been moved. In other words, what we thought was perhaps a temporary aberration is in fact a very welcome substantial improvement in the quality of the drafting of the regulations in accordance with the Committee's principles, which has led to a distinct falling off in the number of protective notices that have had to be issued in the Parliament.
I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my tabling speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
STATEMENT ON TABLING OF REPORT

This Report deals with the work of the Committee from July 1987 to June 1988. The Report sets out the basic statistics of the operations of the Committee over that period; in particular the numbers and types of instruments examined and the number of Ministerial undertakings obtained and implemented in respect of concerns raised by the Committee. Perhaps more importantly, however, it describes how the Committee has interpreted the principles under which it operates and how it applies those principles to the protection of personal liberties and parliamentary proprieties. These are set out in some detail and with various examples.

The reasons for this approach are, firstly, to inform the Senate of the work of the Committee. All delegated legislation is, of course, made under the direct authority of Acts of the legislature, and its legal effect upon individuals is in no way less than that of Acts. A heavy duty rests upon the Committee, therefore, to represent those interests with which the legislature is so closely associated; to act as an agent for the Senate in scrutinising delegated legislation for breaches of individual rights or legislative prerogatives. I hope that the Committee continues to carry out this duty as effectively as it can.

Another important reason for this approach is because the Report should be used as a manual or check list by officers in departments and statutory authorities who advise on and draft delegated legislation. I dealt with this at length last year when presenting the previous annual report of the Committee. I now repeat my strong recommendation that every Minister takes all appropriate steps to ensure that senior departmental officers apply the principles noted in the Report when preparing delegated legislation for consideration by the Minister. It is a test of managerial efficiency for these senior officers to place before the Minister drafts of delegated legislation which comply with the published standards of the Committee. These standards should be well known; not only are they set out in consolidations such as the present report, but the Committee also regularly tables or incorporates in Hansard descriptions of its scrutiny work throughout sittings along with all correspondence in relation to the more important matters which it raises. This is done at the same time as the Committee finalises its consideration of a matter.

The Report also deals at length with procedural difficulties the Committee meets in its operations. An entire Chapter of the Report discusses the requirements for proper Explanatory Statements. Other parts of the Report address delay in implementing undertakings and the necessity for departmental officers to be familiar with the standards of the Committee. These discussions of the difficulties of the Committee are intended as constructive assistance to departmental officials in achieving the standards set by the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also seek leave to incorporate the usual Chairman's statement about the work of the Committee during the present sittings.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
STATEMENT ON WORK OF COMMITTEE DURING AUTUMN SITTINGS
Over the past sittings the work of the Committee has been characterised by two main features.
The first of these is the continued high volumes of delegated legislation which has come before the Committee for scrutiny.

The number and types of instrument confirm the continued reliance of the executive on delegated legislation as a standard mechanism to facilitate day to day Commonwealth public administration. As such the work of the Committee is doubly valuable to the Parliament in both scrutinising the results of the law-making power which it has delegated and in supervising the actions of the executive itself.

Indeed, the volume of delegated legislation suggests that directives and instructions of the executive which previously may have been confined to the corridors of power in the different departments of state, are now subject to parliamentary scrutiny. The role of the Parliament in the oversight of the administration of its Acts is thereby strengthened. The domain of Ministers and their senior departmental advisers has been subjected to the fresh air of tabling and the brisk wind of possible disallowance.

This tendency is only welcome, however, as long as the delegated legislation is justified in terms of filling-in administrative details, prescribing lengthy objective technical standards or providing for situations where frequent minor changes are necessary to schemes or programs. The instruments themselves must also, of course, comply with the Committee's standards of personal liberties and parliamentary propriety. In this context of the proper use of delegated legislation the Committee has detected some disturbing tendencies, which will be discussed in detail later in this statement. In the meantime, the attention of Honourable Senators is drawn to the following table, which describes the various instruments actually considered by the Committee during the present sittings. The list covers the entire sweep of Commonwealth administration, with delegated legislation made on the advice of virtually every department of state and important statutory authority. Honourable Senators are reminded that, for example, the Statutory Rules alone, which are the most numerous single type of instrument considered, and which come under a single item in the list, are made on advice from almost every executive portfolio. Some of the instruments in the Table were made late in 1988 but not considered until the Autumn Sittings 1989.
