TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 74, after clause 56, insert the following new clause:
56a. After section 290 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:
Fixed interest complying ADFs-exemption of income attributable to certain 25 May 1988 deposits

`290a. (1) For each amount that, apart from this section, would be normal assessable income of a continuously complying fixed interest ADF of a year of income, the proportion (if any) calculated under subsection (2) is exempt from tax.
`(2) The proportion is calculated using the formula:
Aggregate of current 25 May balances
Aggregate current balance
where:
Aggregate of current 25 May balances is the aggregate of the current 25 May balances of eligible depositors, as at the reckoning time in relation to the year of income;
Aggregate current balance is the total amount deposited with the fund (together with accumulated earnings), as at the reckoning time in relation to the year of income.
`(3) An election for the purposes of the definition of ``reckoning time'' in subsection (4):
(a) shall be made by notice in writing to the Commissioner; and

(b) shall be lodged with the Commissioner on or before the date of lodgment of the return of income of the ADF for the year of income to which the election relates, or before such later date as the Commissioner allows.
`(4) In this section, unless the contrary intention appears:

``continuously complying fixed interest ADF'', in relation to a year of income (in this definition called the ``current year of income''), means a fund that is a fixed interest complying ADF in relation to each of the following years of income:
(a) the current year of income;
(b) the year of income in which 1 July 1988 occurred;
(c) each year of income later than the year of income mentioned in paragraph (b) and earlier than the current year of income;
``CS policy'' has the same meaning as in Division 8 of Part III;

``current 25 May balance'', in relation to an eligible depositor as at the reckoning time, is the balance as at that time determined by varying the original 25 May balance, in accordance with the following rules, during the period from 26 May 1988 to the reckoning time:
(a) the balance from time to time is not to exceed the original 25 May balance and is not to be less than nil;
(b) subject to paragraph (a), an amount deposited with the ADF by the depositor before 1 July 1989 is to be added to the balance;
(c) subject to paragraph (a), an amount repaid to the depositor from the ADF is to be deducted from the balance;
``eligible depositor'', in relation to an ADF, means:
(a) a depositor whose 55th birthday occurred on or before 25 May 1988; or

(b) a depositor whose 50th birthday occurred on or before 25 May 1988 and who, on or before that date, made a deposit with the ADF that consisted wholly or partly of the roll-over (within the meaning of Subdivision AA of Division 2 of Part III) of an eligible termination payment, being an eligible termination payment that included a concessional component (within the meaning of that Subdivision);
``fixed interest complying ADF'', in relation to a year of income, means a complying ADF where both of the following conditions are satisfied:
(a) not less than 90% of the amount that, apart from this section, would be the normal assessable income of the ADF of the year of income consists of either or both of the following:
(i) interest or a payment in the nature of interest;
(ii) an amount included in assessable income under Division 16e of Part III;
(b) at no time during the year of income did the assets of the fund consist of or include any of the following:
(i) units in a PST;
(ii) CS policies issued by a life assurance company or a registered organization;

``original 25 May balance'', in relation to an eligible depositor, means the amount of the deposits (together with accumulated earnings) standing to the credit of the depositor as at the end of 25 May 1988;

``reckoning time'', in relation to an ADF in relation to a year of income, means the beginning of the year of income, or such other time during the year of income as the ADF elects in accordance with subsection (3).

`(5) This section does not apply to an ADF in relation to a year of income unless the Commissioner is satisfied that the whole of the benefit that would accrue to the ADF from the application of this section in relation to the year of income has been, or will be, passed on to eligible depositors.'.''.

The amendment will provide an exemption from the 15 per cent earnings tax for a proportion of the assessable income of certain approved deposit funds (ADFs) that derive most of their income as interest. The exemption will apply to income that is referable to the deposits held in funds as at 25 May 1988 by two groups of depositors. The first group consists of people who are aged 55 years or over at that date. The second group consists of those who are aged 50 years or over at 25 May 1988 and who, on or before that date, had rolled over into the ADF all or part of an eligible termination payment that consisted wholly or partly of a bona fide redundancy payment, an invalidity payment or an approved early retirement scheme payment. Where such depositors withdraw any of their 25 May 1988 balances, the amount of the exemption the ADF is entitled to will ordinarily be reduced to reflect that withdrawal. However, the exemption will not be reduced to the extent that a person re-deposits amounts previously withdrawn with the same ADF by 30 June 1989.

To qualify for the concession an ADF must satisfy two conditions at all times from the 1988-89 year of income to the year in which the exemption is claimed. The first condition is that the ADF must receive at least 90 per cent of its investment income in the form of interest. Secondly, the ADF must not have any investments in pooled superannuation trusts or life assurance policies. This condition will ensure that funds do not obtain tax exemption on their direct investments while effectively deriving significant non-interest income through indirect investments of those kinds.

A fixed interest ADF will not be entitled to imputation credits to the extent to which any franked dividends that it receives are exempt. The Government understands that this amendment meets Australian Democrats' concerns that people in the circumstances that I have described ought to be protected from the impact of the tax on ADF earnings. The amendment makes it a requirement that fund managers pass on to the depositors in question the benefit of the concession provided. I commend the amendment to the Committee. I have already tabled a supplementary explanatory memorandum.

I wish to make only a couple of other comments. The first is that the Government-I do not think that this is news to anybody-would rather the Bills had been passed as they were presented. These amendments will involve some additional complications. However, the Government made the judgment that it is better to make this concession in order to ensure that the package of Bills is passed, thereby removing the possibility that some 300,000 people who received lump sum payments in this financial year, taxed at the rate applicable in this legislation, would not receive an additional and, as the National Mutual described it, an effectively retrospective taxation slug.

It is different to the amendment first proposed by the Democrats and rejected by the Senate last Thursday week in so far as it is much better targeted than the original proposal. Of course, that has made it more acceptable, or should I say less objectionable, to the Government than the original Democrat proposal. Senator Watson in particular has indicated that he sees a lot of problems with this and that the Opposition has had advice from somebody or other; I cannot anticipate what that is. I just draw to the attention of the chamber the fact that 13 days ago Mr Connolly was claiming that the amendments that the Opposition moved in the Senate two weeks ago were not defective, that is, defective when measured against what the Opposition meant them to do. He also claimed that they had been scrutinised and approved by the industry. As I said earlier today, it would be interesting to know who in the industry had conducted that scrutiny and given the tick. Clearly it was someone almost unbelievably incompetent, given that the person worked in the industry and did not pick up the defect in the amendments originally moved by the Opposition.

It is not my intention to speak again on this amendment. But, in view of some of the things that have been said already, and probably will be said again, I draw attention to a letter dated 2 June 1989 from the AMP Society, which was circulated to householders in the Australian Capital Territory recently. It states:
In the midst of government legislation, three facts emerge quite clearly.

First, that future government age pensions will not be adequate for most of us. With an ageing population, it will be extremely difficult for the government to fund future pensions for everyone at the level we would like.

Second, that the government is still encouraging you to provide for your own retirement benefits. This is clearly evident through changes in legislation that continue to favour Superannuation as an investment.
And third, that Superannuation is still one of the most attractive long term investments. In fact, it is one of the most tax-effective forms of investments available today.
Later the letter states:

An additional change that may have created confusion was the introduction of a 15% levy tax on all tax-deductable contributions (less expenses). We will be writing to you later in the year about this. This levy will be mainly offset by lower rates of tax than previously applied on benefits taken in retirement. In this way your after-tax position at retirement remains virtually unchanged and indeed may be enhanced.

I am not sure whether the AMP Society is the largest superannuation fund in Australia, certainly, it is one of the larger ones. To my knowledge, that is the most recent assessment of the AMP. Of course, it is well known that National Mutual has been publicly supportive of the Government with this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't you ask why?

—Senator Watson should have read the press statement that Eric Mayer sent out a couple of weeks ago when he was aghast at having discovered the amendments being moved by those opposite. Senator Haines has already quoted the relevant section from a letter written by the General Manager of the Commonwealth Bank regarding the Commonwealth Bank fund because it had been believed that there would be difficulties in amending trust deeds. I am not really sure whether there would have been difficulties, but the final six or seven lines of the amendment have been put in because the benefits of the concession must be directed towards qualifying depositors and not spread across depositors generally. We understand, and the Commonwealth Bank clearly agrees with us, that this has removed the difficulty, if any, that amending trust deeds would have entailed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) of relevance. He wants the Bill passed; yet, to take people's attention away from the thrust of the Government's amendment, he has introduced extraneous factors which are of no relevance to the provisions. We should get on with the job of dealing with the provisions before the Committee. The conditions with which an approved deposit fund (ADF) will have to comply as a result of these Government amendments are interesting. There are two conditions: the first is a requirement that not less than 90 per cent of the fund's investment income must be in the nature of interest. Some of these funds perhaps have within them a growth fund or an equity linked fund. What is the provision in the Bill to separate the components of the ADF for the purposes of fixed interest? Each is not a legal entity. There could be difficulty in funds complying with this 90 per cent requirement because an ADF is a generic term and, within the umbrella of a fund there may be different sectors each with a different intent and each with a different purpose. There is no mechanism in this Bill to bring out the different components within an ADF in order to comply with these requirements. Does this mean that these new provisions will excise a number of ADFs that Senator Haines-perhaps naively-hoped would be included? That is the first problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, ADFs cannot have investments in pooled superannuation trusts or life assurance policies. Another requirement which I think represents a further exclusion is that a fund must be a continuously complying fixed interest ADF. This means that at all times since its inception the fund must have been complying. That is another avenue for exclusion of ADFs. Senator Haines has really had the wool pulled over her eyes.

The next matter, I think, requires some comment from the Minister. It concerns a fixed interest ADF. The Minister will know that there are many trustee sorts of companies and others who nowadays, because of increasing interest rates, have what are known as flexible deposits with a flexible and varying interest rate. They have one interest rate one quarter and, if the general level of interest rates rises, their rate will go up. Do investments in these sorts of funds come within the definition? On an ordinary person's reading of the clause, flexible interest rates, which are very common nowadays, appear to be excluded. Why was it necessary to use the words `fixed interest'? It was not necessary. The Opposition is becoming very suspicious nowadays because every word seems to have a hidden meaning. I think there is the potential for excluding a lot of ADFs, which may be 89 per cent and they have a 3 per cent portfolio, which pushes them over into the 92 per cent category, and they are excluded from the very provisions that we are trying to encourage as a result of this Government amendment today.

There are so many weaknesses in this whole shabby deal which has been devised by the Government to let the Democrats off the hook. That is really what it amounts to. Basically the Government has got its way. Senator Walsh has almost got his original Bill, so he should not apologise to anybody. All he has done is put in a lot of complications which have the effect of achieving his original intent anyway. Well done! He has hoodwinked the Democrats in a major way. So we have the problem of flexible interest rates.

Now let us come back to the substance of what the Government is trying to achieve. Many ADFs, as I mentioned, have what are known as various sub-funds, with each sub-fund having a separate investment philosophy. We hope that each sub-fund will be treated separately within the proposed amendments; otherwise, members with capital-stable sub-funds will be disadvantaged. We must get an answer to that. The Minister should respond.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister cannot respond until I give him the call. Have you finished?
—It is essential to get an answer before we continue, in the interests of shortening the debate.

—I have just had confirmed what I believe. First, as a question of law, I am advised that the Government cannot legislate for all the sub-funds which are within some funds. I think Senator Watson has been told this before. That is because sub-funds are not legal entities. Legislation can only be directed to something which can be identified as a legal entity. The answer to Senator Watson's last question is very similar. What overall fund managers do to the various sub-funds they control is really a question for the fund managers. It is not something for the Government or, it seems to me, something that the Government could get involved in if it wished to. I should add this qualification: the last six or eight lines of the amendment require the ADF to pass on to the qualifying depositors the benefits of the tax concession, if any.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the great majority of cases they will not be able to pass on the concessions. I only hope Senator Haines listened to that response, which is the biggest letdown we have heard today. The Australian Democrats must acknowledge the reality. The Government cannot say it is not responsible for how the sub-funds make up their ADFs, but surely it will acknowledge what is commercial practice and legislate accordingly. It has effectively denied all these sorts of funds-the whole packet-the concession the Government says they are entitled to under this legislation. What a hoax! I hope everybody here acknowledges what has just been said. The Government will place beyond the legislation, beyond the amendment, the great majority of ADFs and particular things that it is supposed to be legislating for.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat: these approved deposit funds, which have various sub-funds each of which has a separate investment philosophy, will now be placed at risk in relation to the amendment devised between the Government and the Democrats. That is disappointing. It is disgusting.

The second point is that considerable complexities are involved in translating the exemptions into unit pricing. For example, mechanisms will have to be established which will pass benefits of the proposed exemption to the defined eligible depositors. Instead of an ADF having a particular unit price, I suppose it will have three unit prices-one for the general body which has been missed out, one for the 55-year-olds and over, and another for the people who have been retrenched in the age 50 and over category. That alone will create more administrative complexity. I remind the Minister for Finance that that surely must discriminate against a great body of people. If some get a benefit to the detriment of others, there must be people who will be disadvantaged. Hence Senator Bishop had a valid point in relation to the numbers of people that would be affected-perhaps not in a significant way but who would nevertheless be affected as a result of the change. I remind the Minister that it is likely that the not inconsequential cost involved will be spread over all the ADF members and not just those who stand to benefit. That is an essential principle of trust law. They cannot allocate those costs to a particular group that supposedly benefits. In other words, the people who will be disadvantaged will be disadvantaged further because the costs of administration will be spread over the whole fund because they cannot, according to trust law, allocate this to particular categories. It is another inequitable situation.

The fourth point is that the proposal discriminates against similar persons who have invested in personal super, deferred annuities and pooled superannuation trusts (PSTs). The amendment, as we have mentioned earlier, does not pick up all intended persons. Unfortunately, it has a retrospective application and trust deeds will have to be amended. Because the Government has introduced all these new amendments there will be a whole host of new problems which have to be spelled out somewhere. Up to date nobody has had the guts to come forward and spell out what all these problems will be. There are administrative difficulties with the proposed amendments. These must be added on to the enormous costs of this initial package.

Let us look at these new problems. The funds have now got the problem of identifying depositors aged 55 at 25 May 1988. They will have the problem of identifying depositors over 50 on 25 May 1988 who have received concessional components in their eligible termination payments (ETPs). This date is not ordinarily recorded on computer files. It means that the superannuation funds, ADFs and so on will have to examine each statement of the termination payment for each member over 50 at 25 May 1988. Naturally that exercise will be quite time consuming but at least it will be a one-off exercise.

Then the investment criteria present no problem for certain types of approved deposit funds if they are all of the fixed interest component type. But I have just given an example to show that not all the ADFs are of the fixed component type. They have a fixed component element in one subgroup and a flexible component in another. That will rule the whole of the ADF ineligible by virtue of these provisions. There will have to be a retrospective adjustment for depositors, in one case, over 50 and, in the other case, over 55 who withdrew since 1 July 1988. That will involve checking the details of each payment made and adjusting the person's interest on allocation and the pay as you earn taxes as applicable.

For the large funds that exercise will really be quite onerous in checking back on people who have fallen into this category. We then have the problem of how we will allocate interest for eligible depositors. They will now be on a different basis from other fund members. Again, this will present record-keeping difficulties and some changes to their already complex new software which they had to introduce just to accommodate the original changes. Again, the position is unclear of what happens to benefits which are rolled over into a fund which qualifies for special tax treatment in another fund. If an eligible depositor is aged 55 plus and held a deposit in another approved fund as at 25 May 1988, what happens if he rolls over that fund into another ADF? Presumably the aggregate of the current 25 May balances is increased in one fund. But the rules of one fund might be different from the rules of another into which he has rolled over. How can one meet the continuously complying section of those poor unfortunate people who have moved out of one fund with a particular company and into another where investment was, in one case, segmented and, in the second, a whole ADF fixed interest component? They will be disadvantaged. I would like the Minister's response to that in due course.

We have this term `aggregate of current 25 May balances'. This causes further confusion, uncertainty and doubt. Is it adjusted for interest allocated to the depositor or will it exclude the effect of the interest allocations? If we exclude the interest, there would be special administrative difficulties. They would have to keep separate records of members' balances at 25 May and the interest earned. Any withdrawal would then have to be split into interest and capital at 25 May 1988 component. This will be almost impossible to accommodate. Similarly, new deposits will need to be broken into components backdated to 25 May 1988. Not only will we have a complete shemozzle but the Government will also find at the end of the exercise that it will be passing the benefit to very few people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that the Government's amendments are before us, there are several things that need to be drawn attention to. The first is to answer the points made by Senator Walsh concerning the manner in which the Government chose to deal with the Opposition's amendments. The first thing to say, of course, is that the amendments that were introduced initially into this chamber on 25 May were exactly the same amendments as were introduced into the lower House. It is interesting to note that during the debate in that place not one query or point was raised. I listened to Senator Walsh answer a question of mine at Question Time when I said how interesting it was that the Government chose only to draw people's attention to this technical deficiency at 10 o'clock in the evening. He was at great pains in an answer to a question to say, `No, it was not 10 o'clock in the evening, it was half past nine'. Again, we see the red herring being drawn across the trail. Is the Minister for Finance so contemptuous of this chamber that he believes that the Government has no need to take seriously anything that is moved other than in the House of Representatives? Is that the reason why we did not discover it until half past nine at night? Is the reason that Senator Walsh holds the Parliament in contempt?

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take a look at what happened after that. Let us look at the difficulty that the Government had drafting the amendments to accommodate the Democrats. Let us see what happened when I asked on several occasions whether I could have those amendments. I was told that I could not have them. We then started to hear the scuttlebutt-`The Government has been working on them for well over a week now but it really cannot come up with the answer. The Democrats haven't given their kiss of approval to them yet'. In the final analysis, we did see the amendments, because of Senator Watson's good prodding of the Minister. The Minister said he would give us 24 hours notice of his amendments so that we could at least have a look at them and appraise them. We were told that there was some disquiet that came from the Democrats on that count because they really thought they ought to have them exclusively. Whether that is true only they can say.

Having seen those amendments and having had other folk look at them in the short space of time available, it became quite apparent there were many things that were problematical about the amendments, not the least of which is the question of the ability to change the trust deeds, legally or otherwise in a retrospective manner. Before I go on to deal with the legal opinions and views that are held, I would like to complete the story of the behaviour of the Government with regard to the amendments and how they were dealt with.

Honourable senators will note that following Senator Walsh's 9.30 p.m. revelation that somehow our amendments were technically flawed-that was very simply that the No. 2 Bill which was then before the Parliament required a further amendment to include pooled superannuation trusts-the rest of the amendments, of course, were made to the superannuation Bill which was a separate Bill which was introduced by the Government six months after the No. 2 Bill, which, as I have said before, was originally the No. 6 Bill of 1988, was introduced.

Because of the complex nature of the legislation and the manner in which the Government had chosen to present that legislation, Senator Chaney requested assistance from the Office of Parliamentary Counsel and perhaps of the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of the Treasury officials to assist in the drafting to ensure that good and solid debate took place and that the drafting was really up to scratch. Senator Walsh declined that request. Senator Walsh having declined that request, we then went back to the parliamentary Clerks who were unable to deal with the drafting themselves and had to go out to the private sector. The private sector was most helpful and we eventually had the required amendments which have been moved and sadly defeated in this place today.

The situation we have now reached is that the Democrats did not quite like what the Government put up to them because they were concerned about the question of amending trust deeds. What did they do? I read in one version in the paper that they were actually going to put some sort of explicit instruction in the legislation which would authorise, in very specific words, the trustees to alter their trust deeds. But it does not do that. I go back to a very rare document which one really cannot get in this place any more-the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1989 supplementary explanatory memorandum that accompanied the original amendments. The last paragraph on page 1 says:

The purpose of the amendment is to relieve eligible depositors from the impact of the tax otherwise payable by an ADF on income attributable to those depositors' investments in the ADF at 25 May 1988. It is expected that ADFs which qualify for the exemption will pass on the benefit of the exemption to eligible depositors.

It `intends'; there is no compulsion. It is not required. It is simply an expression that we hope that it will all happen some how. No wonder the Democrats were not satisfied with that. To comply with the Democrats' so-called wish, desire or assumption, many approved deposit funds (ADFs) would have to amend their trust deeds retrospectively. How did the Government deal with that problem? It brought back yet another wonderful supplementary explanatory memorandum. This one is readily available. Somehow, we pretended this one did not exist! The explanatory memorandum states:

The purpose of the amendment is to relieve eligible depositors from the impact of the tax otherwise payable by an ADF on income attributable to those depositors' investments in an ADF on 25 May 1988. It is to be a precondition of the exemption that ADFs pass on the benefit of the exemption to eligible depositors.

I ask the Minister to explain to me how that is an explicit instruction to a trust manager or a trustee to have the power to retrospectively change those trust deeds. In dealing with that question we were able to get some legal advice. We had some advice from a Queen's Counsel (QC) in Melbourne. The Senate will be surprised to hear that on this occasion Melbourne and Sydney are in agreement. The QC said that he had been able to see the Government's amendments as they were given to us-by the Democrats-last night. A person from the Treasurer's office said to me last night that I could have the amendments within half an hour. When that did not occur I rang the office of the Minister for Finance and was told that I could have them at 9 o'clock this morning. We were due to sit at 9.30. I received them at 9.10 a.m. In the interim, the Australian Democrats had the decent courtesy to let me have a copy of them. That is an example of the contemptuous way in which this Government treats the Opposition. Subject to those restrictions, the QC stated:
(a) beneficiaries under a superannuation deed may obtain accrued rights;
(b) those accrued rights are legally enforceable and would take a very clear expression of legislative intent indeed to alter those accrued rights;
Where is that intent? He went on to state:

(c) some trust deeds may provide the power to make retrospective variations to trust deeds in which case any such accrued rights are subject to that overriding right of the trustee-see for example Perpetual Trustees W.A. Limited -v- Corporate West Management Limited & Others 13 ACLR 568;
(d) in the absence of such a power in the trust deed accrued rights could not be validly altered by the trustee;
(e) a direction by legislation to a trustee to alter accrued rights would not be by itself sufficient to alter those rights;
(f) the retrospective alteration of accrued rights can usually only be justified by the trustee acting bona fide;

(g) it is not clear that a trustee directed by legislation to retrospectively alter accrued rights would be acting bona fide. It would depend on a number of circumstances difficult to project in the absence of sighting the legislation, looking at the trust deed etc.

He said that if the relevant legislation comes to light and if they could cite the relevant deeds he would be pleased to give a further opinion. Some views expressed in that hastily prepared opinion remain true of the law of equity. Very specific legal problems have been alluded to with which I will deal later. Advice on those problems was given by a senior legal counsel with one of the major players in this field. We also have and advice which has been provided by Mr R. J. Ellicott, QC, on the instruction of Minter Ellison. He also gives an important opinion. The advice states:
I have been asked to advise in relation to the proposed amendment (s.290a) to the above Bill.

The intent of the amendment is to exempt a proportion of income from the 15% tax to protect eligible depositors, i.e. depositors who, by definition, meet certain age criteria. However, the exemption is not to apply unless the Commissioner is satisfied that the whole of the benefit has been or will be passed on to eligible depositors with an ADF. An ADF is, I am instructed, a trust which is normally constituted by a trust deed and which confers rights and benefits on the beneficiary/depositors.

I have not had the benefit of considering an example of such a deed for the purpose of this advice but, in the circumstances, this is not essential because, as will appear, my advice is general in character and relates to trust law generally.
I advise as follows:
1. Where rights have become vested in depositors as a result of the provisions of a trust deed it would not be possible to deprive them of their rights without their consent.

2. A trust deed might sometimes contain a power to divest contingent rights or to vary the interests of beneficiaries. However, in the absence of such powers or of power in a court to vary a trust, the trust deed must operate according to its terms and it will not be possible to divest vested rights. Similarly, rights to future income from a fund cannot be changed unless provisions enabling a relevant variation of the trust exist.

3. Thus if a deed provided that the net income after deduction of expenses including any tax should be distributed in certain proportions among depositors, it would not be possible for trustees to alter the effect of that provision unless there was some power to do so. Proposed sub-section (5) would not in my view, by itself, be sufficient to confer that power. Depositors who had such rights could of course sue the trustee if it attempted to satisfy sub-s.(5) in disregard of the trust deed.
So the Government is setting up potential legal actions. The advice further states:

4. The result of the application of these principles is that it may not be possible in many cases pursuant to sub s. (5) of proposed s. 290a to satisfy the Commissioner that a benefit from the tax exemption has been or will be passed on.
WARDELL CHAMBERS
15th June 1989
R. J. ELLICOTT QC

I ask the Minister: where in the legislation is the type of instruction indicated by the Melbourne QC? Will the Minister respond to the point raised by Mr Ellicott that we cannot retrospectively alter the deed to take away already existing vested rights or those that exist in the future? I would be pleased if the Minister would provide me with an answer now so I can go on to deal with why the legislation does not do what it purports to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson asked me a question which related to the term `fixed interest complying ADF' which appears at the top of page 5 of the amendment circulated by the Government. Senator Watson was afraid that the definition of `interest qualifying'-I do not know why it is in inverted commas-would be taken literally. My advice is that that term is essentially meaningless in the context in which Senator Watson has raised it and that the critical definition is the one that appears in paragraph (a) (i) which says `interest or a payment in the nature of interest'. That phrase is very common in legislation. It has a well-defined legal meaning. It can be defined as interest in the broadest sense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his confirmation on that issue, but I would be far happier with the definition if it said `interest means' rather than `interest consists of'. We have a specific term but later on it does not say that it means something; rather, it says that it `consists of'. For the purposes of the record I hope that funds can rely on that definition because it could be quite significant in determining whether they meet the 90 per cent requirement. The proposed new section states:

SPEECH.PARA: This section does not apply to an ADF in relation to a year of income unless the Commissioner is satisfied that the whole of the benefit that would accrue to the ADF from the application of this section in relation to the year of income has been, or will be, passed on to eligible depositors.
Very few people would understand that the whole purpose of that is to give them authority to change their trust deeds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I acknowledge that.
—I thank the Minister.
—Some people thought they could not change the trust deeds. I am not sure whether that is true but, in case it is true, that makes it possible.

—I assure the Minister that it will be necessary to change the trust deeds. This is an attempt to provide clarification. But if we take away a benefit from a particular category and give another benefit to somebody else, it is necessary to change the trust deeds. At the same time I would have thought that we would have to canvass all the people who were affected. From a practical point of view, can the Minister see people actually answering the question, `Are you happy to have your benefits under this trust deed reduced'? Who will answer yes to that inquiry? Nobody will answer with, `I am happy about having a trust deed altered so that my previous entitlement will be reduced because of a need to satisfy a cosy deal between the Government and the Australian Democrats'. I put it to the Minister that this is not adequate. Senator Bishop has outlined several legal opinions which indicate that.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with the amendment that I have just referred to is that it is too general; it leaves a discretion. To cover adequately the issue that the Government intends to cover, it would have been necessary that the legislation specifically detail and outline or make clear that some beneficiaries will be discriminated against in relation to the benefit. We would be much happier if the Minister could help the debate by tabling the legal opinion that gives effect to the legislative amendment that he has put before us here today. Has he an opinion from the legal section of the Australian Taxation Office or the Attorney-General's Department? That would certainly aid the debate. If he has it, I ask him to table it.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as I know, the amendment was drafted in the normal way. I have just been advised that there is no legal opinion. I am not sure that Senator Watson has understood this properly. He keeps talking about taking a benefit away from some other person in the fund. This amendment ensures that, unless this benefit from a tax concession is passed on to qualified depositors, the fund does not get the benefit of the tax concession. By definition, no benefit will be taken away from some other member of the fund if the trust deed is changed. I am not sure whether Senator Watson has understood that. I have put it on the record and I really cannot see any point in continuing that discussion. He may not agree with the Government. That is his right. He may not agree with it on policy grounds or on legal grounds, but the Government believes it is sound and I do not see much point in continuing the argument.

—I hope that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is not doing this deliberately to confuse my position. I have previously indicated that because of this series of amendments-I was not referring to subclause (5); I acknowledge that subclause (5) was necessary to give effect to the need to change the rules-there will be various unit prices. The Government will certainly discriminate against certain people if it is to give added benefits to others. That has to be reflected in some way in the trust deed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —The argument that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has just put shows how cynically he regards this whole exercise. I hope that the Australian Democrats listened and paid attention to that degree of cynicism. By this further amendment to clause 5 (c), which requires the total distribution to eligible depositors to be made before the benefit can accrue, the Minister is effectively wiping out any benefit to so-called eligible depositors who are in funds where the trust deed requires that that benefit be distributed across the board. In other words, the Government is effectively locking them out, as it has done at every stage in this debate. Let us look at it. The Government has effectively locked out a fixed ADF which has 99 per cent of its investment in fixed interests. If one unit is held in a pooled super trust, it is out of action; it is barred from getting the benefit. It is not just barred for that year of income: it is barred for the entire quarantine period-potentially a 15-year period. The point is that, at every turn where the Government has allegedly attempted to accommodate the Australian Democrats, it has gone out of its way to make fewer and fewer people eligible for the benefit to be paid. I seek leave to table the advice of Mr Ellicott, QC, because it is pertinent to this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it a well considered opinion?

—It was indeed a well considered opinion on the time constraints. The abuse and the lack of concern that the Minister shows for the parliamentary process are indeed contemptible. A press release dated 13 June put out by TPF&C Consultants-a well-known group of actuaries that the Minister had the temerity, on one occasion, to call a group of `management consultants', when in effect it is the world's second largest actuarial consulting company-drew attention to some of the points raised. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: Many ADFs do not presently allow different classes of investor and may not be able to retrospectively amend their rules.

Well, the Minister has taken care of that! If the Government does not retrospectively amend, if it does not make it possible for certain people to be advantaged, no benefit accrues at all. What a cynical exercise!

Another little pitfall for players is the 90 per cent rule. It is based on normal accessable income of the ADF. If an ADF could accidentally fail in this test due to the fluctuations in the interest rates or other causes, once failed it is barred forever-not just in that year, I remind the Committee, but barred forever. Indeed, perhaps then somebody who is an eligible depositor could take action and sue the trustee because he or she had allowed this to occur. What a minefield we are creating!
Let us take a look at how realistic the purpose set out in the second of the supplementary expenditure memoranda dealing with the aim of the amendments is. It states:

The amendment will exempt from tax a portion of the investment income of a complying approved deposit fund that receives most of their income as interest. The income to be exempt is broadly part of the ADF's normal assessable income-that is income other than taxable contributions and certain non-arms length income that is taxable at the top personal marginal rate attributable to amounts held on deposit including accumulated earnings at 25 May for certain eligible depositors.

What does that really mean? What is the real intention? If one is an eligible depositor, will one gain an exemption for all the interest paid in respect of the deposit? Not likely! Let us take an example. I understand that this example has been made available to the Australian Democrats as well. I hope that when they read the example they will pay attention and perhaps they will decide to support our clause of intent of the Parliament when I move that subsequent to these amendments.

Will the amendment to section 290a (2) exempt from tax all future investment income on balances which were continually complying fixed interest ADF as if they had been quarantined from the 15 per cent investment tax? Together with accumulated earnings, which would appear within the clause, the definition of `aggregate current balance' does not appear in the definition of `aggregate of current 25 May balances' for the calculation of the proportion of the total income of the ADF which is exempt. Thus, if a 50 years old depositor has $50,000 and has been invalided out, is in an ADF and is an eligible depositor as at 25 May, by the time the depositor reaches the age of 65, it will accumulate to $208,862 if the ADF earns 10 per cent per annum interest. Of this $158,862, $75,000 relates to the interest on the $50,000 deposit without compounding but $83,862 is the interest on the interest. The amendment of the Government and the Democrats would not appear to exempt the $83,000. That is, more than one half of the expected investment income which they pretend will be exempt will not be exempt. Is that honest? Is that clearly defined legislation? Is that coming clean with the 100,000 depositors?

Let us consider the same type of example in the breakdown step so that we can all understand. Let us assume that there is a fund catering solely for persons who were eligible depositors as at 25 May. Let us say that at that date the aggregate of current 25 May balances was $1,080 and that figure would increase to $1,200 by 30 June 1989. In the year ending 30 June 1989 section 290a would not exempt all of the $120 of the income but only $108, because under the formula that is laid down in the Government's amendments if we divide the $1,080 by 1,200 and multiply it by 120, we get $108.

Let us go through the process year by year. Let us say that by 30 June the following year another $150 had been earned. We apply the section again. We go through the same exercise. We divide the $1,080 by 1,500, multiply it by $150 and the exempt sum is $108. We do it for the following year. The sum of $1,080, being the basic sum, is divided by 1,500 and multiplied by 150-because that was the interest earned-giving us $108 as the exempt sum. That is only 72 per cent of the income of the fund which was 100 per cent correct for eligible depositors. As we go on, less and less of the sum that is invested attracts the exemption. Is that honest? Is that coming clean? Is it pretending to do one thing and doing another?

This legislation is so complicated-deliberately and by design-that it has confused many. It will be a turn-off for many. It has exposed the deliberate obfuscation which this Government goes in for. And the Democrats fell for it. Remember that letter of congratulations that come to the Opposition and to the Democrats? `Thank you', it said to us, `for looking after our rights'. People are certainly not going to thank this Government for looking after their rights and they are not going to thank the Democrats either.

In this complicated convoluted legislation we are debating, the Government stands condemned by its own falsity in pretending to do one thing and meaning another, just like the Treasurer's statement which we have exposed here today. He tried to confine the statement that nobody would be 1c worse off but allowed the community at large to believe something else. That is the practice of this Government. Perhaps the Prime Minister can shed some tears for the way the Government is behaving today. Perhaps they would be more honest tears if one could honestly believe that this Government had a skerrick of concern for superannuants, people who are trying to provide for themselves, trying to work for a better Australia. What a shameful exercise we have seen in this Parliament.

In moving our amendment to insert into the Bill our general purpose clause we are giving the Australian Democrats one last chance. We are giving the Democrats one last chance to say, `We really do care about what happens to people in superannuation funds'. It is a general purpose clause because, as I said right at the beginning of this debate, it was necessary to put on record a statement in plain, simple English saying what it is we intended to do.

The proposed new clause is very clear. It is designed, as I said right at the outset and as I have said right through this debate, to make superannuation an attractive proposition for people to invest in, to give them that level playing field so that they can be attracted into investing their money for a long term benefit rather than spending their after tax income on instant enjoyment or gratification. We have established very firmly that we need to attract additional people into superannuation if we are to become a more self-sufficient nation with regard to our elderly people. The intent of the Opposition has always been clear. The intent of the Democrats at one stage was clear; they voted with us. We are now going through the shameful experience of seeing them renege and do a deal with the Government. I commend the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be supporting this amendment. I did not expect it to be moved because, apart from anything else, if it were to be passed it would be in blatant conflict with other provisions of the Bill.
