—Before we leave the matter of the $20m, I should like to outline to the Minister for Resources what I understand is the purpose and process involved here and get his corroboration that I have properly understood them. As I understand it, the $20m will pass through the reinsurance fund but will not be used for the normal purposes for which that fund was created-namely, to pay certain claims, which are defined in certain ways-but rather to ease the entry into this new scheme of those funds which will be most severely disadvantaged by the introduction of this new scheme. Roughly the proportion of that $20m which will go to each fund will be in proportion to the extent to which that particular fund is adversely affected by the introduction of the new scheme. It is, as it were, a shoehorn to help the funds which will be most adversely affected in the transition period. Is that the correct interpretation?

—That, in the strict limits in which the honourable senator has defined it, is a true interpretation. But I should add that the Government proposes here to change the 35-day liability provision and to see that all 65-year-olds would be eligible under the new provisions, and that the entitlement is expanded to include supplementary benefits as well. The Government wants to change the character of entitlement and the eligibility for entitlement. Because of that, it deems it appropriate to take some money out of the public purse and put it in these funds to make the connection in the transition phase as a one-off provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood that, but the point still remains that the money is not going to meet the actual claims which come out of the fund but, rather, will go to companies which are most affected, given that the rules have changed to include the over-65s as well as the 35-day rule. It is important to get on the record just where that money is going and how it is to be used.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter that I think is important at this stage is the amendment to include proposed new clause 38a. I have been very concerned that since we adjourned on this matter, there has been an intense lobbying campaign. I can only think that a lot of it was generated by the Minister for Resources himself. Quite a bit of the lobbying has been from people who have been misled as to the nature of this sunset clause. The impression has certainly been given to some people that the effect of the sunset clause is to sunset the whole of the reinsurance scheme. I want to put on the record what this sunset clause does. Its purpose is simply to sunset the new arrangements. The application of the sunset clause will mean that the arrangements will revert to those which obtain as of today, so it is only sunsetting the new part of the arrangements and not the whole of the reinsurance pattern.

It has also been claimed-quite wrongly, I believe-that the application of a sunset clause introduces a high degree of instability into the insurance system. The one thing that the insurance companies desperately need is a much higher degree of stability so that they can plan their premiums and know exactly where they are going. The Government itself has introduced the high degree of instability into the insurance system because it has progressively run the reinsurance pool down over the years and has changed the rules in various ways and it will change the rules by this Bill, as the Minister has said, from the 35-day rule to include also all those over the age of 65. So historically the instability has been introduced by the Government. But there is more than that. This Senate has set up a select committee to inquire into this matter. Clearly, the creation of that committee itself, if it is to do useful work, will result in recommendations for modification to the terms and conditions of private health insurance and, hopefully, somewhat more broadly than that, the whole area of health insurance, including both public and private. Out of that will come recommendations for change so that further down the track there will be change. That is anticipated by the very creation of the committee.

The instability in the insurance industry is created not by the sunset clause but by the fact that the conditions in the industry are themselves unsatisfactory, calling into need the creation of a Senate committee, which, hopefully, will bring into existence a report which will recommend changes which will lead to a much greater degree of stability and a much more satisfactory arrangement in the whole area of health insurance, both public and private. The effect of the sunset clause is merely to say to the Government, `You will have three months after that committee reports on 1 March, and in that three-month period you will be on notice either to relegislate the clauses which will be deleted by this sunset clause or, hopefully, to take note of the Senate committee's report and bring into place something better which will introduce longer term stability in the industry'.

I think everybody agrees-even those most rednecked private insurance companies that are after risk insurance-that they want some level of understanding as to where the Government wants to take the whole area of health insurance over the next five or six years so that they can properly plan their premiums and what sorts of services they provide. Members of the public by the same mechanisms can have some assurance that when they join one or other of these insurance schemes that scheme will remain in place for some reasonable period into the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —How is the sunset clause going to go?

—The sunset clause itself does not introduce the instability. The instability is in the system. The instability will be solved by the report from this committee if the Government chooses to take up the results of that report and relegislate at the end of this year. That, of course, is an inherent part of the Senate committee process. If one were to assume that the deletion of this sunset clause would produce stability one would have to presume that the Senate committee would come up with no recommendations for change or recommendations for change which were not going to be accepted by the Government. The reason for the sunset clause is to say to the Government, `Look, you are on notice, you have to take note of that report when it is available and you will hopefully legislate on such with greater long term stability and a better arrangement will come into existence'.

—I would like to return to the $20m that was, we thought until a few minutes ago, to be put into the reinsurance pool. I take it from the very fact that the Government is putting the $20m into the reinsurance pool that it realises that this legislation will have a deleterious effect on the reinsurance arrangements and that is why it is putting in the money. As I understand it now, that money will not be put into the pool at all but it will be kept by the Government and then given out to the newer and closed funds when they become badly affected. I would like the Minister to tell me whether that is fact. What happens if more than $20m is needed to shore up the reinsurance pool? If less than the $20m is necessary, does that mean the Government will not put the whole $20m into the reinsurance pool?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer both speakers in the hope that it may bring this debate to a speedier conclusion. I am a bit reluctant to rise and address the Australian Democrats on what has been said by Senator Coulter. But I do not think that I can sit here and allow his remarks about the effect of the sunset clause amendment to pass unchallenged. There is a fundamental misunderstanding about what the effect of his own amendment would be. It would now appear to be on the part of Senator Coulter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats' amendment to insert a new clause 38a has been something which we have taken a long, hard, close look at. The Office of the Parliamentary Counsel has advised that the clause, as it has been drafted, would not achieve the objective of reverting to the existing arrangements after 30 June 1990 if no legislation came through and replaced all of the provision-if we were left without any legislative change following the committee's report. It would not, in the terms of the Parliamentary Counsel, achieve the objective of reverting to the existing arrangements. There would be gaps left in existing legislation. It would make the existing legislation then unworkable. To achieve the objective that Senator Coulter appears to want, the draft would have to say that previous provisions reapply.

The proposed sunset clause is not acceptable to us as it would provide for only a temporary application of new reinsurance arrangements. The temporary application of the new arrangements would not assist in achieving the objectives of the changes, that is, providing support for community rating and assisting the aged and chronically ill who predominantly belong to the longer established open membership funds to maintain insurance at reasonable cost. The amendment would achieve nothing more than very temporary relief with the use of the Commonwealth's $20m one-off contribution. That hopefully may settle the argument between us.

I now turn to the question that Senator Sheil raised about how the $20m might be used. The $20m is to be paid over 18 months in instalments. It would go to a private account which would be controlled by the Private Health Insurance Administration Council. It would be able to invest and earn interest on that amount if it wished. But the money would be administered through that account in terms of the fund, as I have explained earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —This $20m is becoming even more mystical as we go along. The very fact that the Government is giving $20m for reinsurance purposes shows that the Government realises the medical insurance companies will be disadvantaged by this legislation. I now know that it is going into a private fund that will be used for investment purposes. I suppose out of that the Insurance Commission will dole it out a bit at a time to the insurance companies as they get into trouble. The Government has estimated the amount of trouble that they will get into will be $20m. I do not know on what grounds it has estimated that figure. But what say it is $40m or $15m? In other words, it could be more or less than $20m. What will happen to those funds in either circumstance?

—I do not criticise Senator Sheil in any way but may I make this point clear: the objective is to distribute the money quarterly. It is to conclude after 18 months, having disbursed all of the $20m, plus what interest that $20m may have earned. It is to go to those funds which have a real need. It is not intended to be some open-ended arrangement. It is not intended to be a first payment for something that might later occur. It is a flat amount for that purpose. I make the point again that the reason that the Government thinks it is necessary to do this, which in all the circumstances is an unusual step, is that we are conscious that we are expanding the eligibility for all 65-year-olds to be entitled and the range of benefits they can attract. On that basis we think there is a need to make a payment of this sort. That is a fairly straightforward and obvious position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister in that statement has just admitted that he will distribute more than the $20m. The $20m will be invested and will earn money. The Minister has now said that all of that money will be paid out to the medical insurance companies as they get into a mess. On top of that, it is a one-off payment which he seems to think is some kind of act of grace following the drastic reductions in the Government's contribution to the reinsurance pool. At the present time it is only giving $1m, and after this $20m plus one-off payment the Government will cut out its contribution altogether and will leave the medical insurance companies, the new and closed ones, to fly with whatever feathers they have.

SPEECH.PARA: I am saying that $20m is obviously just an estimate of how much trouble the companies will get into. If the companies do not get into so much trouble, I take it that the Insurance Council, which will invest the money, will not dish out the whole $20m to the reinsurance pool. That is on the one hand. On the other hand, if the insurance companies are in more trouble will the Government help them out of that hole?

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that that remark was a question. I emphasise this is a subsidy; it is not a buy-out. It is a subsidy for the purposes of bringing in these changes.

—The question before the Chair is that proposed new clause 38a be inserted. I have allowed questioning on the $20m to go on for some time. But I think it best that we dispose of proposed new clauses 38a and these other matters could be brought up at appropriate parts in the discussion of the Bill. The question is that proposed new clause 38a be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will confine my remarks to the specific provisions of clause 38a which is the proposed sunset clause. I wish to make one or two preliminary remarks. The first is that, in criticising the Opposition for the position it has taken, both the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and now the Voluntary Health Insurance Association of Australia have attempted to raise the question of our commitment to the principle of community rating. I want to make it abundantly clear, so that there can be no misunderstanding of this matter, that the Opposition is committed to the principle of community rating. It does not seek, it will not seek and its forthcoming health policies will not be seeking to derogate from the underlying principle of community rating. Any attempt to infer some other view on community rating related to our position on this particular commitment of ours is absolutely specious.

SPEECH.PARA: My second point is that there are some comments which have appeared in today's Age to which I wish to draw attention. An article under the heading `Health changes may be thwarted' says in part:
But the chief executive of the HBA, Mr Derek Shaw, said the Opposition and Democrats were showing a total lack of understanding of the issues and would `double the problem overnight'.

One is tempted to draw the inference from that that Mr Shaw and the Hospital Benefits Association are some disinterested parties in this matter whose concerns are purely for the good health of contributors and the Australian population as a whole. Nevertheless, that is quite interesting set against a letter dated 14 June-yesterday-to Mr Shack, the shadow Minister for health. It was signed by Mr A. G. McGregor, the Chairman of Mutual Community Ltd, and it says in part:
You should understand that this-
he is referring to the Opposition parties' attitude towards the sunset clause-
will achieve virtually no benefit and from our company's point of view would not permit us to proceed with a merger with HBA in Victoria.

It makes the point that some of the vested interests-not the interests of contributors, not the interests of the sick or the aged, not the interests of the wider Australian community, but the commercial interests of some players in this game-are alleged to be affected, or potentially affected, by this decision. It is upon that basis that a large amount of criticism, to which Senator Coulter has already referred, has been mounted during the last 24 hours. Many honourable senators will undoubtedly have received from the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, a file of papers indicating the extent to which various organisations around the country are opposed to, or do not like, the proposals which are now before us. There are a large number of organisations which accept and applaud the Opposition parties for the steps they have been taking. One press release states:

Elderly people across Australia would applaud an amendment by the Australian Democrats to the Government's proposed changes to health insurance legislation, according to the president of the New South Wales Council of Senior Citizens, Mr Joe Weston.

By and large it is a fairly futile exercise to weigh up the number of people who make press statements on one side and the number of people who are cranked up to make press statements on the other side, but it is much easier to relate this to the intrinsic merits of the argument which have been put forward. We are persuaded at this stage of the intrinsic merits of the sunset proposal and the necessity for this matter to be re-examined by the Senate once the three-month period has elapsed following the report of the Senate Committee which we have established and which the Government has now indicated that it will serve on.

I will make a series of brief remarks which go to the principles which relate both to the sunset clause and to the provisions of the Bill to which that sunset arrangement will be applied. It is unfortunate that in the last couple of years the debate about health and public policy on health has been almost exclusively about money. Senator Peter Baume, both in his contribution to this debate and as Chairman of the former Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare of which, if my memory serves me correctly, both my colleagues who are here at this moment-Senator Walters and Senator Sheil-were members at various times, drew attention to the fact that there is not enough debate about the goals of health policy, about the outcomes of health policy and about evaluation and about whether we are actually achieving those goals and outcomes. Here in the Senate the debate in recent months has been primarily about issues such as pathology fees, pharmaceutical fees, insurance arrangements, reinsurance arrangements and an expenditure of $20m, or whatever it happens to be. The current debate has been influenced very much by issues such as the cost of private health care, schedules of doctors' fees, the rebates and the like.

We need to get some perspective into this debate which I hope will be one of the achievements of the Select Committee. I hope this achievement will be focused upon when this matter comes back to the Senate. For example, the contribution to the growth in spending on medical services in Australia from 1979-80 to 1987-88 is related very much to the question of expenditure per service. If we look at the figures we will see that approximately 9.7 per cent of the cost of increasing growth in spending on medical services is due to simple population growth; about 24.4 per cent is due to the growth in services per capita; and 65.9 per cent is due to the expenditure per service.

The Opposition believes that this Government's system is in imminent danger of collapse under the weight of the increasing burdens of public sector expenditure. For example, private sector spending accounted for 45.5 per cent of total recurrent costs in 1970-71, whereas by 1985-86 it had fallen to only 27.5 per cent. Of course the public sector, the taxpayer, has to pick up the cost of the withdrawal of the private sector which has been squeezed out of these areas of expenditures. That is happening at a time when health spending has risen from 5.9 per cent of gross domestic product in 1973-74 to 7.9 per cent in 1986-87.

It is unfortunate that, contrary to what the Government claims, the burden falls very much on those who are least able to afford it. Increasingly, access to better quality health care is a factor of having private health insurance. About 80 per cent of people who had a gross weekly income of more than $800 a week in 1986 had private health insurance compared with only 20 per cent of those whose gross weekly income was less than $126 a week. Frankly, the pressures of this system, which is now being bandaided-pressures of continuing unaffordability of private health care, of private health insurance-have forced people into a greater reliance on the public sector, on the increasing queues in public hospitals around the country. It is not a desirable long term outcome.

We in the Opposition have consistently said that we want to support and encourage a greater proportion of the Australian people to be in a position to be able to afford and to undertake provision for their own health insurance arrangements, and to be able to buy packages of health insurance which are both affordable and tailored to the particular needs they have. We do not believe that the system which the Government is now propping up achieves those goals and those outcomes. As a result, we believe that the Senate inquiry is an important part of getting some of those facts into the public debate. By passage of this amendment at this stage we will be in a position of requiring the Government to make a response to the recommendations of that Senate Committee within a fairly short period. For those reasons, I indicate that the Opposition supports Senator Coulter's amendment. I trust that this will bring to a conclusion the debate on the health aspects of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill now before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Resources for drawing my attention to the omission from the suggested amendment to the sunset clause and that it need not lead to a reinstatement of the present conditions. I foreshadow the following amendment, which will be the second part of 38a:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) On and from the day next following 30 June 1990 the provisions in the Principal Act amended by sections 37 and 38 of this Act shall revive in the form in which they exist on the day before the commencement of this Act.
I believe that will satisfy the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you seeking leave to amend your amendment?

—At the moment I am foreshadowing it. I want to say something else before I seek leave to move that. The previous speaker, Senator Puplick, reminded me that paragraph 3 of a letter, which was circulated to me today from Mr Russell Schneider of the Voluntary Health Insurance Association of Australia, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to limit the life of the legislation to 12 months will mean that all health insurers will have to review their attitude to the enrolment of elderly persons. As at the end of 12 months any fund that actively recruited them would face an enormous market disadvantage.

I point out to the Minister-he may care to comment-that in that paragraph what Mr Schneider is suggesting about what may be done or should be done is illegal because that is not the way the funds are supposed to operate under the Act. In encouraging organisations to undertake that sort of action, Mr Schneider is himself acting illegally. Further, the Minister, in circulating that letter and perhaps encouraging the view that that is the way that organisations might behave, is also encouraging illegality. It seems a rather peculiar way to behave when the Government is arguing that it is the Opposition and the Australian Democrats who are using the elderly as a football, when this organisation itself--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I seek your indulgence to intervene.
—I shall hear the Minister.

—I do not wish to interfere with Senator Coulter's speech-I am sure that he will make the points that he wishes to make anyway-but he has foreshadowed that he will amend his amendment. I just wonder whether we can see his words.
—I have made arrangements for photocopies to be circulated as soon as possible.

—I have just about finished on that point. It seems to me that what Mr Schneider is recommending is illegal. It is not within the law to incite somebody to commit an illegal act. I believe that itself is illegal. I believe that for the Minister to circulate that letter is perhaps verging on the border of illegality. I am a bit surprised that the Minister has sought to use the elderly in this quite disgraceful way. I seek leave to amend the sunset clause standing in my name.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 21, after clause 38, insert the following new clause:
Limitation of effect
``38a. The amendments of the Principal Act contained in sections 37 and 38 of this Act shall, unless sooner repealed, cease to have effect on and from the day next following 30 June 1990.''

(2) On and from the day next following 30 June 1990 the provisions in the Principal Act amended by sections 37 and 38 of this Act shall revive in the form in which they exist on the day before the commencement of this Act''.

I briefly point out that would have the effect which unfortunately my earlier amendment would not have had, that is, to revert exactly to the situation which obtains today. Only those extra provisions included in clauses 37 and 38 will cease to exist.
Question put:
That the proposed new clause (Senator Coulter's amendment, as amended) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 39 to 48-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Proposed new clause 48a.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 32, after clause 48, insert the following new clause:
Applications for review by Administrative Appeals Tribunal
`48a. Section 105aab of the Principal Act is amended by omitting subsection (1) and substituting the following subsection:

`(1) In this section, ``reviewable decision'' means a decision of the Minister, or of a delegate of the Minister, under subsection 40aa (8) or (10), section 40ab, 40aba, 40ac or 40afh, subsection 40ad (1a) or 43a (4), section 44 or 45a or subsection (2) of this section.'.

This amendment seeks to give proprietors of nursing homes the option to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal if the appeal to the Secretary to the Department is unsuccessful. As the legislation stands at the moment, if an appeal to the Secretary is dismissed the next line of appeal is to the Minister responsible for the Department of Community Services and Health. The Opposition feels-to use the cliche that has been used right through this debate-that this is Caesar appealing to Caesar. It is not giving nursing home proprietors very much chance of putting forward their representations to an independent body that can consider their concerns.

We consider it a very reasonable amendment. It certainly gives nursing home proprietors a chance. It removes the need for the Minister to have to seek advice from his Department when it has already made a ruling that could have gone against a nursing home proprietor. The amendment stands on its own feet. It is clear and simple. I seek the support of the Australian Democrats and of the Committee for this amendment.
Question put:
That the proposed new clause (Senator Boswell's amendment) be agreed to

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 49 and 50-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Proposed new clause 50a.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 33, after clause 50, insert the following new clause:
``50a. The Principal Act is amended by inserting the following section after section 138:
Telephone access to offices

`138a. The Minister shall direct the Secretary to make provision for the development of a service which will enable a person to make a telephone call to an office that is under the general control of the Secretary, at no greater cost than the cost of a local telephone call.'.''.

This amendment relates to the provision of access to the basic 008 facility-that is, a local call cost facility for clients of the Department of Community Services and Health. I understood that this amendment had the support of senators on all sides of the chamber. Indeed, all of us who represent or are concerned about the welfare of constituents in rural areas believe that this amendment will provide greater access to officers of the Department and officers of a number of other departments. Clearly, in the interests of equity, people in rural and regional areas should be able to contact their departmental officers by way of a local telephone call in the same way as do people in urban areas. That is the purpose of the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to interjections that were made during my colleague Senator Powell's speech, it is quite clear that the Opposition does not understand the logic of the correct way to apply this provision. Last week Opposition senators were attempting to tell Telecom Australia that it had to provide a 008 service to a government department that may be unwilling to offer that service. Telecom cannot impose that requirement on a department. We believe that this is the correct place in which to insert such an amendment. It is a request to this particular Department to request Telecom to provide a 008 number. What we are doing here is exactly what the Opposition was attempting to do last week but which it attempted to do quite incorrectly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the sort of humbug one can expect from someone who was not in the chamber last week when this matter was raised in the course of the debate on the telecommunications legislation.
—Yes, I was, Senator.

—Well, if Senator Coulter was here, he did not listen. We proposed an amendment to clause 35 which would have meant that it was the intention of the Parliament that 008 services be provided to agencies and government departments. If the Australian Democrats are suggesting that somehow government agencies and departments could thereby have ignored that provision and not compensated Telecom Australia, they are playing games with words. It is clear that in the course of that debate Senator Powell got very cold feet indeed, to the point where she asked for the matter to be stood down so that we could talk about it further. After having trotted out a number of specious objections as to why it was not a good idea, the Democrats came back into the chamber and suggested that they might be in it after all. Ultimately, the Democrats had the cheek to query us about the cost of the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose I should not be quite as castigatory as that because that is now the substance of our response to the Australian Democrats' amendment. That was the first and only time we have ever heard the Democrats ask the cost of any proposal which they have put before this chamber. I think that it is high time that we took a responsible request, made for once presumably seriously, in like vein. Accordingly, we will oppose this amendment, but I give notice that in the report stage we will move an amendment to refer the matter to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in order to accommodate that presumably genuine question raised by Senator Powell about the true cost of such a proposal.

Since that proposal was put forward by Senator Powell, I have indeed had put to me a number of conflicting assessments of the cost from my colleagues and from others, one of which suggested that Mr Howe had said that the Department of Social Security was already providing such a service in every State except Victoria and proposed to introduce the service in Victoria in the near future. If that is the case, it may be that this proposal is not even necessary in that Bill, but the Democrats do not seem to have been aware of that when they tried to move their motion the other day. In respect of all those other government departments which the Democrats now propose be dealt with separately, I think we owe them the courtesy to tell them how much it will cost. If Senator Powell was fair dinkum last time, then she should be fair dinkum now in wanting to know the answer before the Democrats proceed with this proposal, irrespective of knowing the cost. Therefore, we will be moving accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government, I respond to the Australian Democrats' amendment. I must say that I respond with great reluctance because I am a reluctant conscript on this matter. But I understand that there is the Bolkus precedent where a similar amendment was accepted last night on the social security Bill.
—No, veterans affairs Bill.

—Thank you, Senator. Therefore, I think I am bound for consistency's sake to accept it here. However, I do so reluctantly. I just want to put these views on the record: I think this is a precious and pretentious little amendment by the Democrats. This is an example of the Democrats trying to govern all things. If one was going to move an amendment like this, I would have thought that, first of all, one would adduce evidence to establish that the Department does not do this when it is necessary. Of course the Department does this when it is necessary. It provides a phone number for people to ring in from the country to find out what the arrangements are with health insurance, health changes and so on. It does that now. It does not need something to be put into an Act to require that to be done. It is a normal administrative provision. It will continue to do those things in the future. This amendment makes it part of an Act. My view would normally be that it does not have a place in an Act. It is better left to be handled administratively. If necessary, if one is unhappy about those provisions, one should go to the Minister and I am sure that he would make sure that it was done. The principle has been accepted by the Government in another piece of legislation. The Government will accept it reluctantly in this piece of legislation. I say: let us get on with the job and pass the rest of the Bill before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must follow up on what Senator Alston had to say about this 008 telephone number. When it comes to getting a fast buck or a fast vote, the Australian Democrats are pretty good learners. Last week they did not know what a 008 number was. They thought that if a call went into a government department the tab would be picked up by Telecom Australia. Senator Powell could not answer that last week. Senator Alston was pointing out that we were simply putting the facility in that Bill so that Telecom would be prepared for any request by a department to have such a number. The Australian Democrats knew nothing about it. When we pointed out to the Democrats that remote areas as well as closer areas have to have access, we were immediately told by Senator Powell to use the reverse charge facility. I explained at the time that reverse charge calls cost far more than 008 numbers, but they still would not have it.

SPEECH.PARA: Having done their homework since last week and having found out that putting in a 008 number is not an engineering feat of great significance in this day and age, they now have the hide to come back with the hypocrisy to tell us that they have thought about it going in and that every department has to have it. I know that every department has to have it for long distance calls from remote areas. As has been pointed out both in the press and in this chamber, every State except Victoria seems to have this facility. Perhaps Victoria is all built around Melbourne and has not got any remote areas. The Democrats are being very hypocritical. The idea is all right but, as has already been pointed out, the costing must be done. They wanted the costing done last week. Let us do the costing, get on with the game and show it to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister whether the Government has had an opportunity to cost this proposal in respect of all government agencies and departments since it was first proposed almost a week ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Government has, I am not aware of it. I think the answer to that is no, but if Senator Alston wants me to get some further detail and information for him, I am prepared to do that. But I note, for the record, that Senator Alston has indicated that he wants this to go to a Senate committee to be examined. I suggest that may be the best place for the Government to present its information. As I say, I have no instructions on whether the Government has in fact costed this proposal in full.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I make the observation again that the Department of Community Services and Health provides this service without it being in the Act when there are changes to health legislation, for the purposes of accommodating country dwellers to get access to that information from the Department, and will continue to do so in the future. What the Australian Democrats want to do is put this in the legislation. As I said before, because of the agreement last night, I think I am bound to accept this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our approach to this has been that it is a desirable position to reach ultimately, but it is responsible to know what it will cost. I do not see how we are going to be in a position to know that unless we are supported in the reference to the Senate Standing Committee by either the Government or the Australian Democrats. If the Government simply supports the Democrats' amendment sight unseen, we will never know the cost. That is one of the real problems with Telecom Australia's community service obligations. One simply has to accept that they are somehow benefiting the community in a general sense without really knowing what the amount of the burden is. I would have thought that the Government could achieve its objective in acting responsibly in economic terms, the Democrats' objective and our ultimate objective of seeing this included in the legislation by the Government being prepared to have it costed by that committee. We will all then be in a position to make a sensible judgment about the matter. Otherwise, it seems to me that the Government runs into the sort of fundamental principle that Senator Walsh would be hitting you over the head with, which is agreeing to something without knowing what it is going to cost the Government. —Seeing that the Australian Democrats have made such a mess of this in trying to pinch an initiative that was not theirs, might I suggest that we pull the requirement for 008 telephone numbers out of the two Bills that we have already put it into and refer the whole matter to the Senate Standing Committee to inquire into the cost?
