SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is opposing part 5 of the Bill. The effect of the action that we are taking in the Committee at the moment is to remove the transfer of the community services and health legislation to the Disability Services Act. If we pass this legislation in its present form 4,000 mentally and physically retarded in New South Wales and Queensland alone-I do not know how many more are in other parts of Australia-will be forced out of their nursing homes and sheltered accommodation into suburbia. That may be quite all right for some people. But there are other people who are so physically or intellectually handicapped that they will never be able to cope in suburban type accommodation. This situation has arisen without consultation with the patient's family, or without any consultation with the physically handicapped people.

SPEECH.PARA: Organisations such as the Challenge Foundation of New South Wales, the Epilepsy Association of New South Wales, the Endeavour Foundation in Queensland, the Society for Crippled Children New South Wales and the Paraplegic-Quadriplegic Association of Western Australia will have to go out into the rental market and rent houses in order to transfer the substantially handicapped persons from sheltered institutions into the real and wide world. The service deliverers will have to meet the massive rents that are being demanded at the moment. These are being inflated as a result of the Government's high interest rate policies. People are having to sell their homes and to move into rented accommodation. My estimate, for Sydney alone, is that about 600 homes would be required to be provided which would already overheat the current rental market. Those organisations would also have to find house parents who are committed and dedicated to caring for four or five severely mentally handicapped people, most of whom require very special attention. Some are not in control of their bowel or bladder movements. The question must be asked: where are these super-dedicated house parents to come from?

Many welfare organisations have said-these are the people who are expected to provide these services-that these people are not available. I ask the Minister whether he knows how many people are prepared to work 24 hours a day caring for other people's children, who are now adults. A lot of property owners will not want to rent their houses to these types of institutions. Many people will not want handicapped people as neighbours. All of this will happen without any indication from the Government that it will fund these extra charges. One of the major providers of welfare services in New South Wales has indicated that economies of scale will be affected drastically when residents are moved from group or institutionalised accommodation and put into residential care in rented suburban homes. That organisation estimates the cost will be in the vicinity of $60,000 per person as opposed to $15,000 per person in a nursing home. Service providers are strapped for funds already and they are at a loss to know how they will get additional funds. The economy is such that people are struggling to maintain a reasonable lifestyle, to keep a roof over their own heads. Under the present Nursing Homes Assistance Act, the homes are 100 per cent funded. If the nursing homes are placed under the Disability Services Act, the funding will be reduced by between 50 per cent and 80 per cent, depending on the subsidy provided for staff.

I want to know whether any costing of these charges has been done. I do not believe there has been. An added responsibility, which has been termed legal duty of care, has to be accepted by the welfare organisations. They have to ensure that patients are neither physically nor sexually abused. The staff in nursing homes and sheltered accommodation are currently responsible in that area. It is almost impossible when one house-parent has the responsibility for four or five mentally handicapped people, caring for them 24 hours a day, to meet that obligation. The physically disabled will be isolated by the proposal because of their unique transport requirements. Their physical health will also be put at risk. Transferring handicapped people from the security of the nursing home environment will cause grave practical problems for which the service providers have absolutely no answer. Special accommodation will be required, such as special beds and transport. When these people move into ordinary suburban homes which house only four or five people these necessities will not be able to be provided.

The welfare organisations-or, as they prefer to be called, the service providers-have given an undertaking to parents, many of whom are very elderly, family and clients that home care for life will be provided for their relatives. The service providers will not be able to give this guarantee under this disability legislation. They cannot honour these commitments, considering the thrust of the Disability Services Act into the community, regardless of the need for client costs. They will be at the mercy of landlords, neighbours and others. How will they get any guarantees that an owner who rents out a house to these community organisations will not want to sell the property in 12 months time because of changing economic circumstances or because of an interstate employment transfer? All these variations have not been taken into consideration.

There are other issues to consider. What happens to the patients' social lives? Those who can work may go to a workshop or a day care centre. Some may be so physically or mentally handicapped that they may not be able to go to work and may be restricted to the house. What happens to them? What happens when the ones who can work come home from work and what happens at weekends? As things stand now, group transport can be organised. Trips to the circus, to the cinema or out into the hills on picnics are arranged for them. Discount rates apply for such bus trips. But, if people are living four and five to a house, these outings and excursions will not be able to be organised. None of these things have been taken into consideration by the Department or the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are wrong about that.

—I will give the Minister the chance to answer; I hope he does. In a group home, there are social conveners, people who are responsible for the entertainment and excursions. That would be one person's job. But those sorts of things cannot be organised for a home with four or five people.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition certainly wants to improve the quality of life for these less fortunate people. We do not believe that this high risk social experiment will work. It has not worked anywhere else in the world. In some cases patients will be far worse off. This is not only the opinion of my colleague the shadow Minister for community services, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). A meeting in Canberra yesterday of the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of the Disabled (ACROD), the peak body of voluntary service providers, passed a resolution supporting the National, Liberal and Democrat motion to refer the matter of accommodation for the disabled to a Senate committee. I certainly welcome the fact that the Australian Democrats supported us in that reference to a Senate committee. They have given these people half a loaf, which I suppose is better than no loaf at all.

I say to Senator Coulter that, although we have referred this accommodation problem to a Senate committee, if we let this legislation pass with part 5 included it will not be as effective as we would have liked. Included in the resolution of the ACROD meeting was an appeal to the Democrats to remove part 5 from the Bill. The voluntary service providers in that peak body wanted an opportunity to put their fears and their concerns on these issues before a Senate committee, which could then make a bipartisan judgment on the evidence before it. The ACROD resolution was carried unanimously by 85 executive officers from all over Australia. I appeal to Senator Coulter, with whom I have shared some committee responsibilities and whom I have always found a very compassionate and reasonable man, and to his colleagues to give their support to the peak body on this matter of nursing homes.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're wasting your time.

—I do not believe that I am wasting my time. I believe that in these matters the Democrats are reasonable people. I hope that reasonableness will prevail tonight. The Australian Council for Rehabilitation of the Disabled wants part 5 of the Bill, which relates to the transfer of nursing homes from cover under the Nursing Homes Assistance Act to the Disability Services Act, to be removed.

SPEECH.PARA: I make a final plea. I know my appeal will fall on deaf ears amongst Government members. I know that honourable senators opposite will not give the support to ACROD which I believe is absolutely necessary. Time and time again we come to the chamber and are presented with airy-fairy legislation that has not been thought out. Often it is a sop to one of the factions. This will do more to harm the client groups than it will to help them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The intention behind the process in train here seems to be entirely laudable and a move in the right direction. However, in recent days I have become aware of considerable failings in this program on the ground. There seems to be a considerable gap between what is proposed and what everybody agrees is desirable and what is actually happening in nursing homes, particularly the nursing homes caring for people who are mentally handicapped to some considerable degree. It seems that the Government is proceeding without doing what I understand it said it would do, namely, assess the needs of individuals patient or clients to see whether it was appropriate for them to be moved. Moreover, it said that it would not set up proper assessment criteria in the whole program but would find out how well the program was working and feed that information back to modify the program as it went along.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I can make up my mind on this matter, I want to ask the Minister a number of questions. I would like fairly quick replies so that we can go through this quickly. I foreshadow to the Minister that I have some 15 questions. If I can ask them one at a time and have a brief reply, that will help me make up my mind. The first question is: Is it the intention to shift all intellectually handicapped people at present in nursing homes into cottage style accommodation?

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Coulter could give us a copy of the 15 questions, that might expedite the answers. The answer to the first question is that, of course, there will always be people whose disabilities are such that they will want to remain in nursing homes; that is accepted. I have a copy of a letter which the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) sent to Senator Coulter yesterday answering matters that he had raised. If necessary, I will table it in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, I have only got a handwritten copy of these. I am reading from them, so it is a bit difficult for me to give them to the Minister for Resources, but I will read them through. I refer to the letter which the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) sent me yesterday. In that letter he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I give you my assurance that the proposed amendments to the NHAA and the subsequent transfer of nursing homes from the NHAA to the Disability Services Act will result in increased independence and support for everyone who is currently in an NHAA home.

That certainly seems to me to confirm what I have been told by those who are the care givers-that everybody will be shifted out of those homes irrespective of whether it is appropriate or not. That is what the Minister said in his letter. He said `for everyone'. That was the basis of the question. I am encouraged by what the Minister for Resources has said. He is obviously at variance with his senior partner in the matter.

I shall read these questions through quickly, and perhaps the Minister will get the tenor of them. Does the Minister recognise that there are severely intellectually handicapped people for whom this type of accommodation is not suitable? Evidently he does. What is to happen to these people? I again draw attention to the variation between the reply of the Minister for Resources and that given by the Minister for Community Services and Health in his letter. Does the Minister recognise that the cost of the care in cottage style accommodation for these people will be higher than in nursing homes? Has provision been made for increased funding?

Will individuals be individually assessed as to their suitability for this changed accommodation? That was apparently the intention but I am led to believe it is not happening. If they are being assessed individually, who is carrying out that assessment? Is the correctness of the assessments being itself assessed? Is the assessment being assessed to find out whether they are appropriate? Who is carrying out that assessment? Have assessment criteria for the appropriateness or otherwise of the whole program been established? I am led to believe that prior to or during the implementation of this program no assessment criteria were set by which its effectiveness or otherwise could be established. If assessment criteria have been set, will the Minister provide them? How well is the program performing by these assessment criteria if the assessment criteria have been set?

Is the Department of Community Services and Health asking nursing homes and disabled organisations to sign contracts in relation to the new arrangements in which no ongoing funding from government is being offered? I am also led to believe that the contracts are very much one-sided and that the nursing homes either sign the contract or get no funding. Is the Government holding a funding gun at the heads of nursing homes in that respect?

Finally, have departmental officers inspected the conditions in homes for the intellectually disabled? Is the Minister aware of numerous claims that departmental officers have refused to carry out inspections actually within the homes themselves to find out precisely what the conditions are? I have been told repeatedly that officers have merely visited the offices of the nursing homes and not actually gone into the nursing homes themselves. If the Minister would like those questions more slowly, I can go through them, but I think he has probably got the tenor of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some very similar questions. Senator Coulter has already pointed out the extra cost of putting these intellectually handicapped people, particularly those who are severely intellectually handicapped, out of nursing homes and into community-based accommodation. Is the Government prepared to fund this 100 per cent, or what proportion of the cost does the Government intend to fund? The Minister for Resources said that there will always be some intellectually handicapped people retained in nursing homes. If large nursing homes which cater exclusively for handicapped people have been told that they have got to abide by the Government's regulations and have their people out in community-based accommodation, and they are left with half a dozen or so people, what viability remains in those nursing homes? What has the Government done to make sure that a nursing home will be viable with only half a dozen or so people in there when it previously catered for 90? What funding does the Government intend to provide in this area?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of remarks have been made. I will not reply to all of them but I want to put clearly to the chamber that one of the more interesting speeches in the second reading debate-with due respect to all those who made speeches- was made by Senator Peter Baume. In that speech he said that for too long we have been worried about money and that has mesmerised debate in this area. He said that we should be concerned about the quality of outcomes. That is a point on which there ought to be a general consensus. I therefore draw to the attention of the Committee that in 1986 the Government received two reports, the nursing homes and hostels review by the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes and the Handicapped Program Review. Both these reports covered the area that we are now debating.

SPEECH.PARA: The reports came to what I think is an unexceptional, but nonetheless very important, conclusion: that young disabled people are the most disadvantaged people in Australian society, that we ought to be concerned about the quality of life for those people, and that by and large that was obtained when they lived in a more normal environment or an environment akin to that of other Australians rather than in institutions. Therefore, the reports concluded, there was a need to re-emphasise our programs to see that young disabled people had that quality of life.

In this legislation the Government is trying to deliver on that objective. In making transitions there are always difficulties of implementation. I want to go to Senator Coulter's list of questions soon, but I would like to take a moment to answer what I think was the essential question being asked by Senator Walters. In transferring nursing homes so that they go under the Disability Services Act, it is proposed that a new system of funding-not the old deficit financing system-be introduced. That system of funding is that, for services like podiatry and physiotherapy which are performed in institutions, cost of living indexation will be provided at the current rate of the grants to the institution. Those cost of living indexations would guarantee that the real value of those funds was maintained. The same money amount that is provided now on a per bed basis will be provided and will be indexed so that in real terms it will remain the same. But there is a recognition that there ought to be a meeting of some extra costs. There fore, things like the qualification of employees for long service leave or superannuation, which are not calculated on a per bed basis but occur upon qualification, ought to be picked up too. The Commonwealth will pick them up.

I do not know whether that answers Senator Walters's question in full but those funding measures are proper and, indeed, necessary on two bases. The first one is that they remove the open-endedness of deficit financing which currently applies. But, secondly, they guarantee the transitional safety net that is necessary in order to bring these changes in.

I go now to the list of questions that Senator Coulter asked me. I might have some difficulty in reading some of the writing so I will go through the list. I am sure Senator Coulter will correct me if I have misunderstood his question. Senator Coulter's first question related to the intent to transfer all. I have answered that. The answer is no. I do not think there is any difference at all. Senator Coulter is in error if he wishes to read into the contents of Dr Blewett's letter to him and my reply a minute ago a difference. Dr Blewett in his letter is saying that all will benefit and there will be an across the board improvement. That is consistent with what I am saying. It does not mean to say that everyone will transfer out of nursing homes.

If Senator Coulter's second question was, `Do we recognise there are severely handicapped people?', the answer is yes. I am not quite sure what Senator Coulter's third question was. But the fourth question is along the lines of: `Are the costs of care higher under the new proposals?'. The answer to that is: not necessarily. I have said in my answer to Senator Walters that there will be money available to cover the types of costs that Senator Coulter may be concerned about. The fifth question was: `Has provision been made for this funding?'. The answer is yes. Senator Coulter's sixth question was: `Are individuals being individually assessed and, if so, by whom?'. They are being assessed by the organisations concerned. They are the bodies that carry out the assessment.

I think Senator Coulter's eighth question was whether we checked on those assessments. The answer to that question is that we would largely accept those assessments as being valid. The next question was: `Have assessment criteria for the whole of the program been proposed or is there a set of principles?'. The principles and objectives of the Disability Services Act are the principles and objectives that we hold to assess these people against. They are set out in the Act. The next question was: `How well is the program performing?'. That is a question of what assessment the Department makes of progress thus far. In the Department's view and in the view of the clients by way of commentary to the Department, that program is performing very well.

Senator Coulter's eleventh question was a question to the Department about contracts. There was a follow-up question: `Are we holding guns to their heads?'. The answer to that is no; we are not holding guns at people's heads. The contracts are annual contracts for the purposes of the transition. Can Senator Coulter remind me of question No. 13?

TALK.START.PARA: —Have departmental officers inspected the conditions in homes for the intellectually disabled and are you aware that many allegations have been made that departmental officers have merely visited the offices of the homes but have refused to actually go into the homes to see the conditions of clients?

—The answer is yes; of course the homes are regularly inspected. But in terms of the last part of that question, I am not aware of those allegations but will take that up and check it. If it is a valid allegation, we will, of course, ensure that the proper inspections are carried out.

—I thank the Minister for his answer. As I understand it, the services will be kept up to date with consumer price index increases. The present money paid to the individual carers is being paid at the rate that they get at the moment, plus increases, some long service leave and other things like that. As the Minister would realise, if one had a 90-bed nursing home, for instance, and one was told that it had to close and that one had to transfer one's patients to the community based accommodation, the actual care in looking after 90 people in much smaller groups in various accommodation would involve more staff, additional assistance in dressing and showering people and all the assistance that should be given to handicapped people, even feeding and cooking for them. There is an additional cost involved because of the accommodation, staff and extra services as a result of smaller, community based accommodation. I have nothing but praise for the Government if it is able to fund that fully because, as the Minister has said, that certainly will create a far greater benefit to handicapped people. The question that I am very concerned about and it is the concern of the majority of the carers is: how on earth is the Government going to fund this new proposal? Several of the carers in some of the nursing homes have come out with the idea that it will cost at least three times the present cost of caring for each individual patient. I do not know whether they are accurate in their costings. They say that to look after someone in a larger nursing home costs at least three times less than putting that person into community based accommodation. Has the Government taken this into consideration? Where is the money coming from? Has all of this been costed?

—Senator Walters has raised what I regard as an important point. I will try to answer that point as fully as it requires. The Government's view is that we want to make the transition. There is a general view that that is the desirable outcome and that it would improve the quality of life of these disabled people who are, after all, not geriatrics. They are disabled and they should be treated humanely. There are costs in making that change. I choose these words carefully because it is important to make the point that while we would like to see the transition made by 1992, which is set out as the target date, it is not the Government's intention to bulldoze, force, push or shove. Rather, what the Department has been doing is talking to the institutions and working out, in their particular circumstances, the best outcome that can be attained for them. We are working with the institutions to make the transition. Already nine institutions have made the transition and 21 have applied to do so. That is an indication that the way we are proceeding is the proper way and it meets the needs of the institutions for which Senator Walters may be concerned.

—The Minister has not answered my question about the funding. Some of these nursing homes that have not yet made the transition are saying, `It's going to cost us at least three times more per patient to have them in community based accommodation. Who is going to foot the bill?'. That is the concern out in the community. I know that the Minister is well aware of it. Is the Government going to foot the bill for that extra finance or does it expect the community carers to be looking for the extra money amongst their communities?

—I have given the numbers of nursing homes that have applied or come across under the present arrangements. We argue that the concern expressed by those that have not made the transition-that it will cost three times the amount-is not reasonable in all of the normal circumstances. We think those organisations that are anxious about what the effects on them might be ought to talk to the Department-if I know their names I can encourage the Department to do this-about looking at their particular circumstances to see how those circumstances can best be met. However, funds are available for extra payments where that might be necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources said, if I understand him correctly, that the assessment of individuals in nursing homes is carried out by those who are the present carers. If a nursing home which has 70 or 90 patients who are seriously mentally handicapped, many of whom are older patients and therefore do not fall within the category in which the Minister attempted to embrace all clients who are being dealt with here, wants to remain open because it deems it totally inappropriate to move those patients into cottage-type accommodation where the problems of nursing and caring for them will be increased and where it will become more expensive, why is such a nursing home told that it must shut, that it must move all its clients into cottage-type accommodation? If that is not true, why did one such home write to Mrs Bedlington, the Director of the Department of Community Services and Health in Sydney, in June 1988 and say that it could not commit itself:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to any contract unless the eventual terms of it are capable of fulfilment. We will not take the easy course of signing and hoping, if in the process we put the long-term lives of our clients at risk, even at geriatric stages, or impose or seek to impose upon them anything they dislike or may prove detrimental to their health,
The letter continues:
We cannot embark on any transitional measures beyond our considerable achievements, unless we have demonstrated to us that funding will in perpetuity exist . . .

That may seem an extreme claim, but these people have actually signed contracts with parents, some of whom are now dead, to provide that service themselves and, therefore, they are legally bound to do that. The letter further states:

We ask that it be made clear that departmental Officers who have said: ``sign or there will be no funds'', were incorrectly stating Government policy or intent, perhaps be reason of over anxiety . . .
And still further on it is stated:

We are assured by Officers of your department that the special bulletin is in error when it states ``Until A Disability Services Act contract has been signed . . . services will continue . . . and will be required to adhere strictly to the requirements . . .

That all reads very much as though the Department is closing some of these nursing homes, which are providing services to seriously mentally handicapped people who are no longer young, in an attempt to force them into accommodation that is inappropriate. I would like an assurance that that is not the case and that the funding and care of these people, which is appropriate, as assessed by the care givers at the moment, can continue and that the gun is not being held at their heads.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Coulter's question is that we can give that guarantee. It is not the intention of the Department to force the closure or the transfer of individuals. I will make a general, philosophical observation: when issues of change are involved there is a tendency for anxiety to arise and for criticisms to be based on what could occur and not on what is the case. By and large, that is a problem of bad communication, I suppose. Nonetheless, it is a human foible and I recognise its existence. There are elements of that foible in some of the people who may be making those representations to Senator Coulter. As I said to Senator Walters earlier, the best way of assuaging those fears is to deal with the Department which should work through the case of each nursing home, taking into consideration what future arrangements would be. In terms of the assurance that Senator Coulter seeks about bulldozing or forcing the closure of nursing homes, the answer is no, that is not our intention. The funding is to continue in the way in which I have described which is, I think the honourable senator will agree, in a form that makes it an appropriate provision in these circumstances.

—The Minister has indicated that the same amount of money will be allocated to nursing homes that is presently allocated with a link to increases in the consumer price index. Senator Walters and, I think, Senator Coulter raised a valid point that I do not believe has been answered yet relating to the cost of this arrangement. The cost of group accommodation is said to be between $15,000 and $18,000 per person. The providers of these services have told us that the cost of community housing could be as high as $60,000 per person. Surely before the Government embarks upon a major move such as this, there must be a costing. The Department must have calculated what it will cost to transfer people from group accommodation into community housing. What is the cost? Surely the Minister does not expect the Committee to pass very important legislation that will affect the lives of disadvantaged people, without knowing the cost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept totally the thrust of the Government's philosophy in this area. It is the only way to go. I do not think there is any dispute about that in this chamber. I accept also the second point the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) made by way of a general assumption, that in times of change there is much anxiety. But while accepting both of those points, I have spent a great deal of time in the last year, as have other senators in this place, discussing this matter. There does not seem to be a great deal of anxiety or concern about the attitude of senior people in the Department. There is incredible concern about what they are being told by the people further down who are, whether the Minister likes it or not, putting the gun at people's heads. They may be denying it to their superiors, but it is happening.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree that we have to move. I agree that there is anxiety associated with change. I accept that people want to protect their own patch and the way things have been done before. It is accepted that those attitudes will arise. I do accept the Government's thrust in these matters. I remember discussing this matter with former Senator Grimes; I supported his philosophical position. But I must admit that in the last six months I have become more and more concerned that while the general philosophical thrust is undoubtedly correct, the implementation is really hurting people, because some people who are dealing with these various institutions are not dealing with them in any reasonable way. There are institutions in my State of Queensland-the Minister knows them well-that are running into great difficulties. For the first time ever they are in deficit. There are costs not being picked up any longer. There are people they will have to care for who have particular lifestyles that they want to maintain-whether we like it or not. We do not want the younger people to have those lifestyles, quite correctly, but the older people are in those lifestyles. They find it comfortable and want to stay there. We should not wander around and make all sorts of judgments from on high and say, `This is not good for you'. They are happy in those circumstances. They have been living in those circumstances for some time-sometimes for 15 or 20 years-and they want to stay there.

That type of provision needs to be maintained. The Government is not maintaining it. Regardless of what the Minister says here, the Government is forcing many of those organisations into deficit. Those organisations are not being funded. The people on the ground are not being funded. The people on the ground are not dealing with it in a decent and reasonable fashion. That is what we are getting. I am quite sure that, if the Minister were to talk to his back bench members, they would say that they were getting exactly the same type of information. At least with representative government, people on the ground are hearing these things. The Minister's senior people up here in Canberra may not be hearing them. It is happening. What is going to happen? Are we just going to plough on with these types of problems continuing or will the Minister do something to make sure that there is a more humane, reasonable and sensible application on the ground where those people are giving the care?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin makes a lot of sense. But appealing to the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) is not enough; it is not in the Minister's hands. The concern that Senator Macklin raises is now in the hands of the Australian Democrats. The Democrats, by supporting the amendment that the Opposition is moving, will take out of the legislation that transfer of the Nursing Homes Assistance Act into the Disability Services Act. If the Democrats support the amendment, the legislation will go before a Senate committee. The unions, the providers of the services and the patients who are able to make submissions to the Senate inquiry will be able to put their cases before a Senate committee that will have people from the National Party of Australia, the Liberal Party of Australia, the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party. Let that be the way we address the problem. I say again to the Democrats: do not pass the buck to the Government; it is in your hands. Senator Macklin and Senator Coulter know the problem. The Australian Democrats have the capacity to do something about it.

SPEECH.PARA: I will speak on another point that Senator Macklin raised. We came in here tonight and addressed Senator Cook, whose major responsibility is for resources and a number of other matters. He is only filling in for the responsible Minister, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). Senator Cook is getting his advice from the advisers of the Minister for Community Services and Health. I have a note here that supports Senator Macklin's accusation that people are being coerced into signing these agreements. I have permission to use the note in my speech to put this matter into the record. The Chief Executive of the Crowle Home for Sub-Normal Children has been told that if it signs the contracts it has almost as much time as it likes to come up with a transition plan. In the meantime it is guaranteed grants at least equal to the last year's grant plus consumer price index. But the Crowle Home has been told-I hope Senator Macklin is listening to this-that there is a general shortage of funds. It has been implied that, if it does not sign the contract, it is definitely going to suffer. The formula, as per the Department's bulletin, would be strictly enforced. In areas where it has not spent its budget level, it will be stuck with it in future years. This was very serious to the Crowle Home as, at present, it has underspent its wages vote by $80,000 because it cannot fill certain positions. That will mean that in next year's budget it will be $80,000 underfunded. Honourable senators on both sides of the chamber know that that is coercion in any way that one puts it. In fact, the Manager of Crowle puts it in even stronger terms. He feels that he is being bribed or threatened. Those are not my words; they are the words of the Manager of Crowle. The Minister gets up and gives us all the assurances and reassurances that things are great out in the welfare world; but, today, as I pointed out in my speech, the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of the Disabled met. Sixty-five people from every State in Australia gathered and passed a resolution. It was unanimously passed that this part of the legislation be withdrawn until a Senate committee can determine the response of the welfare agencies, the unions and all those types of people actively engaged in these nursing homes. The Minister has not given us an accurate cost. Will it cost $10,000 to put people in community accommodation? Will it cost $20,000 or $30,000? The Minister cannot tell me that it has not been costed because I do not believe that that is a fact. I do not believe that any responsible department or any responsible Minister would draw up legislation without any costing. It is unbelievable that the Minister can come into the Senate and say that. Can the Minister give us even a ball park figure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some things that I need to say about Senator Boswell's comments. First, by a slip of the tongue or an error of speech, he referred to disabled people as patients or clients. They are not. They are disabled people. They are not patients. They are people who suffer some disability but are otherwise able to make decisions for themselves. To regard them as patients is to misunderstand the type of person we are talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point, before I come to Senator Macklin's comments, is that Senator Boswell asked whether we can give a ball park cost? He seems to make an assumption that all of the individuals concerned might choose to go into community care, into a community group housing arrangement or some such proposition. One of the difficulties in offering a ball park figure is that the very idea of giving individuals choices as to what type of accommodation they go into makes problematic the forecasting of the costs until one finds out the choices that they have made. The type of accommodation that they may go into is home accommodation, in which case many of the costs may be met. It may be hostel accommodation; it may be nursing home accommodation. Therefore, the funding provided will be funding as we go along to meet the choices and the outcomes that arise from those choices. That is a perfectly reasonable answer to Senator Boswell's question.

I will now turn to the matters raised by Senator Macklin. I accept his comments that, at middle management level, there may be people in the Department who are bulldozing or forcing or however their actions are interpreted by the people at the other end to constitute that type of behaviour. I accept his recognition that that is not the intention of the Minister for Community Services and Health or the Department. His comments have been taken on board by us and by the advisers in attendance. We will take whatever steps are necessary within the Department to ensure that that is not the demeanour or the behaviour of departmental officials. Further than that, if there are particular cases that we should know of, we will investigate and take particular action on them. If we are apprised of those circumstances, we will do that.

Senator Macklin also made the point that some people may wish to choose to remain in institutional care. That is a fair choice that they may wish to make. It is probably not the choice of younger people but those who have been aclimatised to that type of living may wish to stay in-if I can put in these terms; I do not mean to be patronising-the security that they feel in that type of arrangement. These proposals enable us to assure Senator Macklin that, in how they elect to be accommodated, they will have the same level and types of care that they would have in an institution. The first question Senator Coulter asked me was whether all people will be moved out of nursing homes. Within these arrangements, there will be an ability to meet that elected choice.
Question put:
That the clauses be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of the Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the Bill, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my movement around nursing homes in Victoria one thing that has concerned me has been the fact that funding for nursing home residents is on the basis that the day the resident goes into the nursing home is counted as one day and the day the resident goes out of the nursing home is counted as the same day the resident went in. If the resident dies there is no funding for the resident on that day. Many nursing homes are so strapped for funds that they rush a new resident into a bed the day a patient has left that bed, that is, the day the patient has died. It was brought to my attention in a small town I visited recently that a man in a nursing home there had died and his sister was put into a bed in the same home that afternoon. Because the nursing home staff found it so distasteful they shifted all the patients around so that the woman did not have to go into her deceased brother's bed.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister whether it would be possible for residents to be funded for the day they go into the nursing home and the day they go out of the nursing home if they die. It does not leave the staff of the nursing home time to grieve, especially if they have been nursing the patient for 10, 11, 12 or 15 years. It is another example of the callous way nursing home residents are being dealt with. The Minister said in one of his speeches that what we are really on about is the quality of outcome and the quality of life. I agree that they should be goals. But if we are so mean we cannot fund a resident for the day he dies, there is something wrong with the system. When we were debating changes to nursing homes and their funding, Opposition senators drew attention to the fact that there would be serious problems in the nursing home industry because of current changes.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the Minister's attention to a report which will appear tomorrow, commissioned by the Victorian Age Services Peak Council, which confirms the fears that the standard of nursing homes and quality of life will have fallen in many nursing homes. The report makes the points that working conditions for nurses and other staff are pressured, causing stresses in the system and explosive industrial relations implications; that communications with residents and their relatives have worsened due to a rushed atmosphere in many homes. The Minister has just told the Committee tonight that what he is on about and what Minister Staples is on about is quality of outcome and the quality of life. We have here a situation where patients die in nursing homes and their beds are filled before the bed is cold, with no time for staff to grieve or to deal with the situation. What we shall see now, because of the change in funding, is a rushed atmosphere in many nursing homes where nobody talks to a patient about being afraid to die, or about the fact that their daughter has died or that there is something wrong with somebody in their family. The staff do not have time to cope with those matters any more. The report also shows that activities for residents are being cut back to medical and nursing necessities, so that there is no time for any extras, and that building and equipment maintenance is also suffering.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), in a statement on 3 May, said that the new arrangements being progressively introduced were based on the needs of residents. I cannot believe that the Minister can now hold to the view that arrangements which are being progressively introduced are based on the needs of residents. We see what is happening and we predicted that the position would worsen, and I predict that it will become even worse. The study which has been carried out on 27 Victorian nursing homes-more Victorian nursing homes than the Department has visited-has shown in both the private and voluntary sector that this Government's arrangement for the funding of nursing homes is failing. This will affect, and indeed is affecting, older people who deserve a better deal. It is affecting the industry as a whole. In recent years geriatric nursing has become much more acceptable, but with the changes that are occurring leading to a lowering of standards nurses will flee geriatric nursing. I believe that this Government has a lot to answer for. I hope that the Minister will have a response to the report I have mentioned, which is an indictment of this Government's treatment of elderly people, particularly elderly Victorians.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill agreed to.
AGED OR DISABLED PERSONS HOMES AMENDMENT BILL
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 21, before paragraph 19 (a), insert the following new paragraph:
``(aa) by omitting from subsection (1) ``Conditions formulated'', and substituting ``Subject to subsections (3) and (4), conditions formulated''.
(2) Page 21, after paragraph 19 (a), insert the following new paragraph:
``(ab) by adding the following subsections after subsection (2):

`(3) Conditions formulated under this section are not to include any condition, however formulated, requiring a resident capital-funded organisation to provide services to a person who is financially disadvantaged.

`(4) For the purposes of subsection (3), a resident capital-funded organisation is an organisation which has not received financial assistance by way of a grant towards capital works costs in respect of a hostel operated or proposed to be operated by that organisation.'.''.

The Government has said that in order for a hostel to receive recurrent subsidies it must have a 20 per cent quota of financially disadvantaged residents. Hostel owners had to sign an agreement to this effect by 10 January under the threat of losing subsidy. We seek to remove that 20 per cent aggregation between hostels. We believe that it is unfair to hostels, many of which are church owned and have been funded by residents-by people who have liquidated their assets to be able to get into a hostel and to provide for themselves in their frailty or old age. These are not wealthy people. Under this legislation as it stands, the people who have liquidated their assets, these `near poor' people, would be subsidising the really disadvantaged people. The Opposition maintains that disadvantaged people have the right to live in old people's homes and accommodation, but that this should not be subsidised by people who have saved and who have put aside some money during their lifetime. I believe that the Australian Democrats will support these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to hear the Minister's response on these amendments; I am not completely clear as to their effect. I have been approached by elderly people who have gone into nursing homes under conditions in which they have signed a contract between themselves and the nursing home that the nursing home will provide certain services to them, and that they will provide certain money to the nursing home. Subsequently the nursing homes have found it necessary to abrogate that contract because the conditions imposed on the nursing homes by the Government have been changed. Elderly people who believed that they had made such an arrangement for the rest of their lives have found themselves further disadvantaged. I am not clear whether Senator Boswell seeks to overcome that difficulty by way of his amendments. If that is the case, I would like to hear the Minister's response. If that is the case, it seems to me unfair of the Government to push nursing homes into a position where they are forced to abrogate a legal contract between themselves and some of their residents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed amendments are not relevant to the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Amendment Bill. This Bill deals with planning for the future. These amendments seek to make provision for people who might be financially disadvantaged in certain circumstances. Therefore, they are not relevant to this Bill. To some extent that should take care of some of the questions raised by Senator Coulter. On the point he made, I am advised that out of 974 nursing homes, 972 have signed this agreement. I think that speaks for itself in terms of whether there is any reluctance on the part of the institutions themselves to agree to these proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's amendments seek to vary the new hostel recurrent funding agreements so that hostels which have not received Commonwealth capital funding-that is, where there is 100 per cent resident capital funding-should not be subject to requirements to accommodate a percentage of financially disadvantaged people. The amendments, as I have said, are not relevant to the Bill. Rather, they are relevant to the issue of variable capital funding in respect of legislation passed by both Houses in 1987. I think Senator Boswell is trying to widen the debate. The background of his interest in these amendments was the Uniting Church in New South Wales. I have here a letter from the Uniting Church New South Wales Synod, Board for Social Responsibility, signed by the Rev. Harry J. Herbert, General Secretary, written to the Hon. Peter Staples, Minister for Housing and Aged Care, in which Mr Herbert says:
. . . I believe that the arrangements as set out in your letter are most satisfactory.
He says in a concluding paragraph:

I regret that an obvious misunderstanding has occurred, but I am delighted that the issue has been settled and the agreement is most suitable to our purposes. You can be assured that my aim is to have the largest possible number of financially disadvantaged person admitted to Uniting Church hostels.

I table that letter because it does go to the point that Senator Boswell is raising. On behalf of the major organisation affected, it is writing to say that it is now satisfied, given the assurances that the Minister has given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to disagree with the Minister for Resources. We may be at cross purposes. The Government has said that in order for hostels to continue to receive a recurrent subsidy, they must have a 20 per cent quota of financially disadvantaged residents. Hostels have had to sign an agreement to that effect by 10 January 1989 under threat of losing their subsidies if they did not sign the it. Many of the hostels are involved. Many of the Uniting Church's hostels are involved, but others are involved too. These hostels were funded by residents borrowing money and committing themselves to repay the capital. They very often involved their own church. I suppose that the Catholics had raffles and the Lutherans had lamington drives and so forth. The church actually raised the money, thus relieving the Government of the responsibility of paying the capital to build the facility. So the Government did not have to provide the capital, but it had to provide the recurrent expenses. The Government, by introducing this arrangement, will retrospectively alter the arrangements that are in place between the individuals who have put up their own money and the churches and the other organisations that have borrowed money to set these places up.

SPEECH.PARA: What this legislation does is to say, `If you do not have 20 per cent of disadvantaged people in your particular home, then we will not continue to fund you'. The Opposition maintains that the residents of these homes have paid for the homes. They paid the capital expenditure on the homes. The Government is now retrospectively altering an agreement which says that the people who built the homes and provided the capital to build the homes have not got to provide 20 per cent of places for the disadvantaged. The residents in these homes are going to have to subsidise the disadvantaged people who could not afford them. We maintain that the severely disadvantaged have got to have somewhere to live but that it is not the responsibility of the original movers who provided the capital; it is the responsibility of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one fundamental flaw in what Senator Boswell has put. He has put that each hostel has to have a 20 per cent disadvantaged component. That is not so. The point that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) has brought out is that across the aggregate population of all the hostels for the Uniting Church there is 20 per cent of disadvantaged people. Some may have none, some may have 5 per cent and some may have some other percentages. But I repeat that the Uniting Church in Australia has indicated by the letter I have tabled that it is satisfied with the arrangements.

—I accept that the Minister has a letter from the Uniting Church in Australia and that the letter may well state that. What my amendment seeks to do is to clarify what is contained in that letter by putting it in the legislation. I believe that the Minister has written to the Uniting Church and given it that assurance. Assurances are wonderful, but they are not as complete as having them included in the legislation. This is what I am trying to get across to the Minister. Yes, I think the Uniting Church has been given that assurance, but it is not in the legislation. If Senator Coulter supports this amendment, it will be enshrined in this legislation. I think we are both going in the same direction; we both want to get to the same place. But what the Minister is telling me is that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care has given the Uniting Church an assurance. What I am seeking to do is get that assurance enshrined in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have tabled the letter from the Hon. Peter Staples to the Rev. H. Herbert, General Secretary of the Board for Social Responsibility, Uniting Church in Australia, which sets out the undertakings that he has given.
—Incorporate it.
—Then I seek leave to incorporate the letter in Hansard. I also seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letter that I earlier tabled from the Uniting Church in Australia replying to the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
14 April 1989
Reverend H. Herbert
General-Secretary
Board for Social Responsibility
Uniting Church in Australia
222 Pitt Street
Sydney NSW 2000
Dear Reverend Herbert

I understand that a meeting took place on the 30 March 1989, between yourself, Reverend Ian Bowden and senior members of the Department of Community Services and Health about your organization's capacity to meet the requirements of the Commonwealth Hostel Recurrent Funding Agreement to accommodate financially disadvantaged people.

The meeting took place as a result of my concern that the Uniting Church was basically unaware, despite extensive negotiations and correspondence with the AAVCA Hostel Negotiating Committee, whose NSW representative is from the Uniting Church, and the Director of the Uniting Church's Synod Aged Care Agency, of my detailed proposal on aggregation specifically developed to address the concerns of the Church hostels in New South Wales.

Some specific aspects of the aggregation proposal were raised with me in discussion with Mr Kell of Woodfield Retirement Village and Mr Townley on 20 April in Canberra. These aspects are covered by the arrangements set out below.

I am pleased to be able to confirm the following as my understanding of the agreement reached at the meeting with you, an agreement not being different from arrangements previously put to Uniting Church Hostels. These arrangements were set out in the letter dated 21 November 1988, which was sent by the State Office to every hostel, and accompanied the proposed recurrent funding agreement to be signed by the hostel.

Therefore I was surprised by the debate in the House of Representatives, considering that the outcomes of joint negotiations has been known months before the Opposition members raised these matters. Prima facie it seemed as if the Uniting Church was attempting to re-open the issue after negotiations had been settled.

It is specifically agreed that the Uniting Church in NSW may meet the conditions for accommodating financially disadvantaged people by achieving the 20% requirement as an average of the occupied place days of all existing Uniting Church hostels receiving recurrent funding in NSW.

Completion of the necessary documentation can be achieved by the signing of a single agreement that includes an attachment that will nominate the percentage of financially disadvantaged persons to be accommodated in each of the hostels, such that the average of 20% over all occupied place days can be met. As already discussed with the Sydney office of the Department, this will need to be decided upon and completed by 30 June 1989. I have asked the Sydney office to contact your office shortly to assist you in settling this matter.

I would also like to confirm that although the 20% figure will remain a constant and essential requirement as an average over all existing Uniting Church hostels in New South Wales, the specific percentage nominated for any individual hostel may be varied by agreement. This specific percentage is to be achieved as an average of occupied place days in that hostel over a financial year. Minor variation in the achievement of the specific percentage will of course be taken into account, as there will always be variations in a hostel's admission rate and in the care needs of potential residents.

For your information, all hostels will be able to monitor their achievement of their required percentages through the monthly recurrent subsidy claims form. From June, 1989, hostels will be able to commence recording the financial status of residents on the form. Through a simple updating, hostels will be able to easily monitor their current monthly levels, and their year-to-date levels in achieving their specific average.

I understand the definition of a financially disadvantaged person was also raised. It has always been the Commonwealth's intention that the persons so targeted are the frail aged in receipt of maximum rate pension who are also non-homeowners and, to this extent, changes in the Social Security arrangements impact on the definition of financial disadvantage from time to time. The current definition is attached.

On the basis of the meeting held and the agreement reached on the proposals, I believe that it is not now necessary for me to meet with you. However should you require any further assistance, please contact the State Office or either of my officers who participated in the meeting with you.

I appreciate the time both you and Reverend Ian Bowden have made available, and the co-operative approach taken to resolve any misunderstandings of the earlier negotiations with the Uniting Church in New South Wales. I look forward to further development of our relationship in providing residential care services for the frail aged.
Yours sincerely
Peter Staples
The Hon. Peter Staples, M.P.,
Minister for Housing and Aged Care,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA A.C.T. 2600
Dear Mr Staples,

Thank you for your letter of 14 April regarding Uniting Church aged persons hostels in New South Wales. Mr Bowden and myself appreciated the opportunity to discuss this matter with Mr David Kelaher and I believe that the arrangements as set out in your letter are most satisfactory.

In regard to your comment that it appeared to you that ``the United Church was attempting to re-open the issue after negotiations had been settled'', I must stress that I had no knowledge of this having occurred. When I wrote my letter to ``The Sydney Morning Herald'' and when I approached Opposition members of parliament, I was acting under advice that aggregation of the 20% ratio was not acceptable to the Government. The responsibilities of my Board within the church cover chaplaincy, welfare, and social justice issues. While the Synod Aged Care Agency is a unit of our Board, I am not involved in day to day administration.

I regret that an obvious misunderstanding has occurred, but I am delighted that the issue has been settled and the arrangement is most suitable to our purposes. You can be assured that my aim is to have the largest possible number of financially disadvantaged persons admitted to Uniting Church hostels.
I look forward to future good relations with your Department.
Yours sincerely,
REV. HARRY J. HERBERT
General Secretary

TALK.START.PARA: —Taken together, I think those letters raise this question: given those assurances and the acceptance of the assurance by the organisations affected, there is no need to put this provision in the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —With all due respect, a letter written by a Minister gives no assurance to anyone. Our amendment simply seeks to exempt from the areas of financially disadvantaged placements those hostels that have been fully self-funded. Complying with this requirement means that legal contracts entered into by the hostel management with the residents who capital funded those hostels would be overridden. All we are seeking to do is put the assurance contained in that letter in the legislation. By voting for this amendment, we do that.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Boswell's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise one matter. The Bill says that in section 9aa the Minister may, by notice in writing, published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, specify a number as the maximum number of hospital places for a region, et cetera. The Minister's second reading speech indicated that the Government's objective was to provide 100 residential care places per 1,000 people, aged 70 years and over, with a mix within this 100 of 60 hostel places to 40 nursing home places. Earlier in the Act, under section 3, interpretation, an eligible person is described as being an aged or disabled person who is assessed as requiring hostel care services, et cetera.

SPEECH.PARA: Frequently, one finds in these places disabled persons who, very clearly, are in need of care. Given the Government's objective of providing 100 residential care places per 1,000 people aged 70 years and over, I ask the Minister: What provision is there for beds for those who are disabled and in need of this type of care who are under the age of 70 years, as is so often the case? Is it a fact that the aged are the people who miss out and cannot get places or are there some other criteria for determining beds for those who are disabled-people who have been involved in motor vehicle accidents and the like?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give Senator Reid the information she seeks. However, I will confer with the Minister and provide an answer.
